anything worth recommending in such a fundamentally bad film, filled with atrocious dialogue, terrible editing and a general sense of aimlessness, A Wrinkle in Time may mean well but it doesn't make the experience any more bearable, as we are forced to endure almost 2 hours' worth of schmaltz and underserved preaching. A genuine turkey, this is the film to beat when it comes to the title of worst film of 2018.½ a giant Oprah out of 5

The act was amazing, effects, too. For me it was a bit too fantastic but when you see after all this pizzazz you can actually fully understand where all of it comes from. It is a great storyline that I as a viewer enjoyed a lot. It has a deep meaning which is why this movie is worth watching.

There are no PG Disney movies with this much disturbing material. 
There are no PG 13 Disney movies this disturbing!
I'm not picky about fantasy violence in avengers or Star Wars. It makes its point and moves on. I had good faith that Disney would bring a beautiful show to us. 
This movie had three beautiful Mrs. characters. That's what I liked. That's all I liked. 
They spent far too much time demonizing a young character in a dark place. We don't need to be immersed in evil to know its place in this story, or in life. It's PG! If I wanted to see a possessed child (WHO really DOES?) I would've chosen a different genre. 
It gave us all a bad feeling.. I kept waiting for good parts to come in, but it had to teach a lesson and leave everyone feeling nearly as souless as the IT.. I just don't understand the point. Are you trying to make kids feel dark things when they are coming to be lightened and uplifted? Show the problem, but don't become the problem! 
I really couldn't care less about the concerns with the Universalism themes.. like, it's shown in many of the recent space travel movie concepts, interstellar really comes to mind. But honestly I don't know how it went because we left when the kid started getting a demonic voice (not even joking, it happens). 
You can be WOKE, and yet you can still choose to see the good in the world. I want good, uplifting entertainment for my kids.. I should've researched this more.. but it's a Disney PG movie, and the ones I've seen are Frozen, Tangled, etc. So i was totally blown away when it turned Stephen King. I'm totally sensitive to this, but so are kids.
This movie is absolutely one of the worst. Don't waste your time or money on this one.

I've often contended that "boring" is the worst thing a film can be. Wrinkle in Time makes me rethink that. An exercise in doing, saying & being too much, Wrinkle... certainly isn't boring, but it is bad. 
It has a lot in common with Tomorrowland: live-action, visually-heavy Disney fantasy-adventures, headed by lauded filmmakers, which celebrate braininess. But where Tomorrowland was simply misguided, Wrinkle... is a straight-up disaster. It gets credit for being Disney's most enigmatic, eccentric experiments in years, taking visual and philosophical cues from Jodorowsky and Kubrick. Unfortunately, all intended awe and wonder is swallowed up by good, old-fashioned ineptness.
The story of a girl having to "tesser" across the universe to find her long-lost dad gets some things right, including the critical casting of the lead girl. Unfortunately, this engaging young actress can't quite right this time-traveling ship. The rest of the oddly-casted actors certainly don't help. Galifianakis plays a god-like being doing modern, self-aware schtick for some reason ("I like earthtones."); Witherspoon's comic-relief is more annoyingly repetitve than funny; brilliant ad-libber Kaling is forced into delivering constant platitudes; and deus-ex-Oprah leans into stoicism instead of inspiration. 
These obnoxious side-characters disappear eventually, and the film gets better for it, with potent descriptions of the evil "It" and some great, creepy suburban set-pieces. But it's really too late at that point. So much has gone wrong in so many ways (clunky editing, awful exposition, abrasive music, unearned emotions, prescription drug commercial graphics, ill-timed humor, laughable performances, etc), blame must be placed on normally stellar director DuVernay (Selma) for how unwieldy the final product feels. A forgettable, messy waste of a great cast and iconic source material.

I'll start off by flat out saying that I have not read the books, therefore I will be judging this movie in isolation. That is of course how I believe that all book adaptations should be judged, for what they are. Sadly, this movie in and of itself is legitimately bad.Starting with the positive, I did enjoy some of the cinematography and special effects. However, the movies fails to even be consistent with this, far too much of it feels unfortunately bland for the absurdity of what they're tackling in this movie, which in contrast with the absurdity of this movie, makes the absurdity feel out of place. They're mixed attempts at grounded storytelling and ridiculous storytelling make for a weird dosage. As you can see I've already dived into negatives, because I've sadly already named the positives.This movie tries way too often to be serious, having dark and dramatic scenes that just don't work. The reason they don't work is because half the movie tries to be silly, while the other half relies on us caring. Which I simply don't. Not only does much of the goofy side of this movie come off as annoying, but there isn't enough realism and relatability in characters for me to care about them when the movie does get dramatic.As far as the characters, the flaws come out both from the performances and the writing. So much so that the lines begin to get blurry where the flaws are emitting from, thus I have difficulty pinpointing precisely what is wrong with the characters. But every single character in this movies has flaws.Our three main protagonists in this movie are played by child actors, which is often where movies take a wrong step. I think Storm Reid gave a fine performance, but ultimately her character felt bland. I feel that if she had been given more to do in this movie it would've helped her to stand out. Deric McCabe does poorly, I believe he was miscast in this role, although most of the scenes that really don't work for him would be hard for any child actor to pull off. Also his scenes where he had very little to do felt strangely off, as though he just wasn't up to the task yet. I believe that he was absolutely miscast in this role, and it's possible that it could've been done well by another actor. I believe Levi Miller does fine, but his character ultimately felt far too bland, and when he didn't feel bland he felt weird, but not in an endearing way, in a slightly creepy or offbeat way that just failed. Let's just say that our supporting characters are just as all over the place as our main three, they don't get better.The reason I have yet to mention the plot of this movie yet, is that I might be forgiven for forgetting one was attempted. It is straightforward, predictable, generic, but its biggest crime is that it is forgettable. It's not exactly terrible, although in parts bad, it just fails to be memorable.This movie was absolutely all over the place, from strange attempts at being creepy, which ultimately came across accidentally hilarious, to bizarre attempts at extremely cheesy messages that fell flat on their face. The unintentionally humorous moments made this movie easier to watch, and fortunately my experience was not aggressively annoying. That being said, this movie is genuinely bad, there's hardly anything good in it. Save your two hours and do something else with your life, this one just isn't worth it.

The next film on Disney Plus alphabetically was "A Wrinkle In Time" the flop from 2018 that I didn't see at the time and, in retrospect, wish I hadn't invested the time in now.Angry and withdrawn since the disappearance of her father, Meg (Storm Reid) is given the chance to find him when three . . . spirits (?) give her the chance to travel across time and space and rescue him (Chris Pine). Along with her brother Charles Wallace? Charles Wallace, Charles Wallace? Charles Wallace! Charles Wallace, Charles Wallace, Charles Wallace! Charles Wallace? (Deric McCabe) and a neighbourhood boy Calvin (Levi Miller) who wanders into the plot by accident, they travel the galaxy trying to retrace her fathers movements.I only realised at the end credits that this was another movie that Disney adapted from the work of Madeleine L'Engle and after this, and the awful "A Ring Of Endless Light" adaptation that I had to sit through a couple of weeks back, I'm glad there aren't any more. It's a shame that all of the criticism for the film seemed to land on Ave DuVernay's lap - when the flaws with this film mostly lie with its terrible story. It's a nonsensical and boring plot which isn't interested in it's sci-fi trappings despite bothering to explain them in great detail, instead favouring a painfully on the nose metaphor for not giving in to ones darker and more destructive feelings.Which is not to say that the films production gets away scot-free. Some CGI moments are better than others and it's pacing is all wrong. It's doesn't do a good job of explaining what people's motivations are - certainly in the last third, or what the villain actually wants, or why it switches from an ethereal evil - to a specific possession element. Scenes happen, and then are walked away from without progressing the plot. Performances aren't great, though the kids are better than the adults in this regard, but the most annoying aspect of the film though was to have a character called "Charles Wallace" and then to have other characters repeatedly shout both sections of the name over and over again as they look for him.It's looking to be a "Wizard of Oz-esque" magical experience, but it doesn't have a story to offset its painfully twee whimsy. A horrible time.

reviews.review_title: Not anything close to the book
reviews.content: I agree with above, a step in the wrong direction. I was able to see this as a sneak peek, and I was very disappointed. I am used to Oprah preaching to everyone, but this time it kills the plot and makes the story line read like Karl Marx's "Das Kapital'. The movie was boring at times, and became very predicable. Would not waste my money to see it.

This movie starts off bad and manages to get worse, the characters are totally forgettable. Time seems to stand still while you hope it will soon end.
If your kids have been naughty make them watch this film, they will never misbehave again. 😂

reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle in Time? More Like a waste of one
reviews.content:
Full of cliches and soap opera like performances, A Wrinkle in Time throws away any chance it had from its wild premise, by simply making itself more ordinary than any other movie this year. Chris Pine is undoubtedly the biggest stand out of this confusing cast, but his screen time only clocks in at maybe 10 minutes, and certainly is something worth missing for the case of a better way to spend 2 hours. Disney should stick to what they're good at and stop trusting otherwise generic films with such monster blockbuster budget. But then again, when you have the money to fail, why not go all out? Lets just say you're better watching the canadian disney channel version instead.
My Rating: 4/10

reviews.review_title: It's as bad as you fear.
reviews.content: It's such a shame this movie is so terrible. I'm sure they made it with the best intentions. Good actress in the lead role. Positive message. Defeat the evil without nuclear weapons. Could have been good right?Could have been.... but isn't.It's a terrible movie, just terrible. I haven't read the book, and doubt I ever will. So what's bad about it? Other than it's way too long, there's no plot as such. It's just a long maguffin hunt. It's badly directed. It makes over use of CGI. The script is pure cheese. There's a big green flying cabbage scene.If you are in two minds about going to see this movie then hark my words:Don't.

Just because you have Oprah Winfrey and Reese Witherspoon in a movie doesn't mean you don't have to make an effort this felt like they had made the movie back when the book was written very basic special effects the same that you get from a Saturday morning cartoon nothing special save your $

I feel like this film was only made so Disney can say they have a film with a female director and Oprah as a lead actress. This entire film was pointless. The book was decent. This film should be forgotten from the sands of time.

reviews.review_title: A waste, a disappointment, too abysmal for words...
reviews.content: Every wrong decision that could have been made here was made. Good Grief. Believe the negative reviews; this catastrophe is so bad it's shocking it even got green lit. Man...Good thing the director was a liberal black woman because no one else would be able to have their career recover from this. She has her social justice to keep her warm, and once she gets back in it again the critics will start praising her to the skies like how they were doing before this came out.Anyway, we have no giant evil brain, no oppressive concrete Camazotz, no suspense, no acting, no plot, no decent scenes. This is a Wrinkle in Time where Oprah does yoga with Zach Galifikakis (or whatever his name is) in a long pointless sequence. This is a Wrinkle in Time where one of the characters strips and transforms into some kind of lettuce flatworm that functions both as a trampoline and an amusement park ride. This is a Wrinkle in Time where the most evil actions in the world are represented with a woman trying not to be fat and a homeless man getting his bag of weed stolen. This is a Wrinkle in Time where the greatest evil tempts you by suggesting that you could look like a model. This is Disney.

Quite possibly one of the worst movies I have ever had the misfortune of seeing. The plot was a jumbled mess. The characters were hard to connect with and the acting was subpar at best. Would never recommend to anyone

reviews.review_title: Truly awful, wooden and dull. Don't waste your time
reviews.content: Hollywood ripped the guts out of L'Engle's book, leaving only cliché and schmaltz. Outrageously bad. This film budget must have just been to launder some crooked money, I guess.Especially the last half is insultingly dull. I'm not sure why I persevered. Perhaps I expected more than a super cliché ending.

I couldn't even finish the movie. I am speechless it was just so bad. I mean acting , direction , make up, dialogues just a very poorly done movie which did not make any sense at all. 0/10 A complere Waste of time and money.

reviews.review_title: "Waste" of Time is more like it!
reviews.content: Simply put, this thing was absolutely atrocious. No respect for the source material Oprah still can't act but I'm sure she'll swing an Oscar for this piece of garbage. Poorly directed, incoherent storytelling. Can't believe that that this Director will now be given the reigns of DC's "New Gods!" I am quite sure she will destroy that source material also. Way to go Disney and DC, you both stink! If you want to make bad movies, write new stories to screw up, don't ruin the ones we have all held near and dear for so long. A winkle in time is more like a wast of time!!

After seeing this movies, I re-read the book to understand whether my confusion was poor memory, or something else..... it was something else. First the good news, Oprah is fabulous in all her glory, and so is Storm Reid cast as Meg in all the horrible situations she's forced to endure....and Charles Wallis not bad either. But you can't make up for the fundamental flaws. The movie fails to convey a clear story, and completely misses a key part of the original story in its rush to get Meg and company home. An example of how this movie could have been made? Look no further than the Wizard of Oz which is an adaptation of a book, involves a young girl on a journey, a fantasy world, with munchkins , talking trees, good and bad witches, a yellow brick road, a mission, several and a yearning to return home. It has strong characters, a clear story, a pivotal crisis, and an ending. Its special effects are limited to a spinning house and a melting witch.Cut the gimmicks, and back to a simple framework: key characters, key moments, key emotions, and tell the story with the strong voice of a little girl who is a torrent of emotion and who with the help of a classic trio: three wonderful witches, courageously acts in the face of fear.

Before I start I must say I had no prior knowledge of the book this was based on. Cards on the table, I'd never heard of it. However I saw the trailer for the film and it looked intriguing so I thought I'd give it a shot. Unfortunately I gave up after an hour or so. It comes across like a fever dream of a My Little Pony obsessed child. I must be honest in that I had no idea what the hell was going on. And no, its not because I didn't understand the overall meaning but rather the slip shod way the narrative tried to portray it. It's just jam packed with Maguffins with the odd sprinkling of real science to try and give it some legitimacy. And plot holes..so, so many! I think what realy annoyed me though was the PS1 type CGI flying lettuce. And the way the characters kept calling the kid "Charles Wallace". Is that his name cos that ain't a name. Really annoyed me for some weird reason. What really annoyed me though was the way the film portrayed horrific human behaviour as the influence of some alien entity. That's a bit of a terrible message....you're not responsible. No doubt fans of the book will be seething at what I have just said but I am not criticising the book, this review is purely based on the film and that is the way the film portrayed it.

reviews.review_title: Too Wrinkled to Matter (or lacking passion for the story)
reviews.content: It's just not a good movie. Everything was there with the budget and cast for it to be amazing, but it just didn't translate the compelling characters and the weight of this story to the screen. They tried hard to make it meaningful and important, but I wonder whether the people involved in translating this story to screen, who seem talented enough, were personally passionate about the source material. As long as the director and screenwriters are talented storytellers if they are personally passionate about the source material the difference is usually massive (see Battlefield Earth for an example of passion for the story but no storytelling talent at director/screenwriter). One clear contrast of this is Peter Jackson's 'Lord of the Rings' trilogy (2001-2003), who was personally passionate about the source material, compared to the 'Chronicles of Narnia' trilogy (2005-2010) where that was missing: IMDB avg: LOTR 8.8 vs. CofN 6.6Rotten Tomatoes avg: LOTR 93% vs 64%U.S. Gross avg (adj. for infl.): LOTR $530m vs. CofN $238mSo, I think the ratings for 'A Wrinkle in Time' point to a lack of passion for the source material and the resultant quality of the movie: IMDB 4.2, Rotten Tomatoes 42 (RT audience score even lower at 35%).

reviews.review_title: Like A Film Project For A High School Student
reviews.content: I read the book growing up, but even if i hadn't, this was one of the worse movies i have ever seen. I am surprised there were so many "famous" actors/tress in it. The acting reminded me of a high school film project. Super cheesy and the plot was not well put together. I couldn't understand the little boy either. The part where Mindy said "daaaannnngggg!" really was just it for me. I wanted to walk out of the theater but i had kids with me, who by the way, were also very embarrassed while watching this film.

It is, by all means, I mean by all negative means.
It has the perfect recipe for a BOMB, like you can't go wrong (or maybe right in this movie's case) if you follow it, THE PERFECT BOMB.
The script, the dialog, the idea, the concept, the (unoriginal) VFX, the soundtrack, the cinematography, the lighting, etc....
This was suppose to be a history mark movie, It's the very 1st movie for an African American women with a budget over $100m, well, it's history though but the very different/wrong reasons.
I understand, actors will do anything for money, so let's not talk about them, I've seen worst from great actors, BUT OPRAH?
Please, for god sake, what's the BLOND AMBETION you are having?
What's all the glitters & Swarovski crystals in the eyebrows?
What's with the 5 costumes that u appeared in your own 5 scenes, including the giant you?
For god's sake, you are a public figure, an idol for many, a TV cable network owner, Oprah... you are a legend, what are you doing to yourself?
What a Shame.
(I will not dare calling the KARDASHIANS stupid, after this movie, and after see what Oprah did to herself and to her public image)

Wow. this is so bad, couldn't watch the entire thing. Left after 15 minutes. Someone else bought the ticket, and I couldn't stop apologizing for them wasting their money. If you see this tripe, you are desperate. Wait til it comes out on video and ignore it all over again. Ms. Winfrey should stick to guest shots on cbs morning show. Mr. Disney would roll over in his grave if he was forced to watch this. Please, please say there won't be a sequel.

reviews.review_title: I Was Angry by the End of the Movie
reviews.content: This was a beloved book of mine growing up. I very much related to Meg as an awkward pre-teen. I was excited about the change in the diversity of the characters and the fantastical costuming. Those were the only things that I think were done well. I purposefully did not read the book recently so I wouldn't criticize changes. However, I felt some of the key elements of the story were lost. Some of the changes didn't make sense to me were they trying to make this story more exciting than it was in the book?First off, the bond between Charles Wallace and Meg was totally lost in this movie. I kept waiting for it during the warming the milk scene and it never materialized. Then the whole thing about the forests popping up, the whirlwind and the wall in Kamozots was entirely fabricated. Why? Then the kids that were playing ball, there was a kid that was doing the ball thing erratically. They later see him being "rehabilitated". This whole thing was left out. And it was important because Meg had a speech at the end that talked about the difference between being the same and being equal that was very powerful. This was left out. Then the dad left which made him look like an ass, but that didn't happen in the book. Yes, it was Megs love that saved Charles Wallace, but how they got there was wrong. I was also disappointed that they left out the humor of the happy medium, who was really happy. All in all, I think they missed some of the key messages that then get built upon in later books.

7/2/18. A total disappointment. Two stars go for the special effects, which weren't too bad. While the story line was supposedly a children's classic, it just didn't transfer well from the printed page to the silver screen. Can be safely skipped without ruining your enjoyment of the other movies made by the stellar cast.

reviews.review_title: Meg and her friends journey to other realms to find her lost father
reviews.content: I had rather high expectations from the trailer but after watching it, I was wondering what just happened. The visuals were stunning though. Lush bright colors, and scenery. But the story, and tone is terrible executed. The transition from scene to scene is jarring, and the movie cannot really decide if this is supposed to focused on drama or inspiration. It attempts to be Life of Pi but lacks the depth and conflict. There is nothing at stake for the character, and the villain is not at all menacing. The supporting cast led by Oprah Winfrey was brilliant though. Oprah reminds us that she was once and still is a bona fide actor. But the scene stealer is Mindy Kaling as Mrs Who. She is radiant. Storm Reid as the Meg is too annoying in the beginning to be likable, but she does have talent. The other child stars are bland. In short, as a movie fan, I rarely find a movie boring, but this is one of those boring movies. It is full of spectacle but lacking so much of plot or depth and the graces of Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, Chris Pine, Michael Pena, Zach Galifianakilis cannot save this movie. In other words, this is a flop waiting to happen

reviews.review_title: An unfortunate mess of storytelling and uninvolving plotting
reviews.content: A Wrinkle In Time is a sci-fi fantasy film based on the novel of the same name by Madeleine L'Engle. Directed by Ava DuVernay (Selma), it is an unfortunate mess of storytelling and uninvolving plotting.Meg Murry (Storm Reid) is a young girl trying to fit in at school four years after the strange disappearance of her scientist father (Chris Pine). One day, three mysterious women, Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon), Mrs. Who (Mindy Kaling), and Mrs. Which (Oprah Winfrey) appear at Meg's house and offer to help find her missing father, who is believed to be somewhere on a faraway world.Having not read the novel from which it was based, I have no idea how accurately this film adaptation follows the original source material. However, with this in mind, the film seems to be a jumbled mess of overdone CGI, uninteresting action, and forced poignancy. The film's script feels all over the place and there are a number of plot holes which are never resolved and are brushed under the carpet for the sake of moving the film along and pad out its runtime. In addition to this, none of the characters were particularly interesting and the story was uninvolving and often boring. This is one of those films that you are highly likely to forget you have watched it in a matter of days.I rate it 3/10

reviews.review_title: 2 hours of my life I will never get back. Who do I sue?
reviews.content:
This flim made me angry. A childrens' movie making me angry? It is the laziest, most cliched, self-satisfied piece of nothing I have watched in years. I made the mistake of seeing the trailer on small screens, where the limitations of the visuals are not exposed. It was obvious that everyone was in front of a green screen. The design looked good, but served no purpose other than to say, "wow, isn't this cool!" It had no other purpose.It wanted to be quirky, tried so hard to be quirky. Wanted us to admire how quirky it was. Look guys, we're quirky!! And the message. That bloody message. I love life affirming movies. 
 I'm a sucker for feel good, touchy feely stuff that reminds me of how beautiful life can sometimes be. This felt like being force fed 5 tons of white chocolate and strawberry ice cream, washed down with 200 gallons of Southern Comfort. Pass me the sick bag please.This is the first movie I wanted to walk out of. Can you believe that? I sat through Highlander 2: The Quickening without leaving the theatre early. But this...this was excruciating. (I didn't leave cos I thought my wife was liking it. She hated it as much as I did).Nobody comes out of this with any glory. I need to drink some petrol to get the taste out of my mouth. What a wasted opportunity.

reviews.review_title: This should have never been released
reviews.content: I wish I could get my money back for this nightmare. There was no plot, no building up to any climax. This movie could have been done in 5 minutes without the extremely weird "fluff" in the movie. I looked at the time thinking maybe we were getting to the climax, that maybe there was an hour left of the movie only to realize that it was about 5 minutes from the end. I wasn't bored, I just felt like there was no story. My kids (a couple of 14 yr olds and 11yr old) hated it. Even they commented that there was no plot. It was the strangest and most ridiculous movie I've EVER seen.

The first act provided us with a very thin and clichéd background of the story and the characters, but the worst thing about the first act in general is that the directing and the camera work in it is so bad; weird camera angles, cranky camera movements. That's often noticed in scenes which feature conversations between characters. I felt if I was watching documentary or something, and that made me so confused and I really felt uneasy. There are tons of plot holes and unexplained things from the get-go to the end of the movie. But most of the nonsensical things happened to be related to the character of Charles Wallace. Charles Wallace is a very bizarre character. This character and everything related to it don't make any sense ,alas, Charles Wallace is really a big deal in the story and its messy plot. To add insult to injury, the child who played this character, Deric McCabe, is a very bad actor; for a big part of the movie he was trying to act like a cool sweet young kid, but he is not, then we see him overacting. I wonder if this character, Charles Wallace, is also poorly written in the novel? Mrs. Which, Whatsit, and Who characters have many cringe-worthy moments, and I blame no one but the director, Ava DuVernay, and maybe also Mindy Kaling (Mr. Who) who I should blame; what an annoying character and infuriating performance from Mindy Kaling!I don't have so much to say about Zach Galifianakis or Peña's performances, but I didn't neither like their characters.I think Storm Reid who played Meg, the protagonist, did a really god job. But the only performance that I can really praise is Chris Pine as Meg's father; he is great and due to his performance, the dramatic and the emotional value, which I didn't get, became slightly better. There are very few scenes where the CGI was okay, but, in general, it's weak and cartoonish, and that's due to the bad green screen that is glaringly obvious.I liked the comprehensive concept of the evil as an antagonist, but what we got from it in the third act was disgraceful! I really suffered while watching this act with all its dull and illogical twists.I'm very disappointed! I haven't watched many movies that have been released this year, but this is definitely one of the worst.From now on I'll call this movie A Wrinkle in Logic!(4/10)

reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle in Time: Aimed at a young audience, but not too young as there are some scary scenes.
reviews.content:
Children's fantasy adventure, adapted from a best-selling novel.About a young girl with a close relationship with her scientist father, she's on a journey to track him down after he's been experimenting with bending time and instant space travel, they call this 'Tessering' or some-such.
 
3 celestial beings help to find her father, they're called WHATSHERNAME, DOWECARE & WOTITS.There's some interesting 3d visuals, especially the flower scene but unfortunately the director fails to deliver a clear story, there's some engaging, emotional moments, but they are literally only moments. The complicated plot is hard to understand, especially towards the end. Parents (and some children) may need to prepare to be bored, especially towards the end.

reviews.review_title: When Bad Things Happen to Good People
reviews.content: GRADE: C- THIS FILM IS NOT RECOMMENDED.IN BRIEF: A sci-fi fantasy that is metaphysical mumbo-jumbo and one of the year's most disappointing movies.JIM'S REVIEW: As a goofy teenager, Madeleine L'Engle's A Wrinkle in Time was heady stuff back in the sixties, a book that I found difficult to understand, let alone, enjoy. It was all metaphysical mumbo-jumbo in those late turbulent 60's and Ava DuVernay's updated film adaptation can be described the same way today. It is a film of good intentions gone badly.The film is ill-conceived from the start. (How anyone looking at the kitschy design couldd not have seen the many missteps is beyond me and the universe!) Words fail to accurately explain the many flaws, but try I must. But first, a short plot summary for those not familiar with the novel: Meg Murry, her brother, Charles Wallace, and a friend meet some time traveling matrons named Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit, and Mrs. Who. (Who's on first?...I dunno!) They "tesser" to different worlds to find Meg's missing physicist father, who may have discovered the meaning of life, as they battle an evil force named The It (No, not that supernatural devious clown, although the circus of misfits has fully arrived).The director has diversity and woman's empowerment seemingly the major emphasis throughout this time-traveling saga, more blatantly on display than in most films. Score some points for that issue. But whereas, the recent Black Panther movie had the same idea and melded it successfully into its narrative, this heavy-handed version makes advancement for racial quotas in the most obvious of ways, primarily in its casting choices and stereotyping of some characters. Subtract points for the lack of logic and pure entertainment value. This film is a confusing dumbing-down of its source material.(In Ms. L'Engle's defense, many of her ideas of parallel dimensions, light vs. dark forces, black smoke monsters, and such were innovative and ground-breaking at the time, although now they are commonplace and contrived due to many later reincarnations from other sci-fi sources.) In fact, when the film stays earthbound, it oddly has more impact than its many treks to supernatural destinations.Storm Reid is our young heroine and the actress holds her own and creates a believable girl trying to cope with a new world order. Her casting is one of the few pleasures in this movie. Levi Miller has that teen idol look but is a bit bland as Meg's friend, Calvin, who seems to have a hair fetish through the movie. In smaller roles, Chris Pine and Gugu Mbatha-Raw register very well as the helpless and loving parents. Perhaps one of Ms. DuVernay's biggest hurdle was her miscasting of young Deric McCabe as Meg's gifted brother. He is just physically wrong for this role. As directed, the young actor overacts shamelessly and is annoyingly precocious. Mr. McCabe's resemblance to a small but mighty Hervé Villechaize does not help matters either. (No rescue here, the plane never arrives!) When called on to be a menacing force of nature, his size and high-pitched line delivery has the completely opposite reaction, more bratty hissy-fit than life-threatening peril. This child actor may have talent, but this role does not show off that potential at all.Yet some of the other adult performers are just surprisingly awful, especially the three fairy godmother types played by Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling, and the omnipotent Oprah "You get a car" Winfrey. It's hard to determine just who, whatsit, or especially "why" these actresses interpret their roles with a fuzzy cartoonish smugness and total lack of gravitas. They never create an iota of a believable character or transcend their real life personas. It's just dress-up time. Other unusual suspects are: Zach Galifianakis, once again hamming it up to excess as a yoga guru called The Happy Medium and Michael Pena plays Red briefly, a wise exit. Ms. DuVernay's vision becomes strained in this re-imagining and the technical CGI have a general artificial quality which subverts the story. It is a rarity in today's filmmaking that such a big budgeted blockbuster from the Disney Studio looks so cheap and be so bereft of imagination and visual style. Blame the artisans involved, the worst offender being costume designer Paco Delgado's outrageous drag queen outfits, the bejeweled make-up, and Disney's fairy-tale over-the-top hair design. (Perhaps this look would have worked as a more theatrical musical, A Wizard of Oz updated tale. As it stands, it just looks foolish and laughable.) In fact, evolving hair styles seems to be the deciding factor for character development, since it surely isn't the muddled screenplay by Jennifer Lee and Jeff Stockwell. It's more like a skeletal outline of a series of kiddie adventures as the characters space hop to different planets and different obstacles than a complex story of universal adult themes. The dialogue is just a series of positive pep talks and self-help platitudes that grow tiresome very fast ("Be a warrior!"...Celebrate your flaws!"..." Don't give up hope!"..."You know, you have great hair!").A bombastic music score by Ramin Djawadi telegraphs the emotion one is suppose to feel but doesn't. Most of Naomi Sholan's production design and especially Elizabeth Keenan's unimaginative set decoration looks like a college art design project using painted styrofoam as its main element, with the prize going to best float. Only Tobias Schliesser's photography has some merit.Yes, there are a few effective scenes that are completely satisfying. After all, the director is a powerful force. Just see her previous two films, the superb Selma and the important documentary, 13, and it is proof of her talents. However, in this film, she loses control of her story with trite images (Orion's gaudy cavern, a bedazzled bigger-than-life Oprah, and those ugly costumes with added colored lip gloss, a dated 50's beach scene that seems out of place with all the other contemporary touches) mixed with strong ones (the ripple effect prior to transporting, an eerie beige Stepford suburbia, a dangerous race in a dark forest).This modern reboot of A Wrinkle in Time has many kinks to iron out. Sadly, it is a major disappointment. Hopefully, Ms. DuVerney and crew will learn from their failures and "tesser" onto other more worthwhile projects. This one deserves to be lost in its own parallel universe.

reviews.review_title: Listen to the masses on this one!
reviews.content: My first review of a movie... ever!! Let's get this out of the way, I love terrible movies. I watch b movies for fun and this one made me almost go insane the entire time. I went with my wife and daughter and knew absolutely nothing about it. Wife said time travel and Cap Kirk so I said sure. I about lost it when I saw giant Orpa. This movie made me feel like I was wandering in the dark... absolutely no direction. Where was I being taken? I still don't know what the heck just happened. Best thing I got out of this was when I perused eBay during the movie for a hat I saw in the beach scene (don't worry, these were booth type seats that wouldn't let the dimmed light escape- I'm not that kind of movie goer ).
Just awful.If I could have given it zero I would have. Insipid characters, a soundtrack that was dire and clearly a director who was out of one's depth.

reviews.review_title: The worst children's book to film adaptation in cinematic history
reviews.content: My headline for this review might seem like an exaggeration, but it's really not.Such a joyless, bland adaptation of one of the greatest literary works in history. The lead child was horribly miscast, she simply cannot act. You cannot convince me she was the best choice for the role, she was chosen for "reasons".Oprah is a fine human being, but her giant self 5 minutes into the film just looked dumb. That's the thing about this, everything about this film just rings as unnecessary and dumb.Zach G. Shows up for 2 minutes to collect a paycheck and have his name in the credits, along with 5-6 other actors who probably didn't read the whole script before agreeing to be in it.A total waste, do not bother with this. Read the book!

reviews.review_title: I wanted to like it, I fell asleep instead
reviews.content: I love sci-fi. I'm not sure what this, but it wasn't good. Too pretentious. To self important. Too inexplicable.

Anything Oprah does is usually amazing. I'm sure there is the secondary meanings and messages to this movie. Perhaps it's, "thoughts are things." Perhaps it's "positive can outshine any darkness." The problem I had with this production was......if I heard the word "universe" one more time, and the layered depth this movie was trying to create with this word..... 
I just didn't want to disrespect Oprah. I love her so much. Definitely bring the kids but absolutely eat 3 quaaludes. That will help you get through this movie that definitely needed an editor.

Not worth seeing! I had high hopes for this move, but "A Wrinkle in Time" was a big let down. The movie was confusing, disjointed, and filled with outlandish scenes that did not mesh well. My 15-year-old daughter had read the book and was excited to see this movie, but was unfortunately utterly disappointed with the adaptation to the big screen. The cinematography and soundtrack were great; not much else was. I would give this movie 3 out of 10.

I really wanted to like A Wrinkle in Time, but they made it so difficult. This movie had a message of some sort, awkwardly forced into every scene. Every payoff seemed unearned, every line of dialogue felt flat instead of inspiring or thought-provoking or whatever emotion they were trying to make me feel.As an example, Calvin at one point says to Meg something like "you don't know how incredible you are, do you?" Yet, there is no context for why he know this or feels this way. To this point, Meg hasn't really shown anything incredible and there is no back story for these two except that they barely know each other. This is the kind of disconnected dialogue you can expect from the entire movie. Monologues and speeches that are suppose to have gravity and inspire but feel out of place. Where did it all go wrong? Is this a poor script, poor editing, or poor directing?The only character I really enjoyed was Charles Wallace, a name you get to know quite well because they say his name about 500 times. He (Deric McCabe) really made the best of the dialogue he was given.This movie is harmless, but ultimately not satisfying.

'A Wrinkle In Time' is the worst film of this year thus far, due to it's poorly written screenplay, terribly written screenplay and underwhelming acting. On paper, this film has a lot going for it. It has a good selection of talented cast members, it's a Disney film and it's (supposedly) a wonderful, adventurous tale. So it is a wonder to me that all of these things could have gone wrong. From the very beginning, the weak screenplay is evident and consequently undermines the actors. It's very difficult to have great acting when the screenplay in which they act off is terrible. Unfortunately this resulted in talented actors such as Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling, Oprah Winfrey and Chris Pine being undermined. It also did not help the characters were underdeveloped and simply not interesting. The female trio (Witherspoon, Kaling and Winfrey) were quite quirky and interesting at points, but still remained to be underdeveloped. The leading child cast protagonists were not very exciting, however I can't be too harsh on the young ones. They'll learn one day to be more selective with their film choices. However, Levi Miller shined in this film and was a clear stand-out for me. For a film directed at a younger audience, the plot is extremely bewildering and far too complex. I'm not sure whether this is just a poor adaptation of a great book, or the source material is not that great either. The story comes across as uninteresting, predictable and clichéd. There may have been a few somewhat-intriguing scenes, but they were ultimately lost amongst the rest of the film. The only thing this film truly succeeded in was a colourful costume and makeup design that was visually stunning. The female trio (Witherspoon, Kaling and Winfrey) looked vibrant and beautiful, with imaginative costumes and striking makeup. At least the film was nice to look at. Overall, this wasted-potential of a film can easily go missed as it is poorly written and uninteresting, and was not saved by it's few interesting aspects.
Good fantastic CGI , but the story is terrible with a plot only a 2 year old would appreciate. Needs a do over.

It was like watching a stranger who flayed my friend and wore her flesh like a coat to induce terror. Worst movie of 2018 so far. That said, with the exception of a couple choices, the casting was great and was the sole redeeming quality.

It seems like I will be the first one to give this a good review! Me and my 10 year old daughter watched this with totally open minds. In the beginning it was like being attacked by rainbows and we decided to just laugh and enjoy the ride. But it also has it's share of thrills and plot twists and I really don't understand why people regret seeing this. For a nice evening with your kids (it's rated 7 years but I believe a 7 year old is way too young for this movie) this is perfect. I rate it a 7 for a family movie, my daughter rates it 8.5.

I had been looking forward to this movie not only because the trailers made it look like it had potential, but I have also read the entire book series. Fortunately, it lives up to it's potential. Amazing acting, incredible special effects, and a screenplay and directing that doesn't leave you guessing what the plot is. There are many scenes in the movie that are just plain creepy so keep that in mind. The only reason I did not give this a 10/10 is because I had a few issues with how the father was portrayed at the end.Make sure you know what you are getting into if you watch this. It's not for people looking for brain-dead plots. You need to have intelligence to enjoy it, and movies like this are incredibly rare to come by nowadays.

reviews.review_title: I Do Not Get The Low Scores
reviews.content: It is a kid flick and it is fantasy. My kids sat still, got scared and then were happy (about the happy ending). Additionally, my wife and I were able to sit through without resorting to speaking to each other, out of ennui. Overall, these are the qualities of a good kid's movie, perhaps as it is viewed through mature eyes. No need to troll. It is simply another opinion. Hopefully, no heads exploded for it.

reviews.review_title: Second worst movie based on a children's book
reviews.content: This is the second-worst movie based on a children's book I have ever seen. (The absolute worst was Five Children and It (2004).)

Let's cast Oprah Winfrey and a big diverse collection of nobodies that are all the colors of the rainbow.
It doesn't matter about making a good movie now because we were inclusive 'n stuff.
Nauseating story line made this virtually unwatchable. Oprah needs to stick to daytime television. She was laughable in this. I flipped the dial after twenty minutes. Argh.

reviews.review_title: I love the books, this movie is an absolute disgrace
reviews.content: I don't read much, if ever. I have probably only read 20 books in the last 10 years. I mainly watch movies and tv shows. However the Wrinkle in Time series has been one of the rare few books I not only read, but I read often. Along with Lord of the Rings... Which should tell you on what level I put Madeleine L'Engle books on, so when I heard this movie was going to star Oprah Winfrey, I was extremely skeptical but withheld some small glimmer of hope. Now that I have seen the movie, Nope. Nope. Nope. The ruined ever facets of the book. I might of blamed the failures on staring children, but the Narnia series also stars children and does a great job, not perfect but good enough. This movie was awful, I barely managed to finish it, I ended up doing finances to keep myself awake enough to finish it... It was that bad. Pathetic movie. Please don't watch!
Drop the word "Wrinkle", and replace it with "Waste"!! Also replace word "in" with "of"!! A WASTE OF TIME!!!

reviews.review_title: Did you watch the same movie as me?
reviews.content: Fine, it's lackluster and the momentum was interily ruined by bad writing. But there is no need for 1, 2 or 3 star rating on this movie!Storm and Deric are marvelous actors in this movie, I felt everything they brought into this. And the cinematic experience is breathtaking! Oprah as a Goddess? Reese turning into a beautiful flying leaf Queen? Tulips talking IN COLOR LANGUAGE?I honestly think some of you lack the imagination for this movie. And I do understand the disappointment from those who've read the book, but it's still breathtakingly made.

I noticed recently that when Amazon reviewers have an overwhelming negative toward a movie that Amazon no longer accepts reviews. 
Anyway, 
1. Cheap overused subplot of teen bullying as our setup. 
2. Lack of understanding of teaching by writers as they show teachers & administrators as incompetent, unintelligent poor communicators w/students.
3. An overused sci-fi hook of cheap sciency looking tech equip. to indicate a lab that is about to lose it's science father to some other place. A not creative ripoff and technically poorly presented. A single small chalk blackboard contains the greatest equation since anything Einstein? 
4. Lots of mishmash pop science that would embarrass any half way nerdy middle school science student. 
5. For props we have lots of weird lipstick, sequins and Hollywood prop dept. made up costumes. That was it for special effects other than the time worn vanishings and floating rocks. Even the talking (sort of) plants has been done before.
6. Creativity - non-existent. Acting - weak, rescued by usual cute boy/cute girl hooks. Ending - feel good predictable.

My family and I love Disney movies. This one was so hard to watch because the plot just jumped from place to place. Wether it was the writing or the directing or probably both, it was bad. Hard to watch characters that were developed poorly make decisions for no apparent reason. Not good. I will watch for this director in the future and avoid her work.
This movie is abysmal and laughable. the only reason i didn't give it a half star is because of some stunningly beautiful visuals, especially in 4k HDR (1 viewing)

reviews.review_title: Total garbage! Waste of money and time
reviews.content: This is in my opinion one of the most boring movies that I have watched. What a way to waste the viewer's time and money. Terrible plot. Absurd dialogues. The worst performance by a bunch of wanna be's

I had been looking forward to this movie because the trailers made it look like it had potential to be a lot of fun. Unfortunately it lived up to none of that potential. Horrendous acting, insultingly cheesy special effects, confusing directing, and a clumsily written screenplay made for a punitive movie-going experience. My nephew was bored five minutes in, and I was cringing. I am shocked that Disney released this in theaters. They usually have more respect for their customers.

reviews.review_title: Critics couldn't be more wrong, this is A Beautiful Picture!
reviews.content: This generation of children now have their Neverending Story, and Adults have a means to remember how beautiful a child's imagaination can be. A Wrinkle in Time is absolutely magical. The Star studded cast of Resse Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling, Chris Pine , and the endlessly beautiful Oprah Winfrey are wonderful, as expected, but the surprises of the film come with the absolutely phenomenal performances of the child actors.I'd only been priorly familiar with Levi Miller from, "Better Watch Out". He, Storm Reid, and Deric McCabe all have a HUGE future ahead of them in acting. They were all captivating and believable in their performances, and that added to the power of the film.I left feeling like I'd just been through something magical, beautiful, and important (Especially this day and age). How critics could be so negative towards this film is beyond me. It's as visually stunning as it is mentally. I believe this is an out of the park Home Run for Disney, and will gain its deserved appreciation as it ages.I Highly Reccomend it!Thanks for the Magic, House of Mouse. You never let me down <3
The worst Disney movie so far. The actores are bad, the plot its not enough .

Please see this movie and judge for yourself. My 22 year old daughter and I loved this movie. Neither of us have read the book so we are judging it solely on its own. First of all, it is a PG rated Disney movie. The scenery in the movie is beautiful. I did not think it was boring at all. It may not live up to all the hype but it was still a good movie that was enjoyable to watch!

So glad we went on a $5 movie day. Both my kids and I thought it was terrible. My wife was the only one who liked it. This was a made for TV movie that somehow made it to the theaters. This movie starts off slow. The acting is mediocre. I literally fell asleep got up to go get a beer. Stood up to leave before the credits made it on screen. If you want to watch this movie. Wait till it comes out on Red Box, it will probably be there next month because this movie won't be in theaters for more then 2 weeks.

reviews.review_title: Real story us missing in time.
reviews.content: A whole class of fith graders join, and not one of them liked the movie. They had just finished the book and were very excited to see it. and the disappointment was very apparent by their comments after the movie. Make a moive from a book stay true to the material.

reviews.review_title: The movie could done much better !!
reviews.content: Never read the book, but what I just saw was confusing, poor acting, boring and not imaginative. Over done in the CG department but main plot is just boring :(

I never read Madeleine L'Engle's A Wrinkle in Time, nor any of its four sequels. By the time it was published, my interest in science fiction had been established by Mr. Bass of the Mushroom Planet, Heinlein's juveniles and the Holt Rinehart series with the great Alex Schomburg endpapers. When people spoke of the book, it was in terms that did not fire my imagination. It seemed it was of the wish-fulfillment adventure fantasy that Andre Norton worked in, and I did not care for Norton's work.So when my cousin and I went to see this movie this morning, I could approach it without any preconceptions. No outrage that Michael Keaton has been cast as a Batman with chubby cheeks, no contempt for anyone who thinks elves' ears are that pointy, none of the million and one indignities we are subject to because our slightest whims are unheeded without the bother of our having to even think of them! They could change the story around entirely, and I wouldn't have the least idea. I would judge the movie on its own merits.I was mildly bored throughout by a universe in which the love of tween girls is the most powerful force in the universe; a universe where girls love their younger brothers who are smarter than they. I've been a smart younger brother. I can assure you, it is not an endearing quality.It was clear to me that this movie was made to cater to young girls, probably those who loved the books. Since I wasn't a young girl, never had been one, and probably never will be one, it wasn't intended for me. On the way out, I saw a young girl and an adult woman leaving and consulted with them. The younger thought it was good. The elder agreed with me when I used the word "gooey".

reviews.review_title: L'engle is rolling in her grave
reviews.content: Did the screen writers ever actually read the book? And what about the make-up staff...were they all taking hallucinogens or just most of them. An absolutely awful portrayal of perhaps the greatest children's book of the 20th century.

This movie really isn't child friendly. The dragging of children down a dark hall is a scary image for children. Having something called the "IT" is too much like Stephen King's book and movie. A wrinkle in time should have found a different name. I took a child in grade school to this movie and saw children leaving the theater in tears during the scary part.

Loved the book growing up and was extremely excited to see this in IMAX. DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY!!! Cinematography and story were really good but writing and acting were horrible. Someone is probably going to lose their job at Disney.

We really enjoyed watching this movie! Following Meg on her adventure through the universe to find her father and discover the power within herself was a wonderful adventure. It was also a great reminder that we are worthy just the way we are. This is a great movie to go see with your pre-teens and teens! If you want a discussion guide to use afterwards we have one up on our blog now. 
Yes, there were differences from the book. But I was not expecting it to be exactly like the book and I was not disappointed. Yes, there were some Christian pieces of the book watered down- but I still saw God in so many places in the movie! The themes of light and love shone through. 
It was wonderfully acted and the imagery was beautiful! 
We highly recommend this movie!
The fact that there were a total of 7 people including my granddaughter and myself in the theater tonight to see this movie on opening night speaks volumes.

reviews.review_title: The safest place in the universe
reviews.content: NASA scientist Dr. Murray (Chris Pine) manages to transport himself through space by using his mind and certain frequencies. He always manages to land on a planet that has oxygen. After being missing for four years we get to know his daughter Meg (Storm Reid) and number one adopted son Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe). Charles manages to make contact with what look like three cosmic faeries that can transport our two kids and a neighbor boy to help find their father. Storm Reid was adorable as a bullied kid, but not so much in the second half. Likewise Deric McCabe was okay as a kid, but not convincing as mini Vader. I think the plot may be too advance for smaller kids to grab and the film was a little too Nickelodeon for adults. Reese Witherspoon was a joy.

reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle in Time barely follows the book, makes changes that make little sense, and feels too safe for a cosmic journey
reviews.content: A Wrinkle in Time is one of those books that a lot of kids are aware of. I myself have heard about the book since the sixth grade, and from I understand, is a very popular read for a lot of girls. Before the new movie adaptation came out, I took the liberty of listening to an audiobook version. I can understand why as it focuses on a social outcast who gains a great deal of confidence through her journey within the universe. While I can't say that it's the masterpiece that a lot of people have said it is, it's still a good read for children and would even hope that classrooms use this a part of the English curriculum. I think what kids liked about the book was its use of science and mathematics in conjunction with the more fantasy elements of it. It plays out a bit like a smarter Disney story. It seems fitting that Disney would acquire the rights to make a film version of the story. While it has a lot of cerebral moments, I could see this in the vein of Dark Crystal or Labyrinth; one of those edgier family films from the 1980s. Lets see how this new A Wrinkle in Time does.Young Meg Murry (played by Storm Reid) is a brilliant, but depressed and aggressive middle schooler who is still trying to deal with that her father NASA scientist Dr. Alex Murry (played by Chris Pine) had gone missing four years earlier. She has only her younger brother and prodigy Charles Wallace (played by Deric McCabe) and mother Dr. Kate Murry (played by Gugu Mbatha-Raw). During an evening at home, their visited by the eccentric Mrs. Whatsit (played by Reese Witherspoon) who tells them that "tesseracting" is possible. This puts the family into a shock, but seem to leave it alone as a strange visit.The next day, Meg, Charles-Wallace, and fellow friend Calvin (played by Levi Miller) once again encounter Mrs. Whatsit, this time along with the quoting Mrs. Who (played by Mindy Kaling) and godlike Mrs. Which (played by Oprah Winfrey). The three women reveal that their father is on a distant planet somewhere in the universe and is up to these three kids to "tesseract" with them to find them. They end up visiting several worlds and strange people including the Happy Medium (played by Zach Galifinakis) and the evil Red (played by Michael Peña).This new version of A Wrinkle in Time tries to do a lot with it's short running time, but unfortunately makes me debate whether the book was that good to begin with. To begin with, this only follows the book loosely. It's the same plot of finding our character's father, but the encounters are different. That wouldn't matter if it helped the story, but many of the changes neither make sense or devalue what the book was better at. To be fair, A Wrinkle in Time could have not been easy to adapt. It's clear that director Ava DuVernay (Selma) wants to transport her audience to new worlds. And to be honest, the visuals and art direction look stunning. In fact, I might have liked this movie more if it would have taken it's time to show us these worlds, and let the atmosphere tell the story. She's trying to do this, but each scene seems to flow at a quick pace, almost like their fast-forwarding to the next sequence. They'll show Meg getting in trouble...next. The kids go to a colorful world...next. Kids go to the evil world...next. Having a lack of focus might have benefited A Wrinkle in Time. The story itself, aside from having major pacing issues, has such a convoluted execution, that it still feels dated. Without giving anything away, this is another movie where "love" is the answer. Think of it as a kid friendly version of Inception. While it's not that their trying to make it work, but perhaps this is something was simply better on paper. The acting even suffers. Oprah is playing herself, Reese Witherspoon is in need of direction, and the boy who plays Charles Wallace is really bad. I'm not sure if it's the writing or the actor, but this kid only seems to be emulating a smart alec rather then a true prodigy. The only ones who does exceptional work is Storm Reid as Meg and Chris Pine.I'll give this four copies of A Wrinkle in Time novels out of ten. Sad to say that despite having a Disney-like story, this has no idea what it wants to be. It gets a lot of points for some neat visuals and style, but the story, the most essential thing to a movie, has the distinction of feeling pandering and confused. Perhaps children will see something else, but this is one book I'm keeping closed.

There's no denying the importance that this movie may have for some audiences. The mere fact that this past weekend saw the first time 2 movies with 2 directors of color top the box office is astonishing and inspiring. It's long overdue, and should be lauded. On that note, A Wrinkle in Time is a film that ends up being of far more importance than it does a film that will please most. To say the least, it's a mess.I walked out of the theater trying to quantify what this film felt like, and I think to me, it's a Disney Channel Original Movie with the budget of your typical summer blockbuster. The budget of a little over 100 million is actually historic, for giving the first black woman a budget that high to direct a film. But that's not even necessarily the problem with the film. The problem lies with the screenplay and perhaps partially DuVernay's direction.I've never read the book, nor had the interest to, but I have to imagine there was an easier way to adapt this book than the result we got. The story revolves around Meg, who's father has gone missing for years, as she tries to travel through time and space with a few strange beings, her brother, and a new friend from school. Perhaps some audiences, mostly on the younger side, will connect to the story of reconnection and family, but the execution is mind-bogglingly silly.There are particular story choices in the 3rd act that are laughably out of place, and even a few blatant mistakes in directing that I never truly could grasp how they got past the editing room. If this were to have come out when I was younger, perhaps it's something I could connect with. But a well-performed and semi-visually impressive film isn't enough to surpass all of the frustrating mistakes in the script and direction.4.0/10

reviews.review_title: My favorite book makes a terrible movie.
reviews.content:
I read this book as a 12 year old, and I read so quickly that it seemed like I was watching a movie more than being totally engrossed in this book. Now I'm 65 and I still have the paperback in my library. I recommend it to every child that has the gift to read and understand it. I found NO religious undertones, only a message that you should be the best YOU that you can. With enough Love and Understanding of others is the message.
I was disappointed in the TV movie made years ago, and unfortunately was very sad in the Disney version with all the money Disney makes, they could have made this movie "Word for Word" straight from he book and it would have been a huge success.
To the people who never read "A Wrinkle in Time" series, don't let this movie deter you from reading it the way the author intended it. Poor Chris Pine, he went from Captain Kirk in the Star Trek reboot, to Steve Trevor in Wonder Woman to this. Let's hope he returns to the Enterprise where he belongs.
I found "A Wrinkle in Time" to be a beautiful-looking, serious, sweet, and entertaining movie for teens, young adults, and older folk-- praise to Ava DuVernay for her wonderful directing!

reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle In Story Telling, But A Warrior In Visuals
reviews.content:
Another weekend, another literary classic to be remade by the lovely folks in La La Land. The movie world continues to scrape deep for the next big fad, Disney brings A Wrinkle in Time to life, ready to unleash magic into the world. With super star Oprah Winfrey backing the project and a number of stars to further support the film, and potentially bring in the big bucks. Does it succeed, or should you just read the book? Robbie K here to provide some insight into the movies ad guide your experience. Let's get started!LIKES:The Acting: With a star-studded cast, one hopes for brilliant performances and Wrinkle in Time has some impressive displays of the theater arts. Storm Reid's career has started off well in this movie, a nice blend of passion fighting pessimism in a manner that feels very much like the whiney preteen age. Her fellow child actors are impressive, but the adult casts' experience manages to shine forth. Oprah's words re limited, but her regality comes across well in her performance. Mindy Kaling's lines are a little more dynamic, again executed to be entertaining, and while wise, not the most engaging of characters. It's actually Reese Witherspoon who was my favorite, bringing the most spunk, comedy, and character to the movie. Her chemistry with the cast was fantastic and her abilities certainly charmed much of the movie. The Morals: Like the book, the movie has a fantastic repertoire of lessons to teach the young audience members targeted by the film. A Wrinkle in Time greatly praises the concept of hope, imbedding the driving, divine light of inspiring others to better themselves and motivate them to fight. It's focus on utilizing the positive to combat the negative emotions is something this world could easily learn from, and even more so in the ability to accept one's faults and praise one's strengths. While a bit preachy in the dialog, the movie has those emotional moments to absolutely sell those life lessons and perhaps promote the next great person for them to endorse. Still, use this movie as a means to educate those in the way of values of self-worth. The Visuals: What can I say, the best part of this movie is the fantastic world building is the world building this movie brought to the silver screen. A Wrinkle in Time's selling point is how beautiful the art department made all their characters and settings. While the realistic Earth scenes are a cavalcade of traditional settings, the real majesty comes when our heroes begin to bend reality. First the costumes of the misses are incredible, as their personalities erupt to life on each planet they visit. Makeup and costume blend together perfectly, truly bringing out the beauty of each entity and reflecting their personal view of each world. And once the costumes are recognized, the creation of the dimensional galaxy gets even better. My favorite planet is the Flower planet (as advertised on the trailers) as it blended all the color and visual stunning goodness into one area. However, there are plenty of other things hidden in behind the trailers to be impressed with. 
DISLIKES:The Story: It starts off so strong, but soon the plot takes a major hit in quality because of how rushed it feels. Once the traveling begins, the movie's plot hits a major break and takes a mighty plunged into rushed territory. Character development, major plot hits, even the mighty antagonist were all kind of bland in this movie, never reaching the full steam past girl power junction. Why such a literature classic could not build up steam I don't know, but sadly this movie didn't quite have all it took to be exciting. A bit annoying: The movie has plenty of cute, kid friendly gimmicks, but my word does it crush over into some rather annoying things. The most annoying for me was how often they repeat the name Charles Wallace, a not only obnoxious name, but an obnoxious calling that was used every five seconds. As picky as this sounds, I quickly got annoyed at how lackluster the name was and how it was used unnecessarily in every context. Better luck next time in dialog adaptation guys, perhaps next time you'll learn how to substitute a name with better descriptions. The Simplistic Journey: You might be thinking Disney would pour their hearts into making an interdimensional journey with some style, class and flare their studios can brings. Sadly, the movie itself still seems to fail in this department for me. Three worlds make up the entire leg of the journey and while they each have some magic of their own it didn't feel like quite a detective journey. So many worlds were reduced to a blurry montage that lasted less than a minute depriving me of a scavenger hunt in order to fit into the two-hour runtime package. With their studio they could have much better on this aspect to extend the mystery, perhaps adding their own leeway and integration of cosmic powers to uncover the clues to finding dear old dad. Nope, again the movie is just a sad, sad display of tempting visuals and rushed plot. The Anticlimactic End: Again, there is buildup up to how deadly the darkness is and how it will be hunting for our heroes at every turn. So maybe you might hope that the big, bad, black void had some actual tricks up its sleeve to hinder the young warriors' journey. Again, the movie has little exciting climax to act as an impasse, a few emotional shadows and musical sores to try to illicit a response. However, there is little threat behind the darkness void, which symbolic as it can be is a boring end to what was supposed to be a crossing of the universe. Sorry, but I expect my shadows to have a little more bite and might when they threaten to plague the universe. The result is a cute, but rather dull finale to one of the most epic tales of the literature adapted world. The VERDICT: Wrinkle in Time feels like a child's version of Annihilation, but without the unique and twists the genre could really have used. It certainly isn't awful as some may say, with good acting and world building to bring forth an emotional telling of valuable ethics and morals. Yet, the movie does not meet the expectations placed by the book, for the story has been watered down into a hokey, gimmick filled manhunt that failed to reach its full potential. Perhaps the director's cut will go into more details with the abandoned worlds, but I doubt extra time will be able to bring the full might this movie needed to match the literary work. Not the worst movie to grace the theater, but outside of visuals and some acting, I think this one can be held until home viewing. My scores are: Adventure/Family/Fantasy: 7.0
Movie Overall: 5.5

reviews.review_title: I guess they spent all the money on the cast
reviews.content: This film tells the story of three children who travel in time and space with the help of three fairies.With such a stellar cast, I expected the film to be a blockbuster children's films. Though the ever changing hairstyles of the fairies are quite spectacular, that itself is not enough to hold the film together. The story is not very interesting, even for a children's film. The visuals are really poor and very horribly fake, which is very unfortunate. It looks like as if they spend all the money on the cast, and hence run out of budget for the visual effects.

It is strange to see a huge budget family movie like this fail to achieve any of its own goals on such an epic scale. Saying that A Wrinkle in Time lacks compelling interest would be an understatement. It is a cosmically underwhelming film peppered with expensive yet empty visuals. In fact, it is often straight up boring as it moves through several scenes of superfluous waxing philosophic about the nature of time, love, and good vs evil. These little narrations use up movie time and replace any real development of story and character. Ultimately it makes for a rather tedious film to sit through.
Actors... hmm. The big surprise for me was that Oprah struck me as the weakest in this department. It didn't help that her boring delivery and rather emotionless expressions are contrasted by these stagey costumes, hair, and makeup that would be well suited for a 1970s disco star. But this brings up a problem with all the witches: they don't look like witches, they look like actors in absurd costumes. If I lived next door to these people and they showed up at my house, I wouldn't be concerned in the least, because it would be so overtly obvious that my supposedly "strange" neighbors were really just theater people who pretend their real lives are their stage characters. Too fake. As for everyone else, they were relatively ok I guess, when considering what they had to work with.
Aside from needing a totally different script, I think the core problem here is that the film never felt mysterious or surprising. The visuals never felt like anything beyond generically "creative." Nothing was convincingly weird as it traverses between these supposedly cosmic characters and other dimensions, which ultimately made it exactly the opposite of what a story like this should be, and so it ends up as a predictable film on all fronts.

Grade: C+
In a Nutshell: Despite its best intentions, A Wrinkle in Time is disappointing as a film, although kids will probably still like it.
Based on the very popular book A Wrinkle in Time (Time Quintet) by Madeleine L'Engle , it doesn't quite deliver the magic I hoped for, especially since screenwriter Jennifer Lee had done such great work with Disney's Frozen , Zootopia (DVD) Wreck-It Ralph and even Frozen Fever. 
Tips for Parents:LOTS of moral lessons kids and parents can feel good about.
Kids in peril
Mrs. Whatsit uses the word "prodigious." In case your kids ask you what it means, you can tell them "remarkably or impressively great in extent, size, or degree." Your kids will be so impressed that you know. 
Bullying
No profanity. Thank you!
Multi-racial familyUplifting theme: The only way to defeat the darkness is to become the light.
Love rescues
"Be a warrior." - Mrs. Which (Oprah)
Center yourself. Become one with the universe and yourself.
"The wound is the place where the light enters you." - Mrs. WhoThings I liked:Chris Pine! I love him in anything.
Storm Reid is adorable and did a pretty good job, although a bit straight-faced during most of the movie. Her best scene, by far, was with Chris Pine towards the end.
It's a colorful ride. The gossiping flower scene was the best part of the film.
Fun hairstyles on the Mrs.'s.
Zach Galifinakus was pretty funny and did a lot with the very small role he was given.
I think frequencies and energy are so interesting. If you're fascinated by science, check out A Wrinkle in Time Book of Fun, Facts, and Science Energy is everything.
Some of the scenes were shot in gorgeous New Zealand.
Things I didn't like:While director DuVernay was very enthusiastic and creative, her vision was probably overly ambitious, resulting in a choppy mess.
A lot of the green screens look fake with some special effects that don't really work. 
Some weird moments with missing details. Sometimes I really wish directors would let me see their movies before they released them so that I could point out some of the mistakes that could be quickly fixed.
Deric McCabe as Charles Wallace is super cute, but sometimes it was hard to understand what he was saying.
I couldn't understand a word Storm Reid was saying during the tornado scene in the woods.
Cliched scene where someone says, "Do you trust me?"
Mindy Kaling looked so awkward trying to run in her ridiculous dress. What was her character's purpose? She didn't actually do anything to help. 
Over-the-top make-up. The costumes were creative, but they looked like costumes.The "Mrs's" looked more fake than magical. 
You don't need to pay extra money to see this in IMAX. It's fine on the regular screen. Better yet, watch it when it comes out on Netflix.
The dialogue may sound good in the book, but it's awkward in the movie.
Lots of close-ups that don't really work.
A scene in the second trailer was completely cut out of the movie.
I actually looked at the clock on my cell phone. That's never a good sign.
There's no real villain. There's only a wispy, menacing "it." 
Kids who haven't read the book might think that Oprah's character's name is Mrs. Witch. While Oprah really is bigger than life (I laughed when Mrs. Which was gigantic), her acting is not good. I heard her speak to a room full of 10,000 a number of years ago at the California Governor's Conference for Women and she was mesmerizing.
Surprisingly, some of the acting was not good by quite a few of the other actors too. It felt forced and contrived.
Interesting lines:"You can do this. You're choosing not to." - Happy Medium (Zach Galifianakis)
"It's ok to fear the answers, Meg, but you have to face them." - Happy Medium
"What if we are not just in the universe, but the universe is in us?" - Mr. Murry (Chris Pine)
"You just have to find the right frequency and have faith in who you are." - Mrs. Which (Oprah)
"We can't take credit for our talents. It's how we use them that counts." - Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon)
"Your house is so warm. You've done a good job keeping the darkness out." - Mrs. Whatsit
"Love is always there, even if you don't feel it. It's always there for you." - Mr. Murry
"Don't give up hope." - Mrs. Murry (Gugu Mbatha-Raw)  @trinaboice

I went into this with excitement as I saw the trailer, it looked amazing but........and it's a BIG but........
This movie was very confusing!
The kids dad goes missing and Reese Witherspoon turns up to help them find him. Along with herself and a couple of enchanting friends they set out on a mission to find him.
Okay, so the trio sent to help the kids don't really know how to help them. They take them through some kind of wall into another dimension which is actually another planet (stay with me) where Reese turns into a big green thing that they ride on the back on into the sky to look for the father but there's a big black smoke thing in the sky called the IT. Boy falls off back or Reese monster, lands in a bunch of flowers they move into another dimension to meet some bloke who's going to train the young girl to be a warrior by believing in herself while balancing on some wood thing.
