On top of that, you got a great cast featuring Reese Witherspoon, Chris Pine and even Michael Pena but just the same they weren't enough to save the movie from "tessering" to disaster territory.First the positives: Chris Pine was able to give great acting even though he was given barely anything to work with. I once outrightly dismissed him after seeing him in 'Just My Luck', back in 2006 when Lindsay Lohan was still a thing. He's steadily improved since, between 'This Means War', 'Wonder Woman' and now this. Also worth mentioning is 8yr old Fil-American Deric McCabe who played Charles Wallace. Yes there were some annoying moments (such as the confrontation in the white room) but he showed acting potential and we should see more of him in the future.Now the negatives: The story had so many loopholes and you would know this because you'd wonder about something and even though the cast is just standing there talking no one is explaining it to you. Editing was poorly done and if I had to take a guess I would surmise it's because there weren't a lot of good takes to work with. Even the soundtrack didn't work. I mean I love Sade but the song they chose did not give the feels for the scene they used it for.Lastly the so-sos: Oprah was Oprah, Reese was also Reese and I'm kinda mixed about her performance, like I'm seeing a preview of what to expect in Legally Blonde 4. Mindy, again was the token diversity actress, but that's a progress, from African-Americans we're moving to Asians. In addition, the family in the book was changed from Caucasian to Multiracial in the movie, and I also read somewhere that the book's Christian undertones were heavily edited and they used neutral terms such as light and darkness. While being inclusive opens up more opportunities for everyone, it feels like they spent too much time focusing on that instead of the story therefore it felt forced rather than letting it happen naturally.I'd like to say that this is your usual Disney movie and go watch with your kids, but honestly just watch the trailer and proceed to the next movie on your list.

reviews.review_title: A well-intentioned mess that manages to be weird - and yet also not weird enough.
reviews.content: Since its publication in 1962, Madeleine L'Engle's A Wrinkle In Time has gained a reputation for being unfilmable... for good reason. The book mixes science fiction and Christian theology in an epic odyssey across time, space and the universe - in ways that are endlessly charming to fans, and frustratingly messy to detractors. L'Engle's defiantly episodic tale provides as many pitfalls as opportunities for aspiring filmmakers - accordingly, director Ava DuVernay winds up getting about as much right as she gets wrong.Meg Murry (Storm Reid) - full of youth, self-loathing and abandonment issues - is the prickly heart of the film. It's been four years since her physicist dad (Chris Pine) disappeared, and Meg is still falling apart. But everything changes when her precocious six-year-old brother, Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe), invites a most peculiar stranger into their home. Before long, Mrs Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) and her two equally unusual friends, Mrs Who (Mindy Kaling) and Mrs Which (Oprah Winfrey), invite the Murry siblings and their new friend, Calvin (Levi Miller), on a journey that will take them to the darkest corners of the galaxy - which might well include the very depths of their own souls.In narrative terms, A Wrinkle In Time makes the canny decision to focus firmly on Meg in moving the story forward. While Meg was also the primary protagonist in the book, L'Engle spent almost as much time dwelling on what made her two male companions so special. The film chooses to lavish more attention on Meg, allowing her and all her insecurities and contradictions to anchor the entire adventure. It's Meg whose undying devotion to her father knocks the travellers off-course, and Meg who refuses to give up when loss threatens to claim her loved ones.On this count, at least, the final result is something quite lovely. Meg is achingly real - an awkward young girl who can neither take nor believe compliments about herself, but who has the potential to change the world if only she can find her confidence and voice. Reid is fantastic in the part, credibly convincing audiences that Meg's faults might also be her gifts - that the outsized amount of love in her heart is not something she needs to hide or play down. It's an empowering message for girls and boys, and probably the best thing about DuVernay's otherwise uneven adaptation.Unfortunately, the rest of A Wrinkle In Time lingers somewhere in the key of mediocre. For a book like L'Engle's, every choice made in changing or updating the novel for the screen will invariably invite debate. Viewers and readers will be discussing for years to come whether Meg's perfectly ordinary twin brothers should have been cut out of the family, and if the film's glamorous, purely Hollywoodian depiction of the three mysterious Mrses somehow makes them less - rather than more - interesting.Where it really counts, however, Jennifer Lee's screenplay seems determined to avoid as much controversy as possible. The film steers almost entirely clear of what made the book such a seminal work of children's literature, paring away the Christian themes and allegories L'Engle embedded in her story and characters. And yet, it retains a lot of the more peculiar detours taken by the book, from visiting a Happy Medium (Zach Galifianakis) to encountering a sinister man with red eyes (Michael Pena). As a result, A Wrinkle In Time is almost as random and weird as the book on which it's based - but lacks the layers and soul that help make the weirdness work.To be fair, there are plenty of enjoyable moments threaded throughout DuVernay's film. If you accept it for what it is, Meg's hero journey is irresistible and important for generations of young girls who will see themselves in her as she steps up and takes charge. Some of the modern updates are hugely welcome - from the diversity of the characters to a quite wonderful Hamilton reference. The cast, too, is uniformly appealing. Witherspoon, in particular, is having the time of her life as the chirpy, chatty Mrs Whatsit;, while Chris Pine continues his streak of playing white, male characters that we don't often see on screen by injecting his performance with a dark fragility.Nonetheless, it's hard to shake the feeling that A Wrinkle In Time could have been so much more. In the hands of DuVernay (and, of course, Disney), the film is visually arresting, turning up the gloss, colour saturation and special effects to elicit full eye-popping wonder. But all the visual resplendence in the world can't disguise the messiness of the film's central themes and ideas. In effect, DuVernay's adaptation - a blockbuster that comes across as safe and generic when it should be bold and unusual - has things of its own to say but, in so doing, it largely misses L'Engle's point.

I wanted to like this movie because of the extensive marketing on it, I assumed it was going to be good, but then again look at how Fifty Shades of Grey and Twilight turned out after all the advertisements... I should of figured it was going to suck and this one kept putting me to sleep throughout the movie. The quotes was ridiculous, associating Einstein, inventors and Frida Kahlo with this was too much, even the dollar store gems on Oprah's forehead were crooked. Why was Oprah even in this film? she's not even a real actress, did she market this film? I could only assume it was her and her millions while trying to stand out in this film as some Goddess hovering over everyone else in her gigantic form. This movie was so bad, and criticizing it automatically makes everyone a racist? next they'll be crying out anti-feminism if you bring up how well Black Panther compared to this film. Wouldn't the antagonist non-believing closed minded Meg more susceptible falling into the darknesses seduction rather than a good boy possessing the power of belief?

I think the book was better than this. When you have Oprah, Chris Pine and many other actors, you expect the story to be great, but it sank. It seemed weak and the kid acrors... well at least they tried. Just stick to the book

Where do I start with this? It's a poorly written, poorly acted, poorly directed and poorly edited movie. It's has unlikable lead characters who fail completely to engage the audience. Mrs what, who and whatsit are pretty much surplus to the film narrative and would have worked better been rolled into one character, instead we get Mindy Kailing and Opera Winfrey looking like runners up in a low brow drag queen contest and Resse Witherspoon trying to be the comic relief with the only relief coming when she's not in a scene. I came out of the auditorium thinking I was Mr why did I see this or Mr where can I get a refund or Mr when will I stop watching films this bad. I honestly see it sweeping up at the next raspberries awards.

Basically took the book and trashed it. Really disappointing that they could just follow the book and not screw it up,but somehow they managed to. Feels like it was written and designed by committee. No vision.
Very boring, some visuals were ok, acting was not very good just an all out bad movie

reviews.review_title: Extremely disappointing considering what they could have done with the story
reviews.content: I saw A Wrinkle in Time today. The first half hour or so had potential, as the little brother was set up as an articulate champion of justice type who dressed down two teachers for spreading malicious gossip about him and his family, and then supported his sister. All this while apparently marshaling the powers that be of the universe to help find their missing father. The sister started out with some potential too, beating up a particularly vicious bully and walking out on a principal who was trying to tear her down without getting the whole story behind her actions first. The acting and makeup for the 3 universe goddess ladies was rather off-putting and honestly came off as TV movie quality, but the CGI once they crossed over to a new place was impressive. Unfortunately, the whole movie falls flat on its face immediately after that and never recovers. Leaving the heavy-handed and insufficiently heartfelt scene with the seer out, the little brother disappears briefly without explanation (only to reappear later also without explanation) during which time the kids run through a supernatural natural disaster of sorts and escape in a barely believable (even in the context of fantasy) way. Shortly after the little brother reappears, he touches the hand of one baddie and suddenly turns into a power-mad villain, which makes no sense since he showed no signs of avarice up to that point and not a drop of darkness in his personality to be used in turning him. If anything, the setup made him seem more likely to end up the hero of the story. This is just clumsy writing. When they finally find the father, despite the fact he's been trapped in the core of evil for the whole universe for 4 years, he shows no signs of having changed in any way - plus he was way too easy to find but that's another issue. Then, even though he's supposed to have been trapped there, he just decides to teleport him and his daughter back home at will. What!?! Couldn't he have done that, say 4 years earlier if it was that simple!?! Also, when he teleports away and the daughter wills herself to stay to go after her brother, the boyfriend is nowhere near and in the end the daughter and her brother go home without the boyfriend... and yet he's there when they arrive home... with no explanation whatsoever. Oh, and one more plot hole regarding the boyfriend. The little brother asked him to come along because they needed his sense of diplomacy, but he never used it once. He barely even spoke. Both he and the little brother had considerable potential as characters, but were not really used at all. What a waste. Finally, the climax "battle" scene of the film kind of undermined the moral of the story (that you should like yourself the way you are) since the argument the daughter made to un-evil her brother was that they loved each other and therefore he couldn't be evil. Huh?Oh, one last note. There was one little moment when the bother yelled to the sister "Shut up, Meg!" Surely someone working on that movie must have seen the show Family Guy once in their life and realized that line would have all the wrong pop culture connotations for a moderately large portion of the audience? I mean, seriously, I don't watch that show and even I know that catchphrase. There was a lot of laughter in the theater at that moment, and I think that's why.I'm guessing something important in the original written story was excised from the screenplay to fill it so full of holes. If not, then this is just a very disappointing story all around. Thematically and stylistically, it wants to be Neverending Story, but it just isn't. At all. Not even close.

reviews.review_title: Inception meets Interstellar, meets Oz the Great and Powerful... confused? You will be!
reviews.content:
As a 40 year old white 'dude'- I was told by Brie Larson that she was NOT interested in my review on this movie, as it- "was not made for me!"
But after watching it... I'm not sure the audience, or the writers, or the cast completely knows who it is for either?
To describe it in a nutshell- 'Inception meets Interstellar, meets Oz the Great and Powerful' (and I didn't really like all three of them)... for kids?... or possibly just girls?... actually it will leave almost EVERYONE confused.
Oprah, Reese Witherspoon and Mandy Kalin seemed awkward, uncomfortable and were all too big and too distinguishable to be in such trippy weird roles.
If the writer/film maker was going for female empowerment, it just wasn't there, though the little girl, boy next door and her brother did pretty good jobs with what they had.
Michael Pena was good, (but brief), he almost always is.
Chris Pine was fine. He always is... never good, always 'just' OK... sigh.
The fantasy world/science talk/space-time left a lot to be desired, and there are elements of hell imagery and evil towards the end that didn't fit with most of the movie.
But all in all, I watched the whole thing to see what would happen next and it was not as bad as the other 2 movies I watched this weekend (Oceans 8 & Halloween 2018) which were both terrible attempts at far left-wing feminist propaganda, which this movie fortunately never really felt like (but it also didn't really feel like a Disney Classic).

reviews.review_title: It brings joy to my heart that so many imbd users hate this movie as much as I do
reviews.content: I've thought about this: this is actually the worst movie ever made (in my opinion).

reviews.review_title: Had to rate it, and lowest I could do was 1.
reviews.content: More often than not, the genres Adventure, Family, Fantasy has become synonymous with moral studies classes for children about good vs evil. Gone are the days when one could simply sit back and enjoy children's films like the Swiss Family Robinson or Tom Sawyer without being treated to either a contrasting and convoluted twist or a moral science class.

How could they abuse, torture, annihilite one of my absolute favorite books from my childhood? I feel so angry at the director! I think there needs to be a court for punishing these crimes.
Apart from the characters and the premise of the story the movie has nothing - absolutely nothing to do with the book! 
For example Mrs. Whatsit:
Book: "...was it a tramp? It seemed small for Meg's idea of a tramp.The age or sex was impossible to tell, for it was completely bundled up in clothes. Several scarves of assorted colours were tied about the head, and a man's fel hat perched atop. A shocking pink stole was knotted about a rough overcoat, and black rubber boots covered the feet."
In the movie you get a glamorous woman in technicolor dreamcoat clothes who always smiles and has nothing meaninful to contribute to the story.
And why was there a flying lettuce? And how did the smoke monster from Lost make it into the story? Oh, sorry there is no story. That was somehow edited out of the movie. What is left are random fantasy action scenes and long meaningful glances combined with saccharine smiles.

I don't understand the critics' hate on this. I really enjoyed this movie. Almost all the acting was good, the effects were as trippy as they should have been, and the story was more-or-less the same as the book. My only complaints are that the actor who played Charles Wallace was not as creepy in the second half as he should have been. (But he's still a child, so I'm not going to be too harsh). I was worried when Michael Pena was cast as the villain, because generally his roles are comedic, and even when he's playing a villain, like in ''My Little Pony: The Movie" it's as the main villains' sidekick/comic relief. Surprisingly, he did a good job. The character in the story is supposed to be an allegory for the devil, and while he wasn't as creepy as I would have liked, he did add another element to the character by posing as friendly in order to tempt the main characters more. They also got rid of the part of the story with Aunt Beast. (Yay! Seriously. What were those things? Chewbacca's second cousins? Whatever they were, I always hated that part as I felt it slowed the plot down and added nothing. By cutting that part they proved how unnecessary it was and the story still works without it.) Being a Disney film, they of course toned down the creepiness of the planet Camazotz. (Boo!) I would have preferred it to be as scary as the book and 2003 film. It was still a bit unsettling, but not as much as it should have been. Overall, I thought this was a fine adaptation, albeit a slightly flawed one.
Grade: A- 9/10 3.5/5 stars

Hellloooo Disney!? What are you guys doing? First Project T and now this? The story is very boring, Though I believe the book is great. So much CGI and green screen..it's a pity.. there are like a lot of beautiful places here in the world.. The camera is like inches away from the actors..I thought it were my glasses. Also what up with those dramatic clothing/wigs from the so called misses? It was so weird... Also all that green didn't make Reese Witherspoon prettier or something. Why shoot such weird scenes with Oprah? I mean like the part where the kids are randomly flying on the back of the cgi creature and then there is this shot: Friends of light help him. Also too much drama! We get it they lost their dad...they' re sad... but so much drama is too much for me! I am sorry, I really love Disney , I love all the actors in the movie...But they should' ve done better...

So I didn't go into this one with particularly high hopes... lets be honest, Oprah isn't exactly known for her acting skills across her entire career, but I had some hope with Chris Pine and Reese Witherspoon.I've not read the book/s, so I really was going into this blind. I wish at the end of that 1hr40min disaster I'd not only been blind, but also deaf and rather stupid.From start to end, it just lacks any depth, any story, any satisfaction at all other than the occasional bit of great special effects work. The timeline is all over the place, the characters are shallow and lacking any depth that gives you an investment in who they are or what they are doing, and the acting is at best little better than what I would expect of C grade actors. I think Chris and Reese just turned up for a day or two in-between another more interesting and better paid project, meanwhile Oprah just didn't have much else on that month.I really did ponder if I had fallen asleep and missed a main part of the story, but no, I evidently didn't and what seems to be some large jumps in storytelling were indeed what this film had.Maybe it's a kids film, and they might be too daft to notice all the holes and flaws in general, but these days I doubt that. Basically it was just a terrible film, made no worse perhaps by Oprah and her 'acting', but certainly made no better by the supposedly good actors involved.What I find most marvellous is the fact Disney and others continue to no doubt spend millions on this sort of garbage, when that money might be better spent else where, or donated to the poor and homeless. And whoever wrote this script (adapted it from the book I suppose), should be marched immediately out of the office and banished into the nothing. (Speaking of nothing, haven't we heard this concept before, it was far much like 'the never ending story' without the story and the acting and such. I imagine this won't be a movie people will be hunting out 20 years from now as is the case with my generation and the aforementioned Never Ending Story.Certainly don't bother seeing this anywhere that you would have to pay for it, you'll be bored to tears and annoyed you didn't spend your time and money better.

reviews.review_title: Uneven storytelling is buried through the visuals to being a forgettable film.
reviews.content: A Wrinkle in Time (3 out of 5 stars). A Wrinkle in Time a fantasy adventure film that is visually beautiful and stunning to look at if you can get by with a plot that seems hallow. I never read the book; I am coming from a fresh perspective on this film. And it is not Disney's worse film like Tomorrowland. The performances were emotional and inspirational. The visual effects were great. But the plot seems thin when you think about it after it is over. It is one of those films that you see once and may not enjoy the experience again. The plot follows Meg (Storm Reid) after years with the disappearance of her father Dr. Alex (Chris Pine). When he was working on something new that can transport a person between space and time to another universe. Meg's younger adoptive brother Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) is a genius and has been speaking to Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon). Mrs. Whatsit tries to recruit Meg, Charles, and her friend Calvin (Levi Miller) to go on a journey to another planet to search for her missing father. What worked great with A Wrinkle in Time? The film's visual effects were spectacular. Meg meets the three ladies Mrs. Who (Mindy Kaling), Mrs. Which (Oprah Winfrey), and Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) and they go to a beautiful planet, were the flowers speak to each other. They fly through a sky from a mystical transformed creature. Then, they travel to a rocky balanced setting, were they meet Zach Galifianakis's character. Then, to a dark place called the it, were all the dark negative energy lies upon. It is a fun adventure to see these beautiful visual effects. Which is also the weakness of this film as well. When the film relies on visuals over storytelling. Storm Reid did perfect with her performance. You grow to like her character. Levi Miller was also okay as well that has an attraction to Meg. Chris Pine was good as her father for the brief moments that he is on screen. Reese Witherspoon and Mindy Kaling were great as well. What did not work with A Wrinkle in Time? Like I said above, the film relying on visuals over storytelling. The movie is all visual effects and there may be scenes were it is overdone. But the plot is thin. It is about a father's passion in discovering new planets in different universes. And the voyage to the unknown. When Meg goes traveling to one visual fest set piece to another. Meeting new characters and getting a lead to another new setting. There is not much of a story when characters are just traveling to another eye candy visual set piece. There is a theme of love in the film. But does poorly on trying to execute a story. Also, I feel like Oprah Winfrey, Deric McCabe, and Michael Pena's performances were just dull. Winfrey as Mrs. Which did not have any depth with the character. Deric McCabe did decent as a genius kid. Michael Pena as Red was just terrible.Overall, A Wrinkle in Time is a fair film. The visual effects are spectacular but overwhelming. The plot is thin and forgettable. Storm Reid was great and some decent performances from the supporting cast. Otherwise, I will recommend the film as a rental unless you are a fan of the book or want to see some stunning visuals on the big screen.
The most boring movie I have seen. What a disappointment.

reviews.review_title: This is why we need a zero-star option.
reviews.content: I gave it two stars, so that my rating won't be lost in the intricate vote-average system, which ignores 1's and 10's.Anyway, from the way this movie was hyped and promoted constantly on Ellen and other talk shows, I knew it would be bad. But it exceeded my expectations... meaning that I didn't expect it to be this awful.You wouldn't believe it, I certainly wouldn't believe it either if someone told me... but these people spent 100-million dollars for a movie with no sets at all (everything is low grade CGI). But the most significant, inconceivable point is that the plot involves children going to a magical land where everything is magical, and you know, filled with magic and stuff that has magic in it... with the added bonus of magic. You know? Flying creatures, beautiful landscape, which is supposed to make the kids in the audience "woooow!" like their onscreen counterparts, and carry them away for two hours.Which could very well happen, of course. But only if the kids in the audience haven't seen any of the eight Harry Potter films. Or the Narnia films. Or the Lord Of The Rings films. Or Spiderwick. Or Labyrinth. Or any of the dime-a-dozen, you-get-free-with-any-10-dollar-purchase children's animation DVDs. Or any of the stuff that's free on TV (which are all way better than this).I know for a fact that it's playing on a non-stop loop on the world's largest, diamond-studded TV somewhere in Oprah's palace, just to give her a chance to see herself some more, but if you've seen any movie that's been made in the last 20 years... hell, even if you've seen any well-made commercial, you can skip this one.

reviews.review_title: TOO much taken out of the book
reviews.content: First off, I know books turned into movies will always be different. However, this is the first one I saw where so much was eliminated that the movie just does not makes sense. Most of what I loved about the book was the journey Meg took to get to her father and all the events that happen along the way. This movie basically glossed right over those, which took out so much of the joy of the story. I went with someone who never read the book and she was so confused over this entire movie's concept, basically because the entire middle of the story-line was missing. I was really looking forward to this movie because this was one of my top five books growing up. It's so sad that the transition was done so poorly.

All the cast and crew wasted their talent on a script that's not even very faithful to the book and a director, whom I blame for some of the poor acting on its actors. I think the actors would actually do a very good job if it wasn't for the director, they all have potential but unfortunately, they wasted their talents on poor directing and writing.The cast is miscast. Something about Storm Reid just didn't feel like Meg to me, she did pretty well portraying her insecure personality but she just seemed robotic when Meg was much more of an emotional character in the book. I guess it's because adapting a book character as emotional as Meg would make the movie too dramatic but when strange things would be happening, she would be like "Oh okay..." she didn't show much expressions of curiosity, fear, confusion etc.. Mrs. Whatsit played by Reese Witherspoon just seemed too excitable. Also, Reese Witherspoon is like in her 40s while I saw Mrs. Whatsit as an older woman. Mrs. Who, played by Mindy Kaling would mostly talk in quotes and would even say things that didn't feel natural to the scenes. Charles Wallace is supposed to be 5 yet Deric McCabe looks like he's 9. And Calvin has the cliched love-at-first-sight thing going on, swooning over Meg's hair and how she's hot.The only good things I can say about the movie were the visuals and most of the more fast-paced scenes. They were fun to watch. But all in all, this is an unfaithful adaptation of a book that takes out some important parts from the book and adds some new ones.I do believe "A Wrinkle in Time" book has the potential to get adapted to a good film, maybe not an excellent film because the book is too complex to be made into a wonderful film.

reviews.review_title: All the hype was only in the Trailer
reviews.content: Sigh... I went in with high expectation as seeing a number of big names in Hollywood (it Oprah for goodness sake!) But much to my disappointment the big names remained just big names. Oprah, Mindy Kaling and Reese Witherspoon who played Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit and Mrs. Who have little to no significant roles in this movie. I kept waiting to see more magical moments coming from these three roles but only met with the lack of it. This movie missed numerous opportunities to deliver some comedic moment/line either from the three misses or the children. Talking bout the children, yeah they're cute and pretty all that but there's nothing really making them quite likeable especially the main child, Meg. She's described as unorganised, problematic, aggressive kid but all of these characteristics were only proven in the movie in 1 scene only and what, they thought that is enough to make us believe that she is this out of control, problematic girl?? Heck no. As mentioned, there is nothing really likeable or relatable with the character Meg and so its hard to care for her and in the end, I just can't help but to not rooting for her. She is in this magical journey with her lil bro and friend but all she keep doing was complaining, but at the same wanting to save her father. How the heck do you wanna save your father when all you do is complain? Anyway, no hate towards the child but I do believe if they chosen another well performed child actor for the role of Meg, it'd be a better character. But I do quite impressed with the one who played Charles Wallace. That kid can deliver!

And a really boring story and awful soundtrack. It's really hard to believe this is a Disney movie. Well one that they put in theaters anyway. I guess this would have been fine on the Disney channel especially since it's basically an ad for Disney pop music singers.

reviews.review_title: Congrats to minority female director with a huge budget
reviews.content: I didn't believe the reviews and thought it couldn't be, it's a Disney film. WRONG. Boring beyond belief. The casts seems forced. I'm a minority, but sorry I didn't appreciate the diversity at all. Boyfriend fell asleep 3 times and never finish. I finished in 2 sittings. There's nothing to see here. Don't waste your time. I'm just happy it's over so I can return it.

After 10-15 minutes in the movie, I started thinking what have i gotten myself into and why why why didn't I read the reviews before I watched it? Life is full of regrets and these are moments I'll NEVER ever get back again my life. Meg, her face is frozen in sourness from start to finish, even after finding dad and that final hug, her face is still stuck in a dour expression. Smiling takes a lot of effort out of her and seemed even unnatural. Perhaps she should have played the role of one of the mean kids?Charles Wallace, For heaven's sake must you call him with both names ALL the time!!!!??? Even in supposedly intense moments, the time taken to yell both names just intensified my irritation. And kid, learn to speak clearly. I have no idea what you are talking about!The 3 beings, why is Oprah bigger than everybody? with her garish costumes, awfully glittery makeup, I feel like overwhelmed. Her reputation bigger than life itself also distract the role from her. It just never felt right. They have absolutely no chemistry with one another at all. And the looks they gave each other is so awkward.Plot is non existent, tries too hard to push a lesson that no one cares about. Plodding its way to god knows where, I felt every minute go by and that is a sign of a BAD movie.

I heard about how bad this movie was, but I wanted to give it a try and see for myself. I managed 45 minutes and turned it off.I remember at the Oscars when they gate crashed a screening of it during the show, this probably stopped people from walking out of the screening as it couldn't have been the movie keeping them in their seats.The acting was that of a bad stage play, like they just didn't really care and probably did one take and thought "that'll do".
For something of this budget and from Disney, I am shocked.
I enjoy a good family movie, but this is just not good. I liked some of the science elements to it, but that isn't what this movie focused on.Plenty of better family sci-fi movies out there;
The Last Mimzy, Flight of the Navigator, Explorers, Titan A.E. to name a few
Kids were bored, I was bored. No cohesiveness. Story made no sense and was all over the place. How did this get released?
Does this movie have a plot or purpose? Is it trying to sell feelings and struggle? Who knows. Songs are interspersed for no reason. And it's incredible slow.

reviews.review_title: Bruh.... The Things We Do for Love Right?
reviews.content: Look.... This movie was so bad that I made an active choice to make a log in account just to leave this review. It has no substance, no real plot, no philosophical backbone, and no sense whatsoever. I sat through it though. I sat through each nonsensical scene change, "emotional payout", and the acting. I have to die knowing that a small chunk of my brain will remember the disappointment I have for two things - this movie and myself for not having the balls to tell my spouse "NO!"........

This movie doesn't receive all it's props. I believe many don't have the right amount of imagination to watch this movie which is why everyone else is reviewing and giving it a 1. This movie was well put together and captured many parts from the book. To have adults and kids intrigued by the same movie, I believe its a win!

I literally made an account on this site so I could redirect the negative attitude towards this movie. Granted I have never read the book, but this movie made me want to. I don't care if it doesn't do justice to the novel, we can not overlook the overlying message this movie tries to portray to its viewers. It is a beautiful work of art on its own, visually, and through story-telling. It is all about the conquering of our own insecurities and faults through the power of love, a force so strong it bends space and time. Shame on anyone who discredits this movie due to its discontinuities to its source material. This movie is a verdict of how we should be living and treating others, and to deny its quality is bringing the darkness out into this world. It's a beautiful movie, touching, and very teaching. Please watch it and take it whole heartedly. It's absolutely gorgeous.
I had hoped this would be a fun, maybe thought provoking movie. I was wrong!!! Upside down plot with weak characters and progressive politics thrown in for good measure....

reviews.review_title: Someone please... make it make sense lol
reviews.content: I am a kid at heart and I can for sure say that if Disney were to EVER MAKE MY FAVORITE CARTOON INTO A MOVIE AND IT BE THIS MUCH OF A DISAPPOINTMENT, aka (The Little Mermaid) I, without a doubt will find someone to SUE for ruining my childhood for me! To the adults who fell in love with this story as a child and then had to endure this painful redendition of it, I apologize to u! I feel your pain as this was just awful ha ha ha. Oprah girl, just why???

Why are people hating on this film? imdb is showing an average user rating of 3 out of 10? REALLY?? Not only was this film gorgeous, but it kept most of the story in tact and translated the lessons and morality from the book to the screen perfectly. There was one plot hole I noticed but I was able to look past that because I was just having so much fun.

I like reading imdb reviews because 90% are usually honest. So I waited the movie to be available on dvd since I realised many reviews complained of wasting money from it.Well,,turns out they were right! Here is my summary:+Good Graphics and CGI
+Potential Good Story
+The One star I cant ommit while rating
-Terrible acting from nearly all characters
-So many Story Plotholes
-Poor script writing 
-Unnecessary characters
-Inability to connect with characters
-Boring conversations and interactions
-Unecessary musicTo conclude,Shame on disney for this one!!!

reviews.review_title: "Disappointing" is too much of an understatement
reviews.content: The movie got two stars from me because of good efx, The rest was just a disaster. A book that won multiple awards and has been a standby for middle school literature was absolutely ripped up and thrown away. A beautiful story was ruined.They used the names from the book and some terms, otherwise it was completely unrecognizable. The child actors (Storm Reid, Levi Miller and Deric McCabe) all did credible jobs, while the adult actors, many of whom are very accomplished, fell flat, which lays the blame at the foot of director Ava DuVernay.As to the horrible, disjointed story, I don't know who to blame other than Jennifer Lee and Jeff Stockwell.I hope losing $200 million on this movie was a lesson to TWDC to not mess with well known, much beloved books.

It is actully that they could make such a nonsensical movie from such good starting material. By 30 minutes it is apparent that they have dumbed down all of the characters. The plot line is completely lacking. It was hard to push through to the end of the movie.

reviews.review_title: I wanted to like it, for it's diversity, but if a movie's not good, it's just not good.
reviews.content: 'A WRINKLE IN TIME': Three Stars (Out of Five)A big budget sci-fi fantasy kids' flick, about a young girl that sets out to find her father, who went missing after discovering an unknown planet, with the help of three magical space travelers. The film was directed by Ava DuVernay (who also helmed the critically acclaimed Oscar nominees 'SELMA' and '13TH'), and it was scripted by Jennifer Lee. The movie is based on the book (of the same name) by Madeleine L'Engle. It stars Storm Reid, Levi Miller, Deric McCabe, Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling, Chris Pine, Gugu Mbatha-Raw, Michael Pena and Zach Galifianakis. The film has received mostly negative reviews from critics so far, and it's just a modest hit at the Box Office as well. I found it to be pretty to look at, but it's also pretty boring and uninspiring. Meg Murry (Reid), and her younger brother Charles Wallace (McCabe), have been bullied at school ever since their astrophysicist father, Alex (Pine), went missing years earlier. Then one day Meg learns that he's being held captive on another planet. So Meg, Charles Wallace, and Meg's new friend Calvin O'Keefe (Miller), set out to rescue him. They get help from three magical astral travelers (Winfrey, Witherspoon and Kaling). The movie is always beautiful to look at, and I really wanted to like it. Largely because it has a diverse cast, with multiple minority and female leads in it, and it was directed by an African-American woman. If the movie's not good, it's just not good though. It did have a lot of potential, I'll admit, and it's a decent kids' movie (I probably would have liked it a lot more when I was that age). It's also well intentioned obviously. I think it would have been better served with a much smaller budget though. Sure it wouldn't have been as visually stunning (which is it's one saving grace), but I think DuVerany could have focused a lot more on it's heart (and message) that way. I also would have cast three different (better) actresses as the astral travelers.

reviews.review_title: Literally the biggest waste of time I've ever watched
reviews.content: The amount of dead space in this film is STAGGERING. There are scenes that go by for ten minutes and by the end you're filled with pent-up frustration because they're taking so long between lines and when they do speak they're not even saying anything. Seriously, they could've cut out 20+ minutes from this movie and it wouldn't have affected the story whatsoever. My mind is boggled. If you looked out your window for two hours, you would see more meaningful and fulfilling content than is in this film.The acting is FINE! That's not the problem. There's o my so much the actors can do when their lines and actions are as meaningless as they are in this. The budget for this movie could've been used for so many better projects.I put this on as something to have on whilst I write on my computer, and even as a BACKGROUND MOVIE it was unbearably empty.I actually don't know if I've ever written a review on here before, and I don't like to be negative about people's creative works, but I came straight here after finishing this film. Seriously, honestly, if you hit me over the head with a spoon for two hours I would feel more satisfied than how I feel after watching A Wrinkle In Time.

reviews.review_title: Way to ruin an award winning book Disney!!
reviews.content: Absolutely horrible movie adaptation of one of my absolute favorite books. I broke down and decided to finally watch it after avoiding it just based on the trailer. 20 minutes in and I knew it was going to be as horrible as I predicted. Disney made sure to make it as PC as possible and glitzed it up to make the Mrs. W's more like fairy godmothers and the scenes more Alice in Wonderland and less scary than the book. I remember parts of the book being incredibly terrifying. The only scary scene in the movie was more Pirates of the Caribbean scary, not terrifying. So many key scenes and aspects were left out, some of which include the fact that there were also twin boys, the Murray's lived on a farm with an orchard, stone fence and star gazing rock, the Mrs. W's first appeared as bag ladies, the boy who dropped his ball in the synced bouncing scene. Many of these elements come into play later, in either this book or the series, and were completely ignored. The only saving grace of this movie was some of the acting. Charles Wallace was excellent. Calvin would have been great, too, had they actually delved into his character and his relationship with Meg properly. Meg, one of my all time favorite female characters and an inspiration as an awkward adolescent, was totally flat and unbelievable. Was it terrible writing or terrible casting? I don't know. But terrible, nonetheless. Madeline L'Engle would be as disappointed in this movie as I was. I hope Disney stops here and leaves the rest of the series alone.

I am not sure what to say about this movie. It is not what I expected, it looks cheaply done..even with the effects. Acting was just average. It's a great story, just too bad the movie isn't so great.

I knew the moment I saw the teaser that this is was going to be a REALLY good movie. I was definitely right! I read this book when I was about seven and I remember wanting there to be a movie about the book SO bad. When I saw the original Wrinkle In Time movie, I was disappointed. It wasn't very good. Fast forward to 2018, and we're getting bright colors, amazing actors, and a modern storyline that makes for a great adaptation of the book. Storm Reid should be proud that this got to be her breakthrough!
The kids were confused, I was confused and the director must have been confused...this was a mess of a movie. It tried too hard and missed the mark completely.

I was so excited to watch this movie and so i brought along my friend to enjoy it with me on its premiere. Lets just say it ended up with me feeling ashamed and couldn't look into my friend's eyes because I was so embarrassed for getting all hyped up on this useless piece. And we both agreed the only thing that we enjoyed in this movie is hearing the soundtrack sung by Sia. And not gonna lie, there was a moment where i almost fell asleep while watching this and my friend did too. I could hear her yawning and snoozing! I was disappointed with the lack of magic there is and Oprah, Mindy Kaling and Reese Witherspoon were not as magical as they were meant to be. Shame.

I still don't know why I watched this film this weekend but I as a self professed lover of film needed to keep judgment out while watching this film. It was hard having an open mind because the trailers looked....well.... bad. I was hoping for something smart and entertaining at least. While the film isn't as bad as I thought it was there's plenty of problems that ruin the film and outweigh some of the positives. I think young children will enjoy this because they won't pay attention to its flaws.The film is about a girl named Meg and her quest to find her astrophysicist father who disappeared 4 years prior. She soon realizes that reality is not what it seems and her father is being held captive on a foreign planet by an evil force named The It which attempts to engulf the universe. The film is noticeable for its diversity in cast and story and for being the first 9 figure budget picture directed by a woman of color. While I ca appreciate that aspect of the background of the film and the ambitious effort by Ava DuVernay, the film is still a mess.Some of the positives. The film definitely means well and the younger crowd should be impressed by the visuals and adventurous themes. Some of the passages of the journey of the film are also cool. Now the bad, the child actors really aren't good. Especially the younger brother. I can't really blame them because they are kids, but it was distracting. There is lots of CGI, some parts look great and others the effects are very noticeable. There's also storytelling flaws. Things aren't explained well and we are meant to just accept thing as "oh yeah science". It gets frustrating when inexplicable things happen for the sake of it.I must admit the film is nowhere near as bad as I anticipated. Parts of the film are interesting. Most however is hard to connect with and get emotionally involved in. I'm sure there are people out there whoa re perfectly satisfied with this judging by the applause it received in the theater from other moviegoers. For me though, its a big budget film that needed to be much more to warrant an impact.5.5/10

reviews.review_title: The story that succumbed to its own villain
reviews.content: The film feels like it was produced by The IT itself - so arranged, artificial, by the template - that it as a whole reminded of the scary suburban street with copy-paste houses and inhabitants. Calculatedly pleasing to the eye, but otherwise lifeless. I guess there were the good intentions and perhaps even the talented ensemble - but The IT in the form of the big badass corporation as Disney, in the board of directors, distorted manager's minds, pseudo-psychology calculations on what "moves" and "sells" to the audience and all "the science" of the business ... could hardly produce anything else than the tombstone to the deluded corporate world, Hollywood style.Don't get me on praising "at least the stunning visual effects". They are unimaginative kytsch, boring, underwhelming - considering what we have seen already. No, nowadays spectators cannot be stimulated by quantity, nor by colors anymore. That's not the way to go. Is that the storytelling and acting and directing of the 21st century - people interacting with random "cool" CGIs, almost detached from reality? "I am flying. I am walking the imaginary stairs. I am interacting with zillions of flying dots. I am changing shape and colors." Is that all to the contemporary kid's souls - interacting with VFX? The three godfairies, divas, drag queens - or whatever - are sort of an emblem of this production: Lavishly dressed, but static, statue-like, arranged (symmetrically) ... lifeless.Good=light, evil=darkness? Seriously? What about the potential of art to challenge the status quo, cliches, moralism, cheapness, simplification ... and thus educate?That good=nice vs evil=mean is so neatly contrasted, that there it leaves no space for real-life characters, emotions, or audience's connection.I appreciate the irony towards suburban dystopia - or the overcrowded beach scenes ... yeah, the standardized normal families, the template lives, the template fun, the template joy - epileptically colorful and in the same time same, alike, interchangeable - but that theme could have been juiced endlessly. As an independent movie.Oh my, where are the times of The Toys at least.

This movie is inspiring for all ages.If you love the book, see it for yourself don't let the critics tell you otherwise.Oprah is amazing along with Reece Witherspoon and Mindy Kaling.And great visuals.

reviews.review_title: I felt bad for the actors in this, poor reimagining of a great story
reviews.content:
One thing about the vast majority of movies and are either not well made or just plain bad usually is of no fault of the actors involved. The actors all did a great job and I refuse to fault them for this movie doing so badly. I think all of them did a great job and that needs to be said. However, when the story does not come together and the script is bad, and when, in this case, the book does not follow certain thing crucial to the story, then it seems that often times it can look like a bad performance on their part which is very unfair. I also wonder how much is on the editing room floor.I do think it's great when a story adapted from a book can be reimagined using more modern day situations and events that are more relatable if it's possible and this one should have been one of those. For instance, Calvin's dad being very demanding. We do not actually "see" his dad in the novel, we see his mother who is a worn out, bitter woman who is a bit abusive. But, the book seems to be missing some characters such as Meg and Charles Wallace twin brothers. Other things that were changed were things like who Meg was. She was a "trouble maker" meaning that she was assertive in a "rage against the machines" type of way. In this version, Meg seems more like a push over who cowers at things instead of "fighting back." I have read A Wrinkle in Time" twice and Meg's dad was not gone for so long. Basically, the movie was missing half it's characters or a lot of them anyway.
Things happened very fast whereas the book and the previous 2003 version, the TV Movie, showed a longer passage of time. It felt very rushed, had little character development on a lot of the characters, had frayed ends in the story to the point where it just became annoying and unwatchable. I had a hard time following it and it felt like it was saying nothing with a whole lot. It will be interesting to see if an uncut version comes out, but it is still missing two important characters, the twin brothers, in the story.. It was oversimplified and should have been a longer movie.So, I would not recommend this movie to anyone who has read any of Madeleine L'Engle's books about the Murray?O'Keefe family aka the Kairos series.

I was so excited for this movie. I loved the book as a kid, the cast seemed solid, and the visuals looked awesome. Unfortunately, it was far below my expectations. While the movie is visually stunning with the pops of color and interesting landscapes, the story is disjointed and the acting seems forced or somehow oddly directed. I mostly was bored and confused with the movie. It seemed very much all over the place. The major plot lines were poorly explained. This seemed like it would be a slam dunk since Disney has a reputation for adapting stories, but they fell short here.

reviews.review_title: Good movie up til a point, then too much deviation
reviews.content: I can understand some changes to make a book work as a visual entity, or to take some stuff from the 60's and update/modernize it. This movie was working pretty well for me up until they reach Camazotz. At that point, they took a drastic change from the book, which I think caused the movie to suffer. The book had so many layered themes in it, and I can understand not being able to show them all effectively, or some upgrades from the cold war era feel, but to pretty much chuck the whole second half of the book out in favor of some hard to follow mind trip really suffered.If you can get past that, overall it wasn't bad, but it also wasn't great. Visually it looked great. Kudos for the director for working with kids and getting a decent performance out of them and doing a good job with what they were given, but the writer should have worked a little more on the screenplay.
A Wrinkle in Time might have decent acting, but it is has way too much CGI that is very noticeable, awkward moments, and a story that doesn't even matter.

I can't believe how cringe worthy this movie is. Its almost like an art installation that is made to make you uncomfortable. Words can't express how awkward the acting is. The CGI is so over used and is clear and bright but also gaudy and cheap somehow. The make up and wigs are so so so bad. Mindy Kaling (who I really like normally) is the worst actress in this role I have ever seen. The plot makes absolutely no sense (I've read the book) and its action sequences don't make any sense. The comedy falls flat and even Reese Witherspoon seems lost. Really one of the worst movies I've ever seen.

reviews.review_title: "A Wrinkle In Time": A Muddled and Ultimately Unfocused Piece that Refuses to do Justice with an Incredible Cast
reviews.content:
"A Wrinkle In Time," is an incredibly lacking piece that neglects to be a coherent story with applicable motivations. A good amount of the film simply does not make sense (How was the father being detained? What is the relevance of Veronica, Rowan Blanchard's character? Furthermore, what was the relevance of Calvin?). I think that the story never quite realized its purpose and just seemed to be going through the motions. The director, Ava Duvernay, has proved herself more than capable, yet her style here is almost laughable. I just think the director, and part of the cast was mis-chosen, which is a sentiment frequently proved throughout the film. The effects, for the most part, were haphazardly done, and I felt the film was generally at its strongest when dealing with literal backgrounds and sets, rather than a CGI/green screened backdrop. For example, the scene in which Mrs. Who interacts with Charles Wallace has an engaging and interesting feel to it, even if the acting and directing is lacking. In conclusion, unless you are a die-hard Disney fan who has taken a blood oath to read every. single. film. they release, I do not encourage "A Wrinkle In Time." I hate to say it, but even "Sherlock Gnomes" would be more focused.2/10
20%
F

reviews.review_title: I Wish I Could Wrinkle Two Hours Of My Life Back (a haiku)
reviews.content:
I should have walked out.
Worst film I have ever seen.
No, seriously.

reviews.review_title: Why is it called, "Wrinkle in Time."
reviews.content: This movie has almost no connection to the book by the same name.So, yes, the father disappears and the children travel to other worlds to find and rescue him, but that's the end of the connection.If you're thinking of watching this movie because you believe it will be a reasonable adaptation of the book, it is not.If you're looking to be entertained by a unusual and quirky movie -- this is it.

reviews.review_title: Read the book, skip this disastrous adaptation.
reviews.content: Within the first few minutes it was obvious that some Hollywood hacks had mangled a sci-fI/fantasy classic. The costumes were ludicrous. I'd rather stare at a Wooden Indian then watch The Big O "act". A monstrous abomination, do not waste your time or hard earned money. But definitely read the book or listen to the audiobook. Then give it to or read it to those special young people in your life.
The spoiler in my review is that you are going to hate yourself for watching it.

Attempts at deep character development were made but failed to move past empty words and complete cliches.
Attempts to utilize a star-studded cast failed because actors were given a cheesy script and mediocre co-stars.
Attempts to evoke emotion were cringe, cringe, and cringe.
Attempts to follow the book were not made at all...
I liked the music and the visual effects though?

reviews.review_title: Well... my child said she liked it so I guess that's all that matters.
reviews.content: It was very slow and boring. Not exciting like the trailers showed it would be. The adult cast was good but the child star cast was bad. I'm sorry but those kids can't act. Overall no character development, Disney just expects us to care about these characters by default and I hate when movies do that.The scene where she reunites with her dad is so cringy. Just bad. There were times where my 7 year old started playing with her toys ignoring the movie. So she said she liked it but I could tell she was bored.

The high point of the movie was Reese Witherspoon - though even she was bogged down by sub-par lines. She was the only part of the entire movie that exceeded "average".Most of the rest of the acting was average - or sub par. Maybe with a better script?
Oprah came across with the skill, personality and appearance of an oil drum with sequins plastered on top.
Special effects looked like something across between Cirque du Soleil swaths of ribbon blowing in the wind and a bad 1970's light show.The villain wasn't much of a villain.
The hero wasn't much of a hero.
The "quest" wasn't much of a quest.
The dialog was pointless and went nowhere.Poor script.
Mediocre acting.
Lousy script.
Boring, repetitious special effects.
Very little to recommend this movie.
Three stars may be too high a rating.Maybe a bored 4-year-old would like this film, but in general, don't waste your time.

Disney Studios doesn't have a great track record with live action features in the last decade. The production company attempts to push their limits with a larger than life fantasy world yet misses their mark more often than not. A Wrinkle in Time (2018) is no exception. Vast colorful worlds can't make up for for its claustrophobic scenes.Feeble attempts to make sense of a magical world existing within the real one. Obnoxious child actors that take the viewer right out of the scene. From a studio that has had near a century to play around with different ways to tell a story, its a wonder they couldn't get A Wrinkle in Time correct.

reviews.review_title: Utterly utterly utterly utterly utterly utterly utterly awful.
reviews.content: I'm not exaggeration when I say this this full stop right here >.< is more interesting to look at for 2 hours than this utter pile of horse dung. I've seen some bad films in my life but this takes the biscuit. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY ON IT.

When you see a movie get overly advertised on every form of social media and during "First Look" at the theaters, 9 times out of 10, the movie is a complete disaster. Some people think because they have an original story and a camera that it'll make a great, amazing movie people will be talking about forever. It's sad that Hollywood will make this crap even after our time here, and reboots will eventually be it's only option to turn a profit. Movies are becoming too predictable and boring nowadays, and now this movie forces parents to spend money on it because it captures the eyes of their children. "Bright colors and relatable teens" are all you need for the overpriced ticket. Do yourself a favor, learn from this movie and don't waste money on a movie like this until you do the research. And remember, too much advertisements are most likely not a good thing, waiting til the $1 redbox rental is probably better if you MUST see it.

reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle In Time wrinkles away in a timely fashion.
reviews.content: One of my most anticipated of the year ultimately becomes one of the most disappointing. Whether it be studio interference from Disney or source material too complex to adapt, this film fell flat and left me underwhelmed. A bold scientist suddenly disappears as he attempts to discover an alternate reality, four years later his daughter and son become embroiled in a rescue mission which in turn becomes a quest to save the universe. Adapting the unadaptable will gain praise from me, just for the sheer bravery and boldness of such an attempt. But in hindsight some stories just cannot be adapted cinematically, this is one of them. The technical aspects are the selling point, fantasy worlds filled with bright vibrant colours and imaginative environments. A rather surreal experience with many ethereal scenes, such as the process of "tessering". It maintained my interest through visual awe and delight. DuVernay's direction is splendid and surprisingly makes the transition from powerful dramas to big budget blockbusters effortlessly. The acting was solid, particularly Pine who brings some much needed emotion and Winfrey whose physical prowess portrays a commanding character. The major issues I have inherently come from the screenplay and narrative. The dialogue is consistently filled with exposition, leaving little room for backstory and character development. It's purely focussing on universe-building and crafting creative landscapes, a minimal amount of attention was made to creating a cohesive plot. I mean honestly, many aspects were incomprehensible as it leaves you questioning "what the hell is going on!? How did that happen? Why is he there? Who are these Mrs's beings?" The countless lingering plot holes will infuriate older audiences, whilst the complicated narrative is too advanced for younger viewers. The theme of love is dealt heavy handedly that it left me face palming myself. This is no means a horrific film, with some being slightly too harsh. Technically astute, however it's just unfortunate that it's a wrinkling mess.

reviews.review_title: My wife can't stay to the end of the movie
reviews.content: She stormed out half way to vomit and wanted to find the theater manager to ask for a refund, which is a first for her. I slept all the way to the end and was waken up by all the disappointed sighs around me. I have no idea how such a movie was ever to be made, it has no meaning at all.

"Underwhelmed" was a word used often in the movie-and for good reason! This is one of the most "underwhelming" movies I've ever seen. First, let me clarify-the acting wasn't all that bad. I blame the director, writers, and producers for this monstrosity. The actors were doing as they were told to do. The 2 stars is for their effort. The virtue signaling was so over the top it made me sick to my stomach. Or was it the over the top CGI?! Probably both. Yuck!

There are a lot of things that went wrong with this movie, I feel like this is an example of a movie that got caught up in the movie making politics that sometimes happens. The biggest problem was the writing, it was shallow and contrived.
The performances were fine, but with that kind of cheesy dialogue it wouldn't have mattered who was in the roles.
😴 Poor choice of actor having Oprah in it. She can't act. She can read lines.

I was so excited for this movie, having loved this whole series since I was a child. The way they altered this story for the movie is unforgivable. Yes, movies have to be condensed and altered slightly from books sometimes for time. But Harry Potter is proof that you CAN bring stories to life without sacrificing content. So much is different- sometimes small things that make no sense! Why is it Calvin's mother in the book, was changed to a father for this? No reason that makes any sense. Why were crucial scenes cut out? Why was the gender of the Happy Medium changed? 
I could go on and on. I've wasted money and a Sunday afternoon that I can't get back. If you love the book....skip this movie!

reviews.review_title: Worst movie to be released this year.
reviews.content: I don't know where to start with this. The acting is terrible, Especially from the child actors. The plot is dry and doesn't go anywhere. The entire movie feels like filler and nothing is explained to the audience. The characters were boring and acted like robots. This movie is terrible, most of the people in the cinema left early. I don't recommend this movie to anyone.
This is a boring, uninteresting, and poorly acted film which at times looks fine and doesn't have any charisma. The sequences drag, the dialogue Is flat. It was not good. Very disappointing!

I have seen all bad reviews for this movie but personally it's one of my favourite movies! It's a great concept that I haven't ever seen before and includes great imaginative ideas. I would 100% recommend this movie!
If u are a human don't. Watch the movie.waste of time.Disney's bad movie

reviews.review_title: I've never heard about this film
reviews.content: And it's trash lol. Only braindead people gave it 10 stars. Smh

reviews.review_title: Momentarily poignant and timely, but mostly just a glorified Disney ride
reviews.content: There was a moment in Wrinkle in Time when it showed darkness reaching the Earth and slowly engulfing it. It gave me chills. The movie suddenly felt extremely timely. It may have been talking about a popular girl struggling with an eating disorder and a great student being bullied by his father to do even better. But for me it looked like a perfect illustration of what has been happening in our world politically over the last couple of years. There were a few more poignant moments in the film. But, unfortunately, just moments. And there was just one character that felt alive - Charles Wallace. He made me cry real tears. Little Deric McCabe outacted a bunch of grownups, some of whom are Oscar winners. Reese Witherspoon, whom I loved in so many different roles, was just all Legally Blonde here. Poor Mindy Kahling was reduced to smiling and saying words that weren't even her character's own. Oprah was being Oprah - no more, no less. Chris Pine was stuck in a permanent state of angst. And Zack Galifianakis made an attempt to liven up his character, but was quickly subdued into a state of permanent soulfulness. It is so sad to see all these great performers acting as if they were making a photo shoot for the movie, not the movie itself. Or better yet - one of those fake rides they have at Universal Studios. In fact, much of the film felt as if they were already thinking about a ride as they were making it. My 9 year old liked it. Hopefully it will make him want to read the book. Then it will be worth it.
Really bad script. Extremely horrible acting. Casting was done for the sake for casting high profile people (i meant people not actors).

I just do not understand this movie like why did they call Charles Wallace by his full name. and why did that boy have to be in the story. I understand that the movie has to be "predictable" but at least let it make sense. Don't get me wrong I loved this movie it just doesn't make sense.

reviews.review_title: This movie isn't great for adults but would be great for kids I'm sure
reviews.content: I read this book a week before I watched the film and absolutely loved it, despite me being 19 years old and it being a book for children written in the 60s. So I expected to enjoy the film but I didn't really. I can see that most children (and probably me if I had watched it at about age 10) would love this film, but i would not recommend any adults watch this film unless you're watching it with your child. It's not like other Disney films that are timeless and you can watch them years after they came out as a 30 year old and you still love them. The dialogue and the plot are most certainly written for children, and as someone who is not a child it was sort of cringey and awkward to watch. It has a good overall message and theme that is really not subtle at all (hence why it's good for children), but just don't expect this to be the kind of Disney movie that anyone at any age can enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Dear Ava DuVernay and Jennifer Lee
reviews.content:
I admire the director and production team for the colorblind casting. I give this film 4 stars for the great cast. I only wish they had spent more time highlighting why the book was so good to begin with. They didn't have to put it all on Meg rescuing everyone. In the book it's a team effort out of love and friendship, so the parts of the book where they cut out the other characters sacrificing themselves or offering to sacrifice themselves for each other and the total unselfishness of characters like Calvin or Meg's father could have helped pack the emotional punch of this movie. Calvin had much more to do in the book, why cut that out? Giving him nothing to do didn't help develop why he is there to help Meg. He and Meg had growth in their character arcs in ths book. Why just show 1 scene of Calvin having problems with his father, why not develop that a bit more. Develop Charles Wallace being continuously teased or show a montage of it if you're short on time. I really really really hate they didn't have Aunt Beast in there, the ending was totally silly and half-cooked. And developing the three Missuses much more...maybe DuVernay should have picked the TV miniseries format with a longer running time with more room for character motivation and development and had a screenwriter writing more true to the spirit of the actual novel.
I truly admire the colorblindness the film tried to be, but it would have helped to have more meaty story on this film's bones and kept in more of the best things about the book than focusing on the CGI. Way too watered down for my tastes. Respect the audience! We are smarter than you think we are!

reviews.review_title: A fun journey through space and time.
reviews.content:
Now I'm gonna say, This is not a great movie, but at the same time it's not a bad movie either, It's very flawed in many ways and also very entertaining. Times it feels like The Wizard of Oz mixed with 2001: A Space Odyssey. This film is getting bad reviews on IMDB, and I understand if a lot of people don't like this movie, but I'm my opinion it was not that bad.
The effects are quite mesmerizing, feeling like your in another universe. Now the two teenage leads are watchable, are really believable in there roles. Now the kid who plays the little brother really got my nerves in some scenes. Oprah Winfrey is great in her role. Mindy Kaling is just alright, but Reese Witherspoon is just annoying in some scenes, playing like a worst version of Samantha from Bewitched, I like the way Oprah in the film called her on her annoyance. Chris Pine does alright of what he was giving.

This movie blew my mind, but not in a good way. I was left wondering on how everything was thrown at us. You had the story. It didn't make much sense at all. Okay, I understand that you have to go save the father, but there was no real character development. I believe that everything was rushed and didn't have any meaning. When you saw the children meet Oprah, Kaling, and Witherspoon on the other planet, this was in the trailer, that was the highlight of the movie. I thought it would have been visually stunning, but it lacked in that department too. This movie was pretty much Disney's Eragon. It failed miserably. If you want to see the best parts of the movie without seeing the movie, please just watch the trailer. I expected so much from Ava DuVernay in this movie, but was left wondering and confused. There are many different Disney movies coming up. I hope this isn't the year that Disney leads us on a misdirection based on what we come to expect and deserve.

I have not read the book, so I can not compare the two. I felt for such new actors (as I'd never seen the main characters before) they did much better than the trainwreck movies I have seen. I was kept entertained and, not quite on the edge of my seat because I'm not sure that was the point, but the storyline was lovable and the charcter development was shown very well.

reviews.review_title: This was a horrible movie for adults but a nice one for kids
reviews.content:
Ok so I gave a 2 as an average between my score, my husband's ( a negative 6) and my kids (an 8). My husband and I wanted to leave about halfway through the movie but my 11 & my 7 years olds truly enjoyed this piece of junk. 
As everyone already said the subject is poor, the actors play extremely bad and the production is terrible. I have not seen such a bad movie since The Tree of Life. 2 wasted hours!

reviews.review_title: It Has A Few Too Many "Wrinkles"
reviews.content: Children's books will never be easy to adapt for new generations. Not just because of generational gaps of the state of mind when it was written, but also the expectation of holding filmmakers to the standard that a book indirectly sets (even if it doesn't translate to film). While in recent years, Ava DuVernay has established herself directing impressive urban dramas (Selma, Middle of Nowhere) and finds herself stepping into the Disney fantasy land, and while young children can have fun in her world, adults may find a few more wrinkles than expected.The film follows Meg (Storm Reid) who is at a lost after dealing with the disappearance of her father (Chris Pine). Suddenly Meg's little brother discovers three witches who help Meg, her brother and a close friend try to discover why their father hasn't come home.Ava DuVernay is very much staging an ambitious world visually, and while it's interesting to view, it doesn't allow enough on the surface or even depth to understand how the "wrinkles" operate. While I'm okay with the idea of the children going into a world unlike their own, I found myself asking "what is anything and why doesn't it click like it should?" We are told many times on screen that Meg and her brother have great minds, but we never really get to see what makes them so brilliant like the film says they are. There's points when Meg's brother becomes the central focus and he goes from over his years to unexplainably odd and it becomes hard to digest on screen. And as for Oprah playing the witch, it just sounds like Oprah talking like Oprah. Take what you can from that.It's not all bad within the world though. There's enough colorful elements that I could see young children finding enjoyment in the fantasy world. The set pieces have some interesting ideas and surreal moments in visual repetition and ever changing geography.A Wrinkle in Time sadly has too many wrinkles to give it a recommendation, but I wouldn't tell people run away either. It has interesting ideas, but trouble connecting it altogether. Colorful, but maybe too intense to the eye. The heart and soul is very much seen in Ava's work, but I feel the heart wasn't in the right direction.Rating: 5.1 / 10

Fateful Findings is more coherent and it has more red herrings than characters and more dead plot lines than it's budget. This makes Justice League look like Under The Skin. If someone I knew told me they liked this movie I'd never talk to them again. It's not even funny bad. It's just bland and boring. There is nothing to make fun of.

reviews.review_title: You're Better Off With The Book
reviews.content: I grew up really loving "A Wrinkle in Time". It was my absolute favorite book. In fact, as I write this review right now, the same copy I was given as an 8 year old is on my desk, nice and familiar and reminding me of days long gone. When I heard they were adapting it to a big-budget film with Disney, I was mostly excited, with a few reservations. Here was the chance to see this great story communicated through a new media!However, I went to see the film and was sorely disappointed. To begin with, it didn't start on a dark and stormy night! One of the most iconic lines in literature, and they saved it for after a needless flashback that oversimplified and explained subtleties in the book.Aside from that, the first half was pretty decent. It mostly followed the book, and I liked the characters of Mrs Whatsit, Mrs Who, and Mrs Which. I wasn't expecting to like Mindy or Reese in their roles, but I feel they did a good job. And I did really like Oprah as Mrs Which, which I did have reservations about. I started to have a bad feeling when they landed on Uriel. When Mrs Whatsit shifted into her "other form", it looked like a depressing, CGI version of a piece of flying lettuce. Not at all like the majestic Mrs Whatsit on my cover! However, I tried to hold on nonetheless.While there were several little unsettling changes, it all started to veer quite far away from the book the moment they landed on Camazotz. Without going into terrible detail, let's just say that the filmmakers completely missed the point of what the book was originally trying to portray! Entire chapters were left out! Important character development was skipped! And all of Calvin's best scenes in the book were cut, making him some sort of useless tagalong!With all of their skipping, it ruined the original plot and many other good points. To its credit, however, it did have lovely visuals. The other worlds were very beautiful, and while Camazotz was completely inaccurate, it was gorgeous. I also didn't mind the majority of the casting, whether or not I'd agree with it. But, it just lacked the soul and subtlety of the original text.

Decided to watch this last night. Not sure which movie is worse between this one and The Last Jedi. But either way, both are made by Disney. Someone might want to start proof reading the scripts before they invest more than a couple of nickels on these terrible movies.

reviews.review_title: I'm watching with a look of perpetual disgust.
reviews.content: Everything is wrong. Mrs. Whatsit and her snarky commentary really got under my skin. Charles Wallace is annoying, and not in the too old for his years way from the book... I'm still watching at this moment but the look of disgust has not left my face. The only okay character is the dad. Even the mom misses the mark. Like when Mrs whatsit came over. She reacted wrong, she should have taken the visit in stride as if even if it wasn't normal, she'd patiently wait for understanding. And the whole dressed like a bag lady with the socks and galoshes... that was an iconic imagery that the white frilly pouf Reese wore didn't catch at all. And she is just bubbly in all the wrong ways. Oh and where were the twins? Sigh. All wrong.

A Wrinkle In Time is a Sci Fi Fantasy movie starring Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon,and Mindy Kaling along with Chris Pine and tells the story of a young girl named Meg played by Storm Reed who's father(Pine) goes missing so Meg meets 3 mysterious women (Kaling,Witherspoon and Winfrey) who whisk Meg and her friends to an alternative universe to find her dad.
The movie is like watching something if you are high as it's got a muddling plot and the charcthers are just boring.If u are a fan of Reese Witherspoon or Oprah Winfrey watch something else starring these two instead like Legally Blonde or The Princess and the frog.

Before I begin this review, I would just like to say that I don't know how I feel about this film, and I'm not sure I ever will, hence the 5/10 rating. Having read the original source material for A Wrinkle in Time, this is a strange goddamn adaptation, to say the very least. In my eyes, there are a few reasons for this.
