Firstly, some of the changes it has made to the original source material are baffling, while others actually make sense. For instance, "Red" (read: the Man with the Red Eyes, the physical mouthpiece of It (or, according to this film, the It. Why add the "the"?) in the original novel) looks like a poor man's Willy Wonka, but quantum entanglement being the mumbo-jumbo Meg's dad uses for tessering instead of a pure wormhole is indeed a well thought-out change. The flowers are a stupid addition (although not altogether pointless to the plot), but the change regarding what Mrs. Whatsit transforms into is rather good. All of what they did to Camazotz did my head in as to whether I liked it or not, including the stairwell sequence, which to me might have well been conceived of on
Secondly, it is obvious that the message of this film was tweaked a bit to have a bit of commentary regarding womens' body images and how it affects them, as well as empowerment of women, and I am certain there are cries of "SJW-ism" and what not in this review section. A film like this attracts those sort of unpleasant reviews like honey does flies. I personally don't know how I feel about it. Ask me Tuesday whether it was garbage and you won't get the same answer Wednesday. I don't even know if I care.
Thirdly, while the performances of the three immortal girls aren't too shabby, the rest of the cast is hit or miss. Storm Reid is alright, but she doesn't get as many lines to work with as I was expecting, oddly enough, being the protagonist and all. Calvin's actor's performance is as interesting as watching a sundial's shadow move. Charles Wallace's actor, Boognish bless him, is trying incredibly hard to nail his character, but falls way short, sadly. Shame, too, as he probably would have been better with better direction.
To summarize, I do not know if I recommend this film. Ask Schrodinger's cat instead.

I usually never write reviews on here but this movie was SO bad I felt the need to warn people. If I could get negative, it'd be -100. Horrible acting, horrible CGI, horrible screenwriters, horrible direction, and I could go on. I honestly rather watch the made for TV version. Flying lettuce scene was ridiculous, even my husband started cracking jokes. Disney really messed it up this time. They need to burn all copies of this movie and pretend it never happened. I know I wish I could un-see it.

I read A Wrinkle in TIme as a child, nearly fifty years ago. I have to admit that I don't remember much about the details of the story or the characters, but even with that, there was a lot left out. This is the story that taught me what dimensions are and what properties constitute each one. As I became an illustrator/ 3-D animator, this is a pretty big deal - and they completely left it out of the movie; they didn't even try to delve into the science.
What this ended up looking like was some type of anti-bullying message-movie (and isn't that all the rage these days?) I rarely watch a movie based on a book before reading the book. In this instance, I feel compelled to go back to the book and rereading it to see how badly the movie got it wrong.

The plot is slow to start and then jumps all over the place, however you will be assured of the predictable ending.some of acting was ok, but the boys performance was painful and there were times I couldn't understand what he was saying. The script is very cheesy and nauseating at times.I'm a fan of Disney and what they can pull off when they get it right, it's a real shame they got this one so wrong.

reviews.review_title: Great book, too bad this movie does not resemble it
reviews.content:
Unbelievably poor attempt to bring an old favorite book to the screen. Maybe if they had actually tried to follow the book instead of ... whatever this was.
so extremely bad I could not finish it, just too disappointing for words

I admit, I went into this movie expecting this disappointment of Pete's Dragon, especially after seeing a few reviews giving it a less than stellar number of stars. However, upon leaving the theater, I felt the same lightness and joy I experienced watching Wonder. The film had a deep heart, displaying the power of love and the worth of humans-- and that we can deserve love for being ourselves, rather than constantly striving for approval.A Wrinkle in Time featured charming actors, with Storm Reid stealing the scenes as the persnickety, precocious Meg Murry. Deric McCabe is perfectly cast as the impercetable and brilliant Charles Wallace, while Levi Miller's kind Calvin consistently offers the support Meg needs to save the day. The Mrs.'s, played by Oprah Winfrey, Mindy Kaling, and Reese Witherspoon, are dazzling, beautiful, wise, brave, and unknowable as they guide the children on first a search and then a rescue mission, giving the children the courage and tools to fight the darkness. I read this book in 5th grade and despised the slow classroom pace and the drying of the novel's appeal with homework and questions. As an English teacher, I revisited the book this past Christmas and quickly devoured others in the series, captivated by the flawed, clever fighter who is Meg Murry. I found permission to be a smart, capable woman as well as permission to live with flaws and not constantly try to cover them up in shame. I found a deeper appreciation for the people around me and a desire to reach out and make the world a better place. While a two hour movie does not allow for the depth of development we find in books, this film adaption does good job of opening many of those doors for viewers. Ryan Coogler's praise for director Ava DuVernay is well earned with a fantastic, diverse cast, beautiful scenery, and spot on emotional appeals. This film will inspire people to love themselves and spread joy, it will inspire viewers to find a solution other than violence, inspire girls to be scientists and dreamers, and inspire us all to look for the wonder just beyond our view.

What a boring adaptation of a well written book. The trailers before the movie were more entertaining and at least they ended after 10 minutes. The movie goes on and on and on and on and on while going nowhere.

reviews.review_title: A hollow adaptation with flashy visuals and nothing else.
reviews.content: While plenty of children's books are imaginative, no amount of CGI can cover up the fact that a faithful adaptation to the source material should be the highest priority. Unfortunately, due to the heavy Christian undertones in the original story, an anti-Christian Hollywood managed to churn out this loose adaptation of A Wrinkle in Time that doesn't do much more than waste a few hours of your time. Sure, there are hints to such important ideas as faith, but they're lost in lackluster character development that tries to "modernize" something that has been timeless for decades.Each of the sequences in this film merely seems like an excuse for gorgeous set design. If anything, the alien worlds and settings are neat to look at, but they don't do much to distract from the events that just happen without much explanation as to why, or what purpose they serve. For instance, the scene with the identical houses and families all acting in synchronicity (one of the scenes from the trailer) is visited and exited in a matter of moments, and there was no point or moral lesson to teach there. It just was. Then it was not.Perhaps the most frustrating part of the film was the main characters. When Meg (Storm Reid) was describing all her faults, I had to stop and think: did the movie show us these faults? Some of them were accurate, but most didn't seem to be obvious character flaws that she was trying to overcome, or at least not ones that were presented earlier in the film. Consequently, all the characters felt as flat as a visit to a 2-dimensional world (which, ironically enough, was a scene from the book that didn't make it into the movie).A hollow adaptation with flashy visuals and nothing else, I give A Wrinkle in Time 2.0 stars out of 5.

So A Wrinkle In Time is the exact same schmaltzy product Disney has been conjuring up for a while now. It's getting on my nerves and I'm hoping they can redeem themselves within the coming weeks.The first act is great, the second act sucks, the third act is even worse.Also this isn't really a sin on the movie but I have to talk about Charles Wallace. Deric McCabe isn't a very good actor and he slugs through the scene where Charles Wallace turns into a baddie.Because of the first act's greatness, I'll give a Wrinkle in Time a C- or on an IMDb scale, a 5/10

reviews.review_title: Most of humanity is not ready.
reviews.content: There's too much negativity and fast paced life for this movie to make sense, in ten years it will be understood.

reviews.review_title: Full of mistakes and one-dimensional charakters
reviews.content: Wow, that movie was so bad... it's a complete waste of time. It's full of logical mistakes, bad scripted charakters, bad acting and has an absolutly incoherent story line. It feels like this movie is missing about an hour of its story line. I feel so bad for the talented cast. But I loved Reese Witherspoon. She was a bright spot in this movie. I don't know why the film needed the character of "Calvin". He have zero (really!) influence on the story. He's just eye candy for 13-years old girls and looks like a puppy in every scene. Without him there wouldn't be any changes in the movie... a complete senseless character. The visual effects were (partly) awesome. I give it a 3/10 for visual effects, the music and Reese Witherspoon.

I think there were some misfires when it came to the overall message but when I watch it with a kid's eye rather than an adult one it's SO FUN. It's inspiring, good pacing, and the female lead is great. Kid me would give it 10 out of 10 and beg her parents to buy it when it came out on home video. She would dress up as one of the missuses for Halloween and invite friends over to watch the movie.
When I watch it with an adult's eye (and an adult who has read all the books and loves a wrinkle in time with a passion) I see a lot of flaws. CGI aside, and understanding that adaptations *have* to be different than the book, there is one MAJOR mistake (no spoilers but it has to do with the IT) and a number of more minor missteps. There are mild pacing issues and some characterization is just too too different from the source material (poor Calvin). Adult me would likely rate it a 2 or 3 out of 10. 
Therefore I decided to let my rating reflect my ambivalence. 5 out of 10 may not split the difference entirely between my two rating extremes, but I think it conveys how much I keep waffling over it.
The movie may have tried so hard to be politically relevant. It feels like the writer have googled "Inspirational quotes" and inserted all 10 page results to the script. Very disappointing.

A Wrinkle in Time is one of my all time favorite books and the series is wonderful. When I heard this was being re-made, I was so excited. This movie was so disappointing. The creative liberty taken in the story-telling stole all that was magical and beautiful about the book.If it hadn't been a representative of one of the best children's science fiction stories ever written, it would have been a better film.

reviews.review_title: By the time we got to IT I was just waiting for IT to end.
reviews.content: REVIEW - A WRINKLE IN TIME With all of the hype surrounding this film I thought I'd better watch it and that I have. In essence this is the feel good film of the year so far. The simple message running throughout the film of acceptance, accept the faults of others and the faults within yourself, accept others and accept yourself but.......While watching this film I couldn't help but think of the various troubles plaguing the USA at the moment, which I think this film in its way is trying to address by educating the young to be more tolerant and accepting of others. I do applaud this but there is so much........Whilst certainly a film the kids may love for me personally it felt too lovey dovey with cherries on top and apple pie with cream on the side, no meat to the story and honestly I just didn't care what happened to who. By the time we got to IT I was just waiting for IT to end. This is a children's film so please remember the above is an adults point of view. Rating 5 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Oh look, a pretty set piece. We'll get to the plot later.
reviews.content: This movie just seemed... distracted. That's the only word I can think of to describe it. The movie tries to grab your attention with pretty backdrops and marvelous CG but the plot takes a bit of a back seat. Oprah deserves better! The movie tries to bank on nostalgia for the books alone and the fact that it has a diverse cast. The male lead, who is way more important in the books seemed unnecessary this time round. He seemed shoehorned in. That's a sign of lazy writing. Like a sign that the screenwriters don't expect much from the white audience. They seem to think that the already okay cast can't hold out interest. This movie is trash! Pretty, computer generated trash!

reviews.review_title: Can they create a time machine that takes me back to before watching and erases my memory and refunds me?
reviews.content: Disappointing is probably an understatement. I ignored the bad reviews and went anyway. I HIGHLY recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys flying lettuce, terrible acting, giant Oprah in a mermaid costume, or awful confusing plots with terrible direction. Disney - as someone who had to sit through this film I respectfully request that you use your Marvel money to build a time machine and give 2 hours back to any audience forced to see this abomination.The most fascinating parts of the book were eliminated, or only presented so quickly that it was difficult to understand why they were happening and how they related to the story. This movie could have been SO great - there was incredible potential here, and Disney and the director literally wasted it all.

Thank god I didn't have to pay to see this film. It was just wrong from every possible angle. Story, cinematography, directing, acting, all were a mess. It was harder to sit through this than mortal engines.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful mess, but a mess nonetheless
reviews.content: Having recently re-read this book with my family (in anticipation of the film), I can tell you that L'Engle's classic is fondly remembered but hardly perfect. This film managed to channel some of the best parts of the book - a unique protagonist, an imaginative and beautiful universe, some fun science connections. That said, it also channeled (and magnified) all the messiness too. A somewhat garbled plot became completely disjointed. The 3 mrs. characters just plain never worked, spending every moment either explaining things or making stale jokes. An ominous evil force became laughably cliche fairly quickly. And most importantly, every single theme was beaten like a dead horse. It felt like a very special episode of "A Wrinkle in Time." I love DuVernay's ambition, but I had hoped for better than the most expensive and well-done after school special of all time. Sadly, that's what this was. I will now go live my best life.

reviews.review_title: I'd like to tesser away from this movie!
reviews.content: This movie is incredibly slow and pretty confusing, and I've read the book! And even with its length, it leaves so much to be desired! They even cut out a classic part of the ball bouncing scene, yet left so much filler in other scenes! Yeesh. I will say, the Mrs.'s were gorgeous, great costumes and make up! They are the only bright spot in a dark, boring film.

reviews.review_title: Seriously?! It is not that hard!
reviews.content: I read the book three years ago. I was in 6th grade. I just barely understood it but in retrospect I actually liked it a lot. Enough to try to rip it off! Said rip-off remains unfinished, unpublished and partially lost and that is probably for the best. The 2003 adaptation of the Wrinkle in Time novel was really good and stayed mostly faithful to the book. And when I first saw advertisements for this adaptation I was really excited. I like all kinds of movies and usually when something comes out that everyone hates, I am one of the few people who would like it. With a couple of movies it was the other way around but that is to be covered in other upcoming reviews (specifically for Cloverfield and the 1996 Romeo and Juliet adaptation). I have yet to write more reviews that reflect my cinematic taste but bottom line it takes a lot for me to dislike a movie.So the fact I am giving this movie a 3 star rating is saying something.I saw this a few days after opening day. 3.8 stars right away? It cannot be THAT bad, I thought. So my stepdad took me to see it. For the rest of the week I could not stop talking about how bad it was. The good visuals, casting, intentions, and beginning do not at all make up for its shameless differences from the book. I am not a big reader but when I see an adaptation of a book I have read, I get annoyed if it is an unfaithful adaptation. This movie is nothing like the book. The book was strange, unique and indescribably beautiful. This was a very modern and watered-down adaptation that almost insults Madeline L'Engle. The 2003 adaptation did change how certain things happened, but the plot remained the same. This adaptation, however, overthinks the adaptation concept by changing the plot.Adaptations are not that hard to make! I mean, I understand that scenes from the source material must be cut out or hastened to keep it from getting to long (this would probably be a 3-4 hour movie if they did not cut at least some parts out) but changing the parts you keep is just annoying and unnecessary. Entire characters cut out or heavily altered. Important plot points were made nothing like the book. If you have not seen this movie, I will warn you are not missing out. I fully agree with the other negative reviews of this movie.Oh and one more thing. In the book Meg has two brothers named Sandy and Dennys. They contributed nothing to the plot so it makes sense that they were cut out. However, the book has about 7 sequels and the third sequel, Many Waters, REVOLVES around Sandy and Dennys. With that, Disney would run into some very serious problems if they decide to make a Many Waters adaptation. But given this film's negative reception, it probably was not going to happen anyway. Bottom line, I recommend the book as much as I do NOT recommend this movie.

I love Disney and could not believe the Imdb score. But I went to AMC and understood. The movie is nor for parents, nor for kids. Sometimes I felt like I was watching a psycho movie, sometimes I got to beautiful pandora-like sceneries, sometimes there was something wise said, sometimes it was silly stupid, sometimes it was horror like, sometimes it was narnia like, once or twice I laughed... But for 5-10 good minutes it was not worth it :( This budget and cast could be used for much better project with much better message to audience.
The whole film felt rushed. There was no character development and not enough time to get emotionally connected to the characters. Visually it was very pretty. Disappointed in Disney.

reviews.review_title: Not completely awful, but could've been so much better
reviews.content: Disney's A Wrinkle in Time had great potential. Great actors were cast, and don't get me wrong, they brought their talent to this film, but it wasn't enough to save it. This film needed a better script, and a more exciting/engaging execution. I'll go into what they did wrong in my view. Ok so I've already stated that does a pretty good job, and they do overall. I like Winfrey, Witherspoon, and Kaling in their roles, and Reid and Pine were good as well. But other than that and the effects, the film falls pretty flat. The only moments where I felt truly engaged was when they were exploring the new dazzling lands. Everything was uneven, it wasn't consistent. The enjoyable parts come far and few in between. For an adventure film, it was kinda dull. I would've liked more adventure and more engaging moments. I felt like the characters deserved a better script.The film tried and I can see that, and I really love the diversity shown in the film, that's a beautiful thing. I think the problem was that DuVernay focused so much on that, that she neglected her job of making a great film. If you wanna have diversity shown and represented in a film, make it a great film, otherwise it's almost insulting.

I have seen the movie before this and I don't know why it is so hard to make these into films. Wrinkle in time (2018) is basically a mess of a film with bad acting, one dimensional characters, and just forgettable. Which is the complete opposite of the book. But I do like the visuals so that does bring it up some and the film doesn't keep me bored.

The actual hard bound book is (for me) a lot of better than the movie.
I am glad that I've read the book first

reviews.review_title: Not a Time Sci Fi but more about self discovery
reviews.content: Didn't go into this with high expectations especially considering the other reviews.But I did enjoy this. Was a little corny in places. With that being said. The moral of the story was excellent.Without spoiling in Meg learns to love again and she brings her dad home again.

This movie veers so much from the novel that it's barely recognizable. There was also not one Christian reference throughout the movie. I'm not sure how that's okay for a movie based on a Christian book. Other than that the movie felt boring at times and lacked the heart and soul it should have had. Charles Wallace was not convincing as the gifted brainiac that he was in the book and Calvin's character was just corny. I could go on and on.

This movie is horrible even if you hadn't read the book. Literally 95% is just fantasy, completely unrelated to the original story.But not only that, but nearly every aspect is bad: the dialogue, cinematography, direction, writing, acting. It actually made me angry that it was so bad and they ruined such a good story so abhorrently.

reviews.review_title: Vividly colorful, great imagery -- but that's about it.
reviews.content: I'd kind of like to rate this higher than 5/10, given that it's based on a beloved classic YA novel by Madeleine L'Engle, but the problem is that even though there are lots of interesting details, the parts don't add up to a coherent whole. Looking at the overall IMdB ratings more closely, I see that women voters rate it a full point higher than men do, but even for them the median is 5/10 even after you cut out the trolls who rate anything they see as 1/10.The level this movie seems aimed at, given the simplistic nature of the dialog, seems to be pre-teen, not YA. But the intense, vivid nature of the visuals is such that it might well give nightmares to kids under about 6 -- there are a few quite intense and scary scenes concerning The It (who is, essentially, Satan). There are many good actors in the cast, but they don't have a lot to work with, and the three magic Mrs. (Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling) are kind of wasted, as is Chris Pine. However, two characters I liked were Storm Reid as the young heroine Meg, and Gugu Mbatha-Raw as her mother. They come across well.There's so much here that doesn't make sense even at a first look. The three kids (Meg, Calvin, Charles Wallace) are strictly told by the three "Mrs." to STAY TOGETHER as they set off on their adventure into mystical lands. What's the first thing they do? You guessed it. Why can't Happy Medium (an entertaining Zach Gallifianakis) say more than a few cryptic hints? Why for that matter can't anyone be more specific? And I actually worry about Meg's situation at school. She's a bullied outcast because her father disappeared and she's fallen into deep depression. Kids who are bullied by mean girls at school shouldn't expect their problems to be solved by three demigods who suddenly appear and whisk them off into the cosmos. They need more than just sympathy: they need to know what to *do* about their problem. This movie doesn't, in the end, give much guidance.

reviews.review_title: Please dont waste your precious time.
reviews.content: If you liked the book please don't watch this movie. One of the worst movies of the year. The story is not translated from the book properly and makes very little sense. It is so simplified that it lacks any coherence and just drags. Acting overall is abysmal and most of the characters come off as annoying. There are some severe miscasts here as well. Oprah, Zach G, Witherspoon are horrible. Avoid at all costs!

If I was a kid maybe I would like this. But I'm not, so, this fell somewhere between painful and excruciating for me. A lot of kids movies these days try to gear towards adults as well, so, I thought I might enjoy it given the amount of stars in the film, and the remake of Annie could have been painful but I ended up loving it and have seen it 3 times since it's a favorite of my nieces and nephews. I've happily sat through Moana multiple times, even downloaded some songs. Frozen...I can sit through that, but not one of my faves. So, I like kids films. But this was one of the worst films I've seen in awhile. Which is too bad 'cause I remember loving the book as a kid...although I can't say I really remember the book other than there was that flying centaur guy on the cover of the book, so my dislike of the film isn't from sentiment. It's just a bad movie. The positives, which are few, are the women in the film. They all did a great job. It's hard not to like Reese, Mindy and Oprah. And GuGu did a great job even though she wasn't in the film much, which was too bad. Chris Pine is highly likable but I had a hard time believing he's this genius physicist. He has pretty and likable going for him but he doesn't look smarter than a 5th grade science teacher. Although, you could make GuGu the queen of England and I'd probably say it's believable so that's either a credit to her or my fondness of her is clouding my judgement. Other than them the casting was either terrible or not good...with the exception of the kid who played Clint, he was pretty good. The rest of the kids and the teachers, with the exception of one teacher, seemed like they came straight out of John Casablancas or some terrible casting office.It was pretty clear the director had never worked with visual effects, didn't understand them, ran out of money, or all of the above. The first shot you see of the fantasy world looked like New Zealand with a hue adjustment overlay that flattened the whole picture and they didn't bother to cut and separate the pieces into individual mattes. Which makes me think the director blew the money. No one does that. Usually there are painted mattes overlaying a real scene or the whole thing is various mattes, more typically. There were some crappy looking flower mattes over the hue color change. Matte cutting is VFX 101 and even your cheap, straight to video stuff has it. The scene still would have looked surprisingly low budget for a film with all these big stars but I was surprised by how amateur it was. I did some VFX assistant work at Disney and I could have tackled it, which is how basic it was.Some of the scenes were somewhat cool but it was all kind of cheap looking. Reminded me of the low-budget kids films of the '80s. The effects weren't as bad as them, but were compared to what's out there now. I also started to think the director, aside from having no VFX experience also had no fantasy/Sci-fi experience when Reese turned into a giant piece of lettuce and flew the kids around like Falcor the dragon. Which, I guess I wasn't that surprised when the villain, The It, turned out to be just like The Nothing from The Neverending Story.Another thing that made me think the directory ran out of money is how few scenes there are in the real world. School. The house. An alley. That's about it. It happened on the movie Dungeons & Dragons. The guy who owned the rights to the title convinced a producer to give him 35 million. He had zero film experience and the director blew all his money early on on effects 'cause he didn't understand how the process of getting them made works, which is why they usually give these type films to VFX specialists or animators to direct, or to film makers who have a lot of experience with VFX-heavy TV like Game of Thrones.When I looked up who the director was I was surprised but not surprised. Surprised they would give this budget and type of film to someone who's experience is low-budget drama. It said Selma was a 20 million budget but I find that hard to believe. A Quiet Place was 15 and that had aliens and a lot more going on than a film where most of it was MLK Jr. talking around a table or on the phone. Which, again makes me think the director has a budget problem 'cause I can't imagine Selma costing more than 10 million. There's no stars other than a few tiny scenes with Oprah, and even the period piece stuff wasn't enough to put a major dent in a budget.Pretty much the whole film is the characters meandering from one place to the next. There wasn't much of a cohesive plot, other than her father is missing and they're trying to find him. They just did aimless things like have the lettuce creature fly around for no reason, then they suddenly decide they're going to go to see some dude who lives in a cave...why? Not sure. He just said a bunch of meaningless hippie stuff, like, follow your heart or something. That's kind of all that was said to get the girl to where she was going. So, not sure how she even found her father. They just decided at one point she would by wandering around aimlessly with no one actually giving her any guidance. Just great advice like, "I give you your flaws." Literally that's how she defeated the bad guy. Which, didn't really make sense. She defeated the bad guy by saying she loved him. Lame, and not sure how that's a flaw. The girl also uses fuzzy physics to accomplish things, meaning, not real physics. Like, why in the world would they make that part of the plot? It seemed ridiculous that this young girl would grasp complex physics and in reality she didn't, so, not sure how that went unnoticed. I suppose because film people aren't up on their physics but seems like they should have at least asked someone...like from Cal Tech, the school 15 minutes from Disney that is the MIT of the west. Also, why was her father trapped in a box? Why didn't he leave? There were doors on both sides of the box. And why would the father suggest leaving the son? No father would be like, "Hey, this is hard, let's bail and leave the child I never knew." Also, the finale was surprisingly scary for kids. The little girl behind us was crying. Again, I don't think the director understood horror elements and age appropriateness. I've seen a ton of kids movies and this is the only one I've been concerned I was going to get in trouble for taking my niece and nephew to, in case they got nightmares.It's a shame. 100 million is a lot of money to hand over to a director whose experience is a low-budget movie and documentaries. Not sure how that happened. They should have given it to the director of Girls Trip. Not the same type of film, but GT was really well done, had a decent budget, big stars. I understand wanting to give opportunities but the process is typically working your way up, not giving someone more than they can handle, thus endangering the livelihood of others when the film tanks. Obviously, this won't tank Disney, but this is why studios try to be as risk-free as possible, 'cause a 100 million flop, plus marketing costs which sometimes are equal to the film, can shutter the doors of a studio. Oh well. It was good to see Gugu. Hopefully this will open more doors for her even if the film wasn't great.

For Disney's next trick, they will produce a Lord of the Rings movie, with no Hobbits, and no ring.
Lets get this straight.... A Christian author, writes a book with a Christian theme, pretty straight forward. Remove all elements of Christianity and essentially gut the entire story.
Based on the popularity of faith based family friendly movies, it would seem a no-brainer to keep the intentions of the author in tact.Sad and disappointing.

I love this movie so much. At first going into it I was afraid it wouldn't live up to my high expectations, but it did more than live up to them, it surpassed them. Not only does it support feminism and race equality, it also gives an important lesson of believing in yourself and embracing your flaws without sounding preachy. So to sum it up, A Wrinkle In Time Is a great family movie with beautiful visual effects and truly frightening, heartbreaking, and heartwarming scenes. 
So ignore those internet trolls that are giving it 1 and 2 star reviews and go see it as soon as you can.

Created in 1962 by American Sci-Fi author Madeleine L'Engle, A Wrinkle in Time has gained momentum since the early 60s, which spawned 2 movie releases - one in 2003 and the second most recently in 2018. Coming from the Oprah Winfrey Book Club, A Wrinkle in Time tells the story of a young girl who has lost everything in her life - including her missing father. 
 Directed by Ava DuVernay, and leading an all-star cast from Ms. O, herself, Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling and Chris Pine - this movie defies all gravity at all odds of the spectrum. Telling the story, the way they knew how to, newcomer Storm Reid who plays Meg in the movie, finds herself as she journeys into a world that is strange and very peculiar. 
 I loved this movie and I must give props where props are due to the cast, crew and Ms. DuVernay, they did an incredible job on a book that I have never read or even heard of for that matter. The lyrics to the title track sums up this movie very beautifully, just read these words: "They hear you when you cry. This love is far and wide. When you smile the stars align. Flower of the universe, and child of mine." - Flower of the Universe by Sade

reviews.review_title: Try as I might I just didn't like it!!
reviews.content: I thought I'd give it a whirl and what a mistake. I haven't read the book but the film could have been so much more even for the little kids watching it. I found the live interest between the two children to be a bit of a turn off. So much potential wasted in this film as it could have been a great film but alas they dropped the ball big time on this one.
Boring, boring, boring. The best thing about this movie was when it was over.

Boooo hisss... can't think of anything good to say about this catastrophe, it seemed like it would be interesting but it's just plain stupid. More unreal than unreal can be. Wrinkles of time I will never get back!

reviews.review_title: it's a good thing i forgot the book.
reviews.content: I read 'a wrinkle in time' in 4th grade and it was my favorite. thankfully now as a 32 year old I have forgotten a lot, which according to the reviews, is helpful for enjoying the movie. I do remember the book being dark, so I was nervous when ava said it was a movie for children. THAT BOOK IS NOT FOR CHILDREN. (it is, but it's not. you know what I mean) I was very upset with some of the changes, not because i'm racist, but because SOMEBODY in the Murry family had to have the genius Murry genes passed on. in the book, that was Charles Wallace, but in the movie, he's adopted, so how do you explain his genius? it logistically makes no sense. there's also subplots I wont spoil that could have been put to better use STICKING CLOSER TO THE BOOK. I admit it, i'm a book purist. I go to a film to see the author's vision, not the director's. thankfully, this started to happen the 2nd half of the film. the movie got more faithful (and darker) halfway through. it's a beautiful movie and i'm glad I saw it in 3d, so that plus a great cast is why I give it a 6, but I don't need to tell you this movie is mostly a screw up.

I like some of the big hitting actors in that but there is no substance. Effects are nice but story is utter nonsense and full of cliches. It's the type of thing you would see as a 5 minute film before getting on a ride at Disney world.
Wow! Bad movie. Terrible Direction. Where did all the money go?

reviews.review_title: This flick is a lot "thinner" than I thought it would be . . .
reviews.content: . . . especially compared to a STAR WARS movie, or the BLACK PANTHER film. A WRINKLE IN TIME contained way too many static scenes showing nearly nothing on the screen, as the characters waxed philosophical with seemingly endless Yakkity-Yakking. Even the recent feature MONSTER TRUCKS contained more consistent action, and came off as much better plotted. Considering that the source material for A WRINKLE IN TIME is alleged to be a children's classic science fiction novel, as well as the fact that this movie was promoted as having an A-List cast, most theater goers surely bought tickets with the expectation that they would be blessed with something more stunning, provocative, and "snore-proof" than just something at the level of another NINJA TURTLE offering. But rather than spending the pages necessary to pick apart the plot, performances, dialog, and effects of A WRINKLE IN TIME, perhaps it would be more constructive to focus on the ONE good thing about this exercise in how NOT to win friends, or influence people. That would be the portion of the movie in which--thanks to the Miracle of CGI--America's favorite traffic cop Sasser turns into a flying head of lettuce (though it would be nicer if we'd see more of her as she changes).
The storyline is loosely adapted at best, and very choppy. No character development. The special effects were meaningless. I was shaking my head for most of it.

This movie is rated PG. It is chaste, exciting, magical, curious, whimsical, visually exceptional, emotional, sentimental, and occasionally terrifying.What I enjoyed most was the respectful and often matter of fact focus on the children and adolescents around whom the story revolves. They are brave, intelligent, resolute, and at times goofy or even cruel.The three main characters find themselves in an intergalactic search for a missing father helped along by three very different but benign witches. Acting by all participants is solid. Storm Reid as the main character inhabits her role with just the right mix of seriousness, charm, and intelligence. The mix of music is also perfect with well-chosen songs throughout.200w_d.gif
My only real complaint about the movie is its length. It's packed with events and visual splendor but is too short. At times I wanted things to just slow down a bit and explore all the characters more. Maybe that's because I've never read the book. Perhaps children seeing the movie will be less patient than I.You must try to experience the movie from the perspective of a child or an adolescent. The emotions displayed in the film are at times very raw and on the surface: love, regret, fear, doubt, jealousy, anger -- they're all here and viewed from a young perspective.It's a heady emotional mix that occasionally butts heads with the plentiful visual splendors on display. That's quite a directorial accomplishment, in my opinion.Some younger children may find some of the sequences too scary or even nightmarish. But on balance this is a very solid film.The Disney organization should be proud that it has made an investment in such a film. What's also significant is that the film's multi-cultural and multi-racial nature will be unnoticed by many if not most of the young people who see it.

reviews.review_title: Is the It in charge of IMDB now?
reviews.content: I truly do not understand the hate for this film. As a lifelong fan of the series, I was looking forward to the movie. It captured many of the big themes and small scenes, left out some things I think were important, but in no way deserves such a low rating on IMDB. Unfortunately, Calvin's character was pretty much gutted from the mathematical genius who has to hide his brilliance to remain a popular kid. I was sad that the rescue of CW was gutted as well. The decision to go back after being safe is what love is really all about.I will say that I was in a theatre full of children on Saturday and they were quiet and invested in the film. There were a few scenes that really touched me as well. Take your kids to a GREAT film about love and family and adventure and ignore all of this darkness.
The name should not be a wrinkle in time, it should be a frickin waste of time.

reviews.review_title: I want a wrinkle in time!
reviews.content:
Can I use a wrinkle in time, space, or in the black vacuüm of a black hole so i can go back to a time where i haven't watched 65 minutes of this wretched nightmare. And warn myself. Warn me not to do it, not to watch it. And instead watch Barb Wire with Pamela Anderson because that is a gem compared to this piece of baby talk. 
I wish i was home in my kitchen so i can sit on a knife with my face because my eyes don't function no more.
A Perfect example that special effects can not always save a movie.

reviews.review_title: A wrinkle in tie cause it's a waste of it.
reviews.content: I had heard bad things about this movie but I always had hope there could be some Disney magic and good entertainment. There's none of it.

reviews.review_title: Worthy watching movie!!! I don't understand why people are criticizing this movie!!
reviews.content:
First of all, the concept of this movie is very unique. It is not like any fantasy movie. It shows to you the universe and nature in a different!!
The first part of the movie might be boring but afterwards the movie guides you to a whole new world filled with extraordinary things.MY advice is that ignore the bad ratings and go watch the movie you and your kids will love it!!

reviews.review_title: Lots going on at once, but not a bad film.
reviews.content: With a lot of low reviews you expect the film to be awful, but every film these days seems to have that trend, and you can't go in with what others think of it. It overwhelmed me a bit at the beginning as it felt like there was a lot going on, and everything was bright/intense. But eventually it grew on me and I came to like it. Young Deric who played Charles Wallace is an incredibly actor, full of potential, same with the actress playing Meg. Also the soundtrack was a stand-out for me.

reviews.review_title: Most Confusing Two Hours Of My Life
reviews.content: Being a big fan of Disney, I entered this movie with high hopes and expectations. I mean come on, they have some of Hollywood's biggest names staring in it! Well let me tell you that that only left me even more disappointed.From the start of the movie they used some very unrealistic situations, which left the audience feeling more disconnected to the characters than we should have. Along with some horrible character development, I overall disliked about every character in the whole movie. The main character, Meg, was unlikable, emotionless for most of the movie, and a major bore. She did not make for a fantastic heroine. Calvin honestly did not add a single thing to the movie at all. They could have left his character out entirely and the story would not have been effected. The little brother was SOMETIMES cute but mostly just annoying. All of the actors, even the very well known ones were preformed atrociously. How is that even possible?? Every line felt lifeless and forced. I'm a crier but there wasn't a single heartwarming/emotional scene in the whole movie. The whole performance was awfully dry.The costumes were, well cool I guess if you like vegetables and have horrendous sense of style. I personally hated everything about them. The colors of the background were way too vibrant and there was an overwhelming amount CGI. It gave me a major live action Alice and Wonderland vibe, which I really disliked.There were too many plot holes left and I was continuously confused throughout the entire movie. Now it's not unusual for a movie to not explain everything so that it builds the viewers curiosity, but in those movies they normally end up answering your questions. In THIS movie, not only do they not explain what's going on and why, but they continue to pile on more and more plot which just made me more confused.The ending seem way to easy, almost as if there was no challenge for the characters. Now I'm going to be honest and say that I have never read the book, so maybe the movie made more sense to those who read it, but after watching A Wrinkle in Time, I really don't want to read the book.Overall, I would NOT recommend this movie to even your worst enemy. I would recommend showing it in prisons as a punishment but that itself is way too inhumane.

This is one of the few books that I can remember from my early childhood, as it is very memorable and very good. 
Sadly the movie does not live up to the book. 
Just scene by scene it looks terrible, the cast is terrible, Oprah is a joke. 
I don't understand that with so many people working on a movie someone can't point out that everything about it is rubbish and change it before it is released.
I'm happy they tried to make it, but that's about it.
Worst acting ever.. lucky it got a 1 I wanted to give it a zero

Once again, Oprah's ego takes over. God forbid somebody else gets some screen time. This movie was terrible. It was corny, boring trash. Thanks for the PC mixed race marriage also. How progressive.🙄 I hope this film failed.

This movie was so worth watching! my only regret is not sending this sooner and seeing it alone! i will be sure to support this film
some more while it's still in cinemas!!

reviews.review_title: The film isn't that good, but the special effects still work.
reviews.content: I really had high hopes for this one. The poster gave me some kind of thoughts that this one would turned out great somehow. But sadly, it didn't that much. The main characters are basically fine and visual effects and all. But what I really hate is the name of that so-called the darkness. The IT? Really? The writer couldn't think of a better name than this?The other thing I don't like that much is how Meg defeated the darkness inside Charles Wallace. It's so simple. I really hoped that there would be more than that. When I saw that scene, when I saw Meg defeated the darkness and everything's ended, I even said "Is that it? That's all?" from my mouth out loud. Quite disappointed.All in all, for a film produced by Disney, it shouldn't be that bad. Although it isn't that much perfect, it's still watchable because of the special effects. If they could do better than this, it's be great!

reviews.review_title: Don't miss reading the book! Skip the movie.
reviews.content: I read the book with my 8 year old son for him to experience an exciting Newberry Award winning classic work of literature....he LOVED the book! The science fiction, excitement, message on many levels and imagery of the original kept him glued to the pages. As a reward I took him to the movie today... what a disappointment! The Disney-fied version cuts out the meaningful chunks of the plot and message, leaving what's left unexplained, contrived and disconnected. The real meaning of the original story and characters has been gutted and has been substituted with the plot merely being a rescue mission with special effects instead of a well-written engaging story of self-discovery and coming of age. Disney confabulated completely new plot elements and characters that didn't exist in Madeleine L'Engle's classic, hijaking the original story and losing the audience. Instead of "based on" L'Engle's a Wrinkle in Time" in the opening credits, it should have said "vaguely suggestive of." If Disney had half of the courage and ethos of L'Engle's original they would have stayed true to "A Wrinkle In Time," and could have made a memorable family movie instead of a big shoulder-shrugger.

Great book.
Great cast.
Great musicians.Awful movie. How did you do that?

The story in a Wrinkle in Time is very well built and it shows Disney isn't just pretty and pink. I think the CGI and effects were great. The actors were well chosen. The sets and costumes were stunning along with amazing soundtracks. Some scenes were not great acting-wise. Also, some camera angles weren't great. That is why I rate A Wrinkle In Time 9 out of ten stars.

You would think with some big names on the screen this would be decent. Not even close. BORING BORING BORING. Almost the entire time is spent showing us the special effects and scenery which is what I call sugar coated lame. As for story about the kids wanting to find their father who disappeared mysteriously, it's just a side note to the scenery and not deep at all. On top of that, the acting was pathetic. I can't get the time I spent watching this back, but at least I can warn others before they waste their time.

reviews.review_title: Ignore the Trolls, go see this!
reviews.content:
I went into this movie as a big fan of the book. I intentionally didn't reread the book beforehand. This movie captured everything I remembered about this amazing tale. What changes there were from the book were done to aid in the translation of medium. The costumes, effects, and performances were all top notch.
Don't let the trolls sway you. This movie is amazing.

All those fancy special effects cannot make up for the sorry-ass story and the lousy acting. The dialogues are meant to be "oh so wise" with words like love, family, home, etc. but it all sounds phony and way too drippy.I was tempted to give it 1 star maximum!

A Wrinkle in TimeTypically the children of scientists tend to be hideous patchworks of random limbs and organs. Thankfully, the offspring in this family-fantasy appear to be fairly normal looking.Obsessed with finding her missing scientist father Alex (Chris Pine) after he disappeared looking for the seeds to humanity out in the cosmos, Meg (Storm Reid) is obviously thrived to learn from three astral beings (Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling) that he's still alive.However, Alex is being prisoner on another planet that is ruled by a malignant organism that intends to use Alex's transportation device to take over the universe. A vast departure from the beloved children's novel from the 1960s, this effects laden, star-studded adaptation sheds significant character and story elements from the novel to accommodate the aggressive visuals, timely social commentary and its overreaching narrative that strives towards its doubtful sequels.Incidentally, imprisonment on another planet is a good excuse for missed child support payments. Red Lightvidiotreviews.blogspot.ca
I now a lot of people didn't like this, but i read the book multiple times and still appreciated the movie i thought it was incredible

I realize that I am obligated to like this movie, but I can't. The acting is dopey, the story line lurches, and the overall tone is in comprehensible.This will put Oprah in the White House just like The Right Stuff was guaranteed to put John Glenn in the White House. How well did that work?The best part of the movie was the extra butter on the popcorn and the really refreshing taste of Coke Zero Sugar. The movie, on the other hand was chewy and flat.

reviews.review_title: Everybody calm down... It's not flawless, but it's okay.
reviews.content: When I first saw the trailer I was concerned. I re-read the book in January just to refresh my memory on how this SHOULD go... And it should be noted that the book also has it's flaws, like poor character development and an abrupt ending. I'm seeing lots of complaints that movie-Meg is annoying and one-dimensional, and let me tell you, book-Meg is too. However, there is a pivotal scene in the book in which she learns to stop being petulant and finds her purpose, and this scene DOES NOT EXIST in the movie. I would argue that this one scene that they cut out is crucial to the climax of the story, and this adaptation completely jumps over those events. Therefore the fault of character development is further worsened, but it's worth pointing out that one-dimensional characters in children's books are common, in order to allow the child to imagine themselves as the protagonist.Anyone who's read the book knows that their mother has red hair, and Meg's is a mousy brown. People are so upset by this change. The idea that Meg hates her hair is TRUE TO THE BOOK, and personally, I don't think the texture of the actresses' (mom and Meg) hair are necessary to the storyline. The fact that we chose to make them WOC actually makes MORE sense than what's in the book, in my opinion, because our culture actually SHAMES textured hair whereas brown is just boring. In the same way, Charles Wallace isn't adopted in the book, however I feel it helps to explain his "oddness" more effectively because of it. We aren't recreating the world of the 60s, we're telling the story in present day so our children can relate to the characters and not roll their eyes at an out of touch story. These were excellent ways to do this. The book is written in a way where it does not make it relevant as to what era it takes place; that's part of its transcendence. As far as the Misses go, they were obviously hyped in the trailer because they're freaking Oprah, Reese, and Mindy, but their roles are not supposed to be main characters. I'm seeing a lot of complaints that they don't serve enough purpose, but that's kind of the point. Albeit, the way they are utilized in the movie doesn't make as much sense as it does in the book with what they chose to leave out, but overall the three actresses play them the way they are written in the book. Whatsit is young and inexperienced in her role, Who speaks in quotes, and Which is your most wise, guiding figure who is so otherworldly she struggles to materialize. And as far as their races go, who cares? The book doesn't describe their skin. I'm more upset that Whatsit transforms into a Green Giant looking parachute instead of Pegasus-like creature described in the book, but that's mainly because I love horses. It doesn't affect the story.All of this leads me to my final point which is, I don't understand why people think this is so preachy? The entire book is based around the concept of good and evil, love and hate. The "IT" is essentially the devil in the book, to the point where references to God are made (they're EXTREMELY random, but they are made). So what if Meg is insecure about natural waves instead of dishwater brown? So what if we made the Misses Indian, Black and White? The only scene that gets preachy is when Oprah's character Ms. Which describes what "IT" does to our world, and literally all she says is that evil is the influence causing all terrible things in our world. This isn't incorrect. And the whole point is for Meg to learn her potential as a young girl being the ONLY person who can do what they've set out to do. This movie is neither heavily political OR socially conscious, unless you deliberately choose to single out things which neither positively or negatively affect your characters (like race).Let us please remember that the book was written in the 60s, and won the Newberry for it's radical-for-the-time science fiction plot. No, it wasn't radically socially conscious; most children's books then weren't. But this movie only feels like an agenda if you choose to view the casting in this way. If the whole movie was nothing but white people, it would feel like any other stereotypical "child discovers their potential and how to boost their self esteem" story. There's a new one of those out at least once a year. Please calm down.This is either the best nor the worst adaptation of a book. It makes some weird choices that make it fall a little flatter than it would have had they followed the book more closely, but when is that ever not true of an adaptation? If you love the book, it's worth watching, but you'll be a little disappointed if you've recently read it. If you've never read the book, there are lots of things which will make you scratch your head and not understand the direction being taken, but keep in mind that most of it is the author's writing, not the directing or acting. This isn't the most exciting work of sci-fi ever written, but it is the foundation of many that came after it. Let's keep it in perspective, ay?

I stopped watching this movie after an hour. Now I unterstand all other reviews. Awkward, rediculous, boring. Waste of time. Bad acting, slow paced, pointless dialogues and bad action sequences, hilarious special effects and horrible, annoying Soundtrack

I'm stunned by the amount of "adults" giving this kids film bad reviews. You all look insane and you really need to grow up. This is a wonderful, unique, clever kids film that delivers something great for girls and boys alike. I took a group of several kids to see this and they all loved it.Even for those whose haven't read the book, the film has a fantastic cast of intriguing characters, a beautiful storyline, interesting scientific and magical themes, and of course truly stunning imagery.I am so glad Disney tried something new, and I am so glad my kids were able to experience this film.

This movie made it's way to Netflix's "trending" list recently which is the ONLY reason I watched it. The only sensible plot here is the protaginist's scientist father disappeared in the universe somewhere and they have to go find him. But it's so unbelievably slow!! This entire movie is fillers. I just wanted to fast forward to where they find their dad! 2 stars for Disney instead of 1 only because the visuals as per usual were fantastic.

I loved this movie. I recently re-read the book and of course they changed a few things but that always happens. The book is very dark and I was happy that Disney left it creepy, dark and sad. The little guy who played Charles Wallace was great.

I loved the book this movie is based on and I found this movie to be a wonderful adaptation. Everything about this movie is fantastic. From the acting to the costumes, this movie did such a good job of taking the beloved classic and putting it on the big screen. Miss Ava and her crew should be proud.

AWIT is an incredibly faithful adaptation of a bizarre, surrreal, but ultimately dazzling, happy, and very important book. The cast delivers on the oddity especially, giving their all to performances that likely don't make sense to audiences that refuse to come in with an open mind. But if you're willing to give this film a chance, its spectacular visuals, thrilling action, and incredibly sweet story are sure to prove a great time at the theater.

reviews.review_title: This movie is too advanced for its time
reviews.content: Most people can't understand the concept of this movie because it's too positive and enlightening which most people are not. It's kinda an analogy of life and how you should live it, by avoiding and disengaging yourself from all negativity and focusing on the "light". This means being a very kind person but also putting yourself first and believing fully in yourself. Anyway, that's not something most people in this world know how to do just yet.

Ignore the reviews.
No, it is not L'Engle.
But you can and will enjoy it if you can watch it for what it is, a 2018 version of a fantasy kids book.
It's OK.

Madeleine L'Engle's fantasy works are in part highly expressive of her Christian viewpoint in a manner somewhat similar to that of Christian fantasy writer C. S. Lewis. She was herself the official writer-in-residence at New York City's Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, which is known for its prominent position in the liberal wing of the Episcopal Church. L'Engle's liberal Christianity has been the target of criticism from more conservative Christians, especially with respect to certain elements of A Wrinkle in Time.

reviews.review_title: Disappointing if you loved the book
reviews.content: This was one of my very first favorite books, and I always thought the story and imagery was fascinating.I didn't feel the movie properly represented anything from the book, and I was bored the entire time I was watching it... even had to stop and restart several times trying to get into it.I also didn't feel like any of the characters looked or acted at all how described in the book. The characters weren't really believable or likeable. Meg is supposed to be an angry, stubborn high school student, but the character in the movie was like a bland middle schooler with no redeeming or relatable qualities.I always thought this book would make the coolest, creepiest movie, so this watered down Disney interpetation was a huge letdown for me. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone who loved the book... or anyone else.

I have to start by saying that I have no idea where the hate for this movie comes from. Maybe Disney's and Ava DuVernay's politics were a bit too in the face for some people, maybe the hate for Oprah blinded them, maybe there was a Twitter battle that I was not aware of, but this is not a bad movie by any measure. Ava DuVernay is an odd choice to direct this children's fantasy movie, as she seems more interested in politically driven movies than CGI eye candy, but Selma was very well directed so I can see what Disney were thinking when they hired her. Most of the movie is really beautiful, very well shot with great sets and visuals. The only thing that doesn't work (and it doesn't work big time) is the look of the Three Misses, from their costumes to their make-up, all is truly horrendous. I have no idea how such an otherwise beautiful movie made such a mistake. But that is not enough to destroy this movie! It has a nice message, from what I can see it was well adapted from the source material (I can agree with the decision to take the religion out of it), and it was entertaining enough. Unfortunately I have to admit that I found the story a bit generic, the Charles Wallace character was a bit too obnoxious, and this genre is not a favorite of mine, hence the low rating after so many good things to say, but I can still easily recommend it. And it all comes back to me not having a clue as to why people hate this movie so much.

Since the book was a fave, had a diff mood when i first watched this. As time passes tho, we tend to forget our moods. Haha. I still find that translating fantasy or imagination into film is quite difficult. All in all , i find today it works and fits better into the original story.

reviews.review_title: I have no idea what I just watch but my kids liked it.
reviews.content: I was massively underwhelmed by this movie. For much of the movie I had little idea what was going on. It seemed to just jump around, like I fell through some wrinkle and time traveled. People showed up, solutions were too easy to find. It seemed contrived and a disjointed mess. The only reason I give it 4/10 was that my kids enjoyed it.

reviews.review_title: The "spy kids" of spacetime-travel (warning, broken english incoming)
reviews.content:
Personally i think the movie failed from the very begining. The concept/approach was not just pretentious but tried to impose

 I personally tend to judge this films by tis capacity to appeal to any other audiences. I could get more technical, or maybe not. Maybe this wasnt the review you were expecting. Personally i think is way too cheesy (as i said, if you watched spy kids you will understand the exact level of it) 
 For that and all, and that im not a critic but a watcher, i scored the movie a 1/5, scoring not the movie itself by what i think was its capacity to amuse me.
 (Personally, if a friend was asking i would say something like "a complete dissapointment and by far the most idiotic film i saw in a while. I would be very dissapointed if anyone gave this more than a 4 out of 10")

reviews.content: You might not need a 40-year-old white dude to tell you what didn't work about 'A Wrinkle in Time'. And you know what, I won't. I wouldn't even rate this film. But now I feel obliged.
