I saw this movie a few months ago, so I don't fully remember it, but I remember it was an insanely boring and unworthwhile experience and, while not the worst movie I've seen (I've seen the Emoji Movie in full), is quite possibly the most frustrating. Let's start off with how unfaithful it is to the book it's based off of: Entire sections from the Wrinkle In Time book are cut out from this movie. For starters, instead of finding Meg's father by going into the Camazotz headquarters and having to fight the red-eyed man inside and Charles Wallace under his possession, the part of the movie on Camazotz is restrained to completely boring borderline filler. Eventually they reach what the movie calls the Camazotz headquarters but it's an empty room where Meg's father is just sitting up in another empty room connected by an invisible staircase. Another big change is that the planet Ixchel is completely removed from the movie despite being a major part of the book without any attempt to even replace it. Even more randomly it seems they changed the introduction and conclusion specifically to highlight Calvin as a love interest. Another issue that sinks the movie: The visuals do not live up to the book's descriptions. The beautiful creature described on Uriel literally looks like flying cabbage in the movie and Camazotz looks less like the madness described in the book and more like a generic small town neighborhood. Possibly a bigger issue than terrible illustration or terrible adaptation, however, is terrible pretentiousness. The movie as a whole has this attitude that it's woke and deep with the flashbacks of bad things happening on Earth and the semi-vague descriptions of IT that make the whole thing play out like the protagonists are on an ego trip. I had to stop here because I'm late for something but yeah this movie sucks.

Ok, watching right now. I'm half way in but what the hell?I don't understand any of this...
Was the director either drunk or high or both?

reviews.review_title: The Arrogance of Disneyland Jennifer Lee
reviews.content: To think they could rewrite this storyline. Instead of an engaging classic realized on-screen, an enraging waste of everyone's time, the actor's, the audience, everyone who in some way is connected to this banal flop. This story did not need to be embellished, it simply needed to be told. The screen play on this one is garbage, IF this was solely Jennifer Lee's doing, I am sorry but she SUCKS!!!

reviews.review_title: My Wrinkles go in other directions...
reviews.content: I loved this when I went to see it in the theatre, so we bought the DVD. This month we lent it out to a young couple and they pointed out the commentary, so we pulled it out and watched it again, and it has aged really really well. It's amazing.Okay, so the book was about a white family in New England, but that was what "families" looked like to Madeleine, so that's what she wrote. Now it was a mixed race family in L. A. And all along the way the things that the book made impossible to turn to film, they transposed it to 21st century modes. Who would want a "pulsating brain" in a room for "IT" today? That would be so Dr. Who and this was Disney.This film honours L'Engle's intents as I understood them from the book in every way I could imagine and I am disappointed that its absolute commercial failing meant that the set up for Wind and maybe Tilting Planet will never come to be, when I'm sure that this nucleus of actors could have made it sing if they'd been given the chance.... but the market has no brain, it doesn't love, it's not God: all it can tell you is the price of lunch...So be it. Look for me somewhere out beyond Ixchel and Uriel.

At first I thought a good editor might have saved this film by cutting it down--but it's not three hours long, it only seems that way. All of this is sooooo obvious and didactic. No sense of wonder. No excitement. The best we've got is Reese Witherspoon, who seems to be in a different and more whimsical movie but who really doesn't have anything to work with. We watched about 45 minutes, then skipped forward to the end, which also was slow . . . slow . . . slow . . . and uninvolving. Duvernay's "Selma" was much more interesting, but also played somewhat fast and loose with the material (making LBJ a antagonist to ML King rather than an ally). This film also seems not to be the book it was based on.

reviews.review_title: Seriously? Is this a Disney movie?
reviews.content: I can't even believe it is a Disney movie. The acting was poor, the plot has no sense at all, cgi and special effects were disappointing. I really can't understand how nobody in the production realized that there were so many faults in this movie. Save two hours in your life and watch something else. ANYTHING else. Really.

reviews.review_title: When the student is ready, the teacher will appear.
reviews.content: I thoroughly enjoyed A Wrinkle in Time. Yes, I gave it a 10. I understand the transformation journey and how the universe will manifest my deepest desires as a result of my thoughts and intent. I believe in guardians, guides, and angels. A Wrinkle in Time was exceptionally profound and enlightening. Ava DuVernay, thank you for capturing the essence of spirituality in the movie. I felt Oprah channel what she has learned about life through her personal experiences through her character. Witherspoon's character and personality...definitely a mirror for Meg. I understood the quotes throughout the movie. I'm a Disney fan and always enjoy their movies. I've been taught if you listen long enough you will learn something new every day. Watching A Wrinkle in Time today proved that. This movie will reach the intended listener and audience it is designed to reach. I am one of them. I relished the fact that there were only 4 people in the movie today. Silence and peace to absorb the numerous lessons the movie offered.

I almost didn't watch this movie because of the low reviews, but I am glad I did. A wrinkle in time was my favorite book growing up and I will say that the movie was extremely true to the book. I was impressed. I could see if someone did not read the book and watched this without any background they might not be able to follow it or understand it but for those who know the story I think it was done very well. I'm not saying it should win an Oscar but i will say it does not deserve the hate - I'm glad I watched. It brought me back to my childhood. If you liked the book, give it a chance!!Also - Chris pine is the dad!! Can't do better than that casting.

reviews.review_title: I had high hopes but was totally disappointing
reviews.content: The only positive thing was the CGI. Just bad all the way around. Some good actors who had no chance with this movie.
I enjoyed being led on a rescue mission thru kids eyes. Fantasy, I enjoyed it.

reviews.review_title: Overall I enjoyed this movie, but it was difficult
reviews.content: In general, I really enjoyed this movie but there was a lot that made it very difficult to enjoy. It was a heartwarming, encouraging story with a great cast. But the directing/editing made it hard to follow sometimes and easily took you out of the story. I honestly thought every performance was great but the one that stood out to me was Storm Reid as Meg. Some of her scenes really blew me away. I also enjoyed each of the "misses" immensely. The story was great but the writing sometimes felt stunted with very little world building. My girlfriend was confused throughout the entire story. I just felt like the story could've gone so much further while explaining a little more along the way. The graphics were great but some of the editing/directing made it feel chopped up and inconsistent. Lots of extreme, extensive close ups. In particular, a lot of the music choices really bothered me. Maybe it's just me but adding modern music with lyrics in a sci-fy fantasy movie really takes me out of the story and cheapens the whole thing. It felt like we were constantly switching from an inspirational fantasy movie to a teen drama. Just pick one.

reviews.review_title: One of the absolute worst movies
reviews.content: Bad story, bad acting, bad FX. Completely worthless.
Every review is so mean. I loved this movie. Some people just need to watch the movie for what it is. A great a amazing sifi movie that is for all ages. No judgment. Loved the movie 😍

reviews.review_title: This movie made my brain hurt!
reviews.content: No. Just no. This is such a waste of time and money.
I don't understand the hate the movie was great the acting was really good as well I don't understand
Really Good. I really like the book and Disney so this is good

reviews.review_title: Bad in the same way as '80s classics
reviews.content: Not a good movie. But Meg is a good actor. And it's bad in the same way that all those '80s kids fantasies are bad-Neverending Story, Labyrinth, Legend, Solarbabies, Time Bandits, etc. So there's some real charm and nostalgic resonance to that.

Not sure why the bunch of adults is so critical about this movie. It's a sweet modern fairytale about family values. Yes, it's naive and some dialogues are too simple, but very understandable for children. The picture is mostly nice as well. I think it's not suitable for adults, but kids like it.

I have not read the book and have no idea what the storyline is MEANT to be. I have heard the movie is a trainwreck but not in what way. I don't like fantasy and went into it not expecting to like it but am pleasantly surprised. I think the difficulties the children experience when their father disappears is well portrayed. I like how the boy goes off at the teachers for their idle gossip about something that is so deeply personal to him (the disappearance of his father) and sticks up for his sister who is being systematically bullied since their father's disappearance because of her vulnerability.. He is promptly called crazy along with her for which his sister retaliates and is told by the incompetent principal that it was an unprovoked attack and that she is trying to use "her father's disappeared" card for four years as an excuse for her aggression and is told to cut it out.It is later revealed the principal was indeed selected over better candidates for the position,. Then the movie moved from social justice themes into the trippier themes of time travel and the timeless fight between good and evil. (People criticise that it didn't show the father and friend tessering back, but everything obvious thing doesn't need to be spelled out in a movie. They tessered back the same way the brother and sister did).. Meg stayed back to rescue her brother that had been possessed by evil and it could only be overcome with love. Meg had to face all that was dark and hidden about herself, all the things she didn't want to accept about herself to be strong enough to save her brother. Only the strength of pure love could overcome evil and she achieved that. People may think that is corny but in my 50 years, I have only got strong by facing my weakness and I have only overcome evil with love. The themes are pretty solid for me. That is my lived experience. I actually liked the costuming. I liked seeing what they would do with the makeup, the clothes and the transformation into other creatures. If people are so disappointed with the movie, the book must be outstanding or just not focus on the themes of social justice and good vs evil as much - or has it's qualities in another area that the movie missed and disappointed viewers. It held me all through and I enjoyed it.
Don't mind the negative comments here. A good movie with a very clear message. Fun, entertaining and great family feel good film.

I finished reading the book, and decided to sit down and watch the movie. Sure, there are a bunch of big name actors and some stunning visuals, but the important scenes are glossed over or completely missing. What should be heartfelt and thought provoking is instead drab goes for the cheap quick surfacial emotional response. The character development is near non-existent, and storyline is too choppy.

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your time if you love the book
reviews.content: Other than using the names of the characters this version is so watered down that should be called A Waste of Time. Do yourself a favor & read the book as it's a better use of your time.
Maybe it's because I've never read the books or I just love all things space but I thought this was a cute movie. Kind of like a child's version of "Interstellar"
I think they missed the mark on casting the main female lead as well as her character in general. Found it really aggravating to watch and follow along.

This was a really great movie. It adheres pretty well to the story in the book and was captivating. The cinematography was beautiful; they make great use of CGI to depict the alien worlds, while still maintaining the realness of the main characters. I also thought the pacing was good. I was worried it was going to move too slow, but it ended up moving slow in the parts where it should and moving fast where it shouldn't.I liked the unconventional cast, though maybe Oprah didn't need to be in there. In the book Meg is supposed to be awkward, so people who are saying she can't act are just misunderstanding how she's supposed to be acting. The story is about embracing your faults and figuring out a way to use them to succeed in life; it wouldn't have worked to have Meg be swashbuckling.The main difference between the movie and the book is in the movie IT is actively trying to get them, whereas in the book IT is much more passive. I didn't mind the change. I think the PG13 rating confused some people-- this is a definitely a kids movie, but one that grown ups can also appreciate.

If I were you i would go see this movie! I seriously hope they make a 2nd one! If someone asked me what my favorite movie was i would say A Wrinkle in Time! If you are wanting to do a family night come out and see this movie!

reviews.review_title: One of the worst Disney Movies
reviews.content: The plot is written poorly. The movie is confusing, and boring. There are many scenes that things just happen and no explaination for that. A lot of great actors and actresses. I feel for them being suckered into this. I am sure the book is better. Its like moments of excellence mixed with awful ones.
I regret watching this. Sooooo far away from the book.
I liked the movie. I took 2 little boys, ages 8 and 6, who stayed engaged during the entire movie.

This movie was soo bad I could barely believe it was a Disney movie. Who has ever approved this script? Casted the actors? Directed the movie? The story lacks fluency and sense, the acting is bad, I was really in shock. Two hours wasted. And it was so clear to detect CGI... I mean, how is possible nobody stopped it before it was released? Impossible to understand.

Watched this due to a sick child's request, which next time I will suggest Dr. Who instead because we will definitely both feel better. Nothing in this is appealing - it reminds me of the confusion I felt when watching The Wiz as a child... bright colors, lost plot, poor acting. And Oprah... uggghhh... feels like PBS from the 70s threw up on me... can't get this time back...
Absolutely horrible movie especially for disney. Not for children. Very depressing and boring. Too long.

reviews.review_title: Worst movie i have ever seen..
reviews.content: Never wrote a review before - but if it Can help people from wasting two hours of there live - then This will Be worth it.

The acting is awful, especially from meg and he love interest. The only character I somewhat enjoy is Charles and that's only when he is evil and hurting the others. The should have done a different cast and a different scrip for this steaming garbage heap I want to give it a negative number so bad.

reviews.review_title: Pretty good film, but one bit disappointed me.
reviews.content: I think this movie is pretty good, if I'm being honest, but I was a little disappointed with how they didn't make you feel more sympathetic for Veronica. Sure, it may be easy to absolutely just hate her, but she flat on hated herself, and I was a little upset that nobody pointed that out a bit more, but other than that, I have no idea why people keep on throwing shade onto this film. People are throwing so much disturbingly pathetic shame, I hate how bad the director must feel.

Just what? The acting is cringeworthy, the plot points are confusing and just dumb, I didn't read the books but I'm sure that wouldn't have cleared anything up or made the movie better. This may have taken my new top spot as most hated movie.

Do you like uncomfortably bad acting? Do you like not being able to follow a plot? Then this is the movie for you! It's literally uncomfortable to watch it's so bad. Don't waste your time with this lousy excuse for a movie.

A Wrinkle in Time was one of my favorite childhood books...so powerful and inspiring. The movie, on the other hand, made my heart hurt. I can't understand how or why those involved in making this movie felt compelled to destroy this story. Such a wasted opportunity, I regret that I cannot I watch this.

reviews.review_title: Loved loved Loved this movie!! I'm Going again*****
reviews.content: Great Family Movie..loved everything about thus movie

The review title says it all. Plot was non existent and meaningless other than the very predictable ending. Waste of the talent that appeared in the movie. Regret sticking with it until the end hoping it would improve, sadly, the only hope I had in the end is that it would finish soon(er) than it did.Pointless waste of resources and talent.

I had never heard of this film or the books. I will now be reading the books as the idea this film was based on looks to be amazing. The film however, I had no idea what to make of it so I'm glad I didn't read the books first.The thing is, to a layman who has never read the books, taking this film as it is, it could have been something fantastic. Really. There are some moments in this film, albeit small moments that the dialogue is exquisite and really made me sit forward and think. In fact at one point I was even nodding in agreement with what Oprah was saying about how the main character got to where she was. There were a few moments like that that saved me from turning it off. There was also other visual moments that kept me watching, like her last leap through space/time to get home. It such a shame that Disney has taken another, what I'm sure was a, literary masterpiece and tore it to shreds to make a quick buck to add to the billions they already have. Shame on you Disney/producer/director but well done to everyone else who was great in this film. Thank you for restoring my faith in books, I will be visiting this series soon.

I've never ever read the book..and was really excited to watch it since the trailer looked really good. Few minutes in to the movie i was just confused and puzzled till the end! I barely got anything what the movie was about..and the affects we're sooo bad..even the first harry potter movie was alot better. Sadly i just hated it and left me dissapointed! I just wasted my movie night on this....

reviews.review_title: Completely ruined by pacing and loud, continuous music!
reviews.content: Why in the world did they not understand that constant, TV music that adds nothing just ruins a film? Smacks of Oprah Winfrey. Brilliant woman, but she ruins every film she touches with sappy, over the top television sensibilities instead of film sensibilities. I've seen other things by this Director, and she seemed to have a better handle on music, so it must be Winfrey. It was distracting and so over the top and absurd that it was alarming.Additionally it was so, so slow and did nothing but wear you out with music for a long, long time.This could have been a Wizard of Oz for the present, but instead it turned into just a massive distraction. Why can't they just hire people who know what they are doing and leave them alone!
This movie is so awful. Im not gonna explain how awful it is, just because it's too awful to look back to the awfulness of the movie. Not gonna recommend this one. It sucks big time. Bye

Having read the book to my elementary students in the early 70's, I was looking forward to a decent cinematic version following some early feeble attempts. This turns out to be a very dark recruitment product for new age philosophy. The Oprah factor is obvious in the highly edited story line. I found the 'it' factor to be so pronounced that I would never encourage this to be viewed by children or adults. I felt soiled when it was over.

What can I say. The CG was cool but that was it. The little boy and the redhead did OK but the rest of the cast struggled big time. Oprah should just stick to misleading people....lol. Not very well thought out and jumped around too much.

I read the books with my daughter before watching this movie. Neither her nor I could make heads or tails of what was going on in this movie. There are some bad adaptations from book to screen, but this one takes the cake. I felt disappointed after watching this, but I believe my daughter left even more disappointed than myself. Disney proved again that throwing money at a project is not enough to make a great movie. Which is more disappointing considering they had source material to work with.
It was very unique that makes you say spectacular and very peculiar
characters=4/5 plot=3.5/5 acting=3/5 songs =5/5 movie vibe=2.5/5 ending=4/5

5 years later this ends being pretty misguided but relatively harmless The plot is notoriously difficult to explain being it's based on the book by Madeleine L'Engle Director Ava Duvernay helms a large cast starring Storm Reid, Reese Witherspoon, Oprah Winfrey, Mindy Kaling, Chris Pine, Gugu Mbatha-Raw, Zach Galafanakis, Michael Pena, and Rowan Blanchard in fantasy/sci-fi story of family Meg's parents are eager to explore more of the universe and traveling to other parts of it; of course her father has been doubted by everyone so he decides to venture on his own tapping into the right frequency But he ends up going missing in between dimensions trying to make his discovery after a year 3 magical witches Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit, and Mrs. Who then offer to take Meg, her brother, and friend Calvin to look for him and they come across other worldly things like sentient flowers, flying leaves, and an evil entity called the IT that feeds off beings' negative energy Meg has to learn to open her mind and be more trusting to herself battling her insecurities in the process The movie is good, not great, felt very rushed and a lot of those scenes in the trailer were missing I think the biggest issue is that the book is full of more Christian themes which maybe explains why this movie was so limited and they didn't want to step on anyone's toes It does have a clear cut allegory about the evils of communism and conformity But there are some effective emotional moments, interesting visuals, some interesting concepts, and it has a great slew of actors Aside from Pine and Reid who nail their roles perfectly everyone else feels like they're in a completely different movie In order to be great it's not enough to be right, finding out all the universe's secrets cannot measure how much love we have in our hearts, we don't have to be desperate to matter in the universe This movie might still stand out as one of those trippy movies kids can look back on making them think Won't hold much for adults though for all the trippyness involved I do like the fantasy element as well as the actors but the narrative is clumsy

Clearly written on drugs. Costumes are meant to be loud and stunning, but they look cheaper than the special effects. Characters lack any development and lines/script is as poor in writing as in delivery. 
It could have standard to have a little more effort put into it, especially from some of the actors who have been in the industry for a long time. But their efforts would only quell the stink of a few problems with the film. It's one of those houses that needs to be completely torn down and built back up entirely different.
Just turned it off midway couldn't bare to watch another minute of this monstrosity!
I really liked this movie
Yes i do agree that the message of the movie is a bit heavy handed which drags it down. But everything else about the movie i genuinely enjoy and definitely recommend this movie.
I couldn't wait for it to end. Each moment was more nonsensical than the last. I award the director no points, and may God have mercy on his soul.

It was visually stunning and had strong performances. Perhaps because of the limitations of a film (run time) fans of the book may see plot holes and less character development, but it is a strong story well told.
Awesome movie! definitely watch it!

Another failed attempt at making a movie based on an excellent novel.   Hollywood's insistence on changing the source material in ways that will supposedly broaden  it's appeal ends up warping the story to the point of it losing everything that was special about it. If you loved thr book do not waste your time by watching this movie. If you haven't read the book skip this and watch literally anything else.

When diversity is your main selling point and visually quality being your fallback.  Overall performances in the film lack and the story is made politically correct for a progressive audience.  It's at best a popcorn film.
The worst movie so far made by Disney, this is what happens when you run a movie using hallucinogens

Daughter is severely dyslexic, so I read to her every night, including most of the extended Wrinkle in Time series, both the Meg novels and the Poly novels.

The novels were precious to me as a kid and I was gratified that daughter loved them also.

And then the movie came out.  Well, I guess it wasn't made for me.  Or her.  Or anyone who cherishes the book.
Was not as good as the book.  Wouldn't watch it again.
One of the most boring movies of Disney.
Barely similar to the book with bad acting
So much wasted potential. Lots of good talent, too bad it did not translate well to the screen.
All hail Oprah Winfrey
Just nope! Thought it would be cute but it was just weird.

A young girl named Meg travels through the universe in search of her father. Based on a novel by Madeleine L'Engle that I have not yet read. Storm Reid plays the lead and I wasn't wowed by her performance, but I think she did a good job. Chris Pine and Reese Witherspoon both make good use of the limited screen time they have. There were many moments of "hey look at this CGI sequence that we bought" in this film that slowed the pacing down and took away potential character moments that this film needed more of. I was very confused by the motivation, or plan, of the villain. Through the movie I was rooting for the lead, but had no doubt she would succeed. Skip this film.
Horrible directing. Excuse for these women to just dress up in different outfits. They ruined the book.

It's SO bad. Even after reading the book and understanding it, I find the movie extremely confusing and hard to follow. Several times we had to pause and be like, "Wait, what is going on now?" Characters continually compliment Meg to the point that it gets creepy. There is a weird side plot with a school bully that doesn't make much sense and could easily be eliminated. There's an awkward beach scene that comes out of nowhere and gets weird when one of the characters shows his glowing red eyes and sticks out his tongue. Reese Witherspoon turns into a giant floating leaf. Oprah spends half the time floating around as a giant in the background. There's just a lot that doesn't make sense. Also, the CGI hurts my eyes. And why are we calling It "The It" instead of just "It"? So many questions.

I absolutely cannot stand this movie. I can't find anything I liked about this film it seems like an uninspired cash grab trying to come off as imaginative and special. The characters have no depth, they just appear out of nowhere and don't do anything interesting, the plot is unoriginal and cliché while still managing to be a mess and there are individual scenes of this movie which I cannot stand. A few parts of this movie make me laugh out loud about how terrible of a film it is and some are just plainly terrible. I'm not lying when I say this is my least favourite movie of all time.
There's no doubt in my mind that this movie looks amazing. Yet a story can't drive off of visuals.

This film belongs to the visual effects guys as it looks good with some tricky shots. The problem comes in with the conflict of camera work, atmosphere and concept design, meaning it has no clear distinction as to what it wants to be. It's filmed like a scientific drama, but tries to have a sort of magic and cosmos feel and it doesn't work because the visual lacks atmosphere and has a lot of handheld operation. To me, it feels like the director couldn't handle the weight of the project and simply tried to get the shots done in time. The hinting at technical scientific theories is weak and brushed under the carpet, even though it's for kids it still felt weak. Disney has seemed to lost their master filmmakers who were disciplined in all aspects of filmmaking. And if I have to hear the double name "Charles-Wallace" one more time I'll go crazy.
Kid's name is Charles Wallace, that tells you all you need to know about the quality of the film.
whay ???? what is going on ? disney

Maybe this one got mediocre reviews because people are attached to the book? I was never attached to the book, and I love this film. 

I'm taking off half a star for Chris Pine, as he wasn't a believable father figure, and he seemed waxy and ken doll-like. When Meg finally found him after all that searching, I really felt like "Ugh, not him..." which is no way to feel toward a metaphor for God. Most of this film is missing Chris Pine, though, so 4 and a 1/2 stars for that!*

*Chris Pine is definitely a draw for most of my lady friends, so, the marketing here works.
Horribly edited, but has a lot of heart and is visually amazing!

"A Wrinkle in Time" is best described as a mix bag; moments of brilliance and moments of "why was this not cut?" On one hand, this Disney adaptation has splendid color and CGI that will "wow" the kids, but on the other hand this story about two children trying to find their missing father fails to develop any of its prolific ideas or smooth out its narrative gaps.

While visually stunning, it missed the mark for me. Kids were alright, made you feel. The little Charles Wallace character is adorable. Reese, fantastic as always, and the comic relief. Mindy felt a little robotic, which is too bad because she's good. And showing the egomaniac Oprah as almost godlike..😑..no thanks. They missed the mark on that casting call. If you're looking for something to pass the time then I'd give it a whirl, it definitely a kids movie. But don't expect too much.
This movie is a kids movie but this movie meh

I love this movie. There are people that say that you can't enjoy it unless you are a 14 year old but I am actually 20 years old. I haven't read the book, although I plan to. If you did read the book, don't expect the movie to follow it to the T. And don't be so harsh oh my God some of the reviews I see of this are so harsh. Damn! You go make a movie! lol I think the movie is beautiful. I love how it showed women of color and how the leading actress was a black girl. It talked so much about self-love, unity and peace. It has deep messages about loving and accepting who you are. It is beautiful to see how Meg has so much love for her family and keeps on following her gut and intuition despite how people don't believe in her. In situations where someone would is completely loose hope, she is persistent and resilient. I have watched this movie so many times and it brings me so much joy.

The problem in cases like this is that the indisputable nature of its message, centered on the power of love with a good dose of female empowerment, should not serve to hide a script with a clear tendency to the schematic that relies too much on the effectiveness of certain scenes is enough so that by the mere fact of putting them together, everything will fit perfectly
Beautiful movie excellent acting Amazing plot Wonderful songs
This movie was bad, really bad. I read the book and still didn't understand the movie. I recommend you to not watch this movie.
Too forced and obvious cgi it tries hard to be cool but its not

Sweet enough. Just a shame it doesn't finish as great it starts.

'A Wrinkle in Time', I think, starts off very nicely. It gives a satisfactory background to the main character, while it builds the intrigue well. Unfortunately, it does drop off as it goes on - but not to the point that it hindered my enjoyment, it is a noticeable step down though. I really like the special effects, I think they look terrific throughout.

Onto the cast. Storm Reid does a respectable job as Meg, her performance arguably gets better as things progress - which is the opposite to the film overall. Chris Pine is underused in his role, but the casting of Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon and Mindy Kaling is good - Zach Galifianakis too. I didn't actually find Deric McCabe's character, Charles Wallace, annoying like most seemingly did.

Surprised to see that this has a low rating across the board. I've never read the Madeleine L'Engle novel so perhaps that has something to do with it? I do agree the writing isn't necessarily great either. Each to the own, but I genuinely enjoyed it I can't lie.

After the disappearance of her scientist father, three peculiar beings send Meg, her brother, and her friend who came out of nowhere to space in order to find him. This movie has a lot of heart but it just doesn't work as a movie. It was dull and it was not very engaging.
This was such a bad movie. The story was very bad. The acting was very bad. The characters were very bad. This movie was 110 mins, it felt like 3 hours.
It is so good you need to see it now
This really was a wrinkle in my time, I could have been doing something more productive than watching this garbage. Even with such a great cast nothing could save it from its demise.
Really Really horrible, on the level of some old Sid and Marty Croft Saturday morning fare such as H.R Puffenstuff, but with poorer quality acting, and lesser special effects.

The book is one of my all-time favorites, so I had very high expectations for this movie. It has pretty great casting in my opinion, and had amazing visuals and a really sweet clear message at it's core. But what I don't like about this movie, though, is the fact that it seems like a bit of cash grab, ya know? Like they were a little more focused on the money aspect, and less on the actual storytelling. Like, I don't like a lot of Meg's lines, or just her general vibe throughout the movie to be honest, even though the actress portraying her had so much potential. I loved the guy playing Calvin, I think he did a great job and they brought to life a very unique vision of him, which I really loved. I just wish we had more time with him, because he kind of seems like 'just along for the ride', even though he is so much deeper in the book. The only real character development we get from him is his dad, and that one line from the It. I also really loved Charles Wallace, and he's to be honest the only main character besides the Mrs', that has no actual faults. The casting was perfect, he had good dialogue, he was likable just like he was in the book. Mr and Mrs Murray were okay, I guess, we didn't get too much time with them so they don't even matter that much. Also, I think the Veronica role was just shoved in movie to make it so they have another well-known star in there. All in all, it just seems a little lazily put together, but had SO MUCH potential. I loved their take on this universe and story, it had such a unique signature to it, but with the lazy writing and some lazy shots here and there, it kind of didn't go all of the way that it needed to. I kind of wish they did, because then we get to see how they bring the rest of the series to life, which would be really cool to see. But what can I say, it's disney.

I was probably 12 when I read a Wrinkle in Time for the first time. It had a profound effect on me. 40 years later I still can't see subdivisions without thinking about the scene from the book where they are standing on the hill on Camazotz looking down at the houses and all the houses look exactly the same. Sameness became a dirty word for me. The book made me value those things that made me different. I would guess that maybe 20% of the movie comes from the book. The rest was created, written for the movie. I wanted to love the movie. But the drastic rewriting of the story made it impossible at the end. I've watched movies that had nothing to do with the original source: Robert Downing Jr. in Sherlock for instance. It has very little to do with the Conan Doyle version of Sherlock but it's fun as heck to watch. The changes made between L'Engle's book and the movie make no sense. They weaken the story. Mrs. Whatsit would never have kicked Meg in the book, why did they have her do it in the movie? Thirty minutes into the film and I found myself hating Mrs. Whatsit. At one point in the book there is an intense struggle between Charles Wallace and a certain entity, but in the movie he just instantly yields. Why? It goes against everything that Charles Wallace was/is. Over and over the movie rewrites the book to it's own detriment. By the end I was bitterly disappointed, angry, and frustrated. Loved the actors, except maybe Charles Wallace. My advice, go read the book.
Felt like the story was all over the place, fantasy nightmare.

Sort of exactly what you'd expect. Sloppy, slow, muddy, lowest common denominator children's film with bad dialogue, no sense of scale and no cohesive design. I applaud the abundance of female characters in strong roles and the superb, gentle damaged soul of the beta-female Lead Character. But Duverny has no understanding of how to shoot fantasy, at first coming across awkwardly against the urban backdrop and then later in a soulless void of green screen with flat plates of actors and vistas with no grounding or relevance. Wrinkle has a stodgy  story with no relatable sense of logic; typically, although cliche, these kinds of fantasy kids films end up portraying the fantasy elements as connected to the grief or fear of the child as they grow up. This film just throws colourful nonsense at us willy billy with no explanation of the logic and no way of connecting to any of it. One imagines that if this were a 2D animated Ghibli film it would be spectacular and appropriate, but like this it ironically seems lifeless and disconnected and pointless. 
It's twists and turns are predictable and the action is turgid. The way characters meet and the plot moves on are utterly contrived, it's disappointing really. 
It's not a terrible film, and sometimes with the dramatic elements it can actually be quite stirring and emotional, it's just mostly a film that misses the mark in every department.

It was one of my favorite books when I read it as an 8 year old in 1960.  It should have been made with the adjectives that described it IN the book! Too much time was spent in the beginning with SUNSHINE, and LOW KEY DELIVERY, where everyone spoke in whispers,and smiles!  IT WAS A "DARK AND STORMY NIGHT" WITH A PURPOSE!!!  Loneliness, heartbreak from the mother (from Meg hearing her cry every night), Who, Whatsit, and Which appeared at NIGHT - with the door flying open in the storm, not all "glittery and sunshine and smiles" like it's an ordinary day.  It does not have munchkins singing about the "Yellow Brick Road", and this looks like it is set up to be that way. The story has foreboding in every word Whatsit, Who and Which speak! The time should be spent when Meg tries to recover from the Tesseract, and the creatures has long arms, more like an octopus, not a green video game Princess that looks like a Sea Monkey you buy from the back of a comic!! Children express themselves with abandonment, not "whispers"!!!  UPLIFTING voices, even in fear! The director had the kids speak so monotone, it became boring very quickly! I mean, who cares about the kids before they even get to the "village"??? And, OPRAH - what happened to that great actress that had us in the palm of your hand when you were in the Color Purple?  Your delivery was so..... FLAT!!!!!  Who cares if you are "looking for a man who is lost in the universe?"  It seemed like you just wanted to go "around the corner" and you would find him! This is a story that can make you shudder, and feel some trepidation and fear, only to have such a showdown with "IT" that never materialized here! I mean, what's the matter with you, Director????  Don't YOU have the imagination and wonder and thrill of discovery that a child has???  TAKE THAT AND PUT IT OUT ON THE SCREEN!!! There should be the 'introductory scene" of the village with the children bouncing the balls in tandem, and the permeating "thud thud thud" of the rhythm of the  bouncing ball, that slowly creeps into the pulsing vein in Charles Wallace's head when he and "IT" confront the other kids!!!! THIS should be an adventure, not a stroll through Wonderland.   Not so with the way this was directed!!!!

Visually beautiful in Disney's simple manner. Solid performances by Storm Reid (Meg), Deric McCabe (Charles Wallace), and Chris Pine (Mr. Murray). Storm Reid, especially, is mature in her acting ability, employing finer nuances of powerful emotion in her performance. Oprah Winfrey, however, is there for name power only. She is not an actor and it shows throughout her uninspired, pandering performance. The story is, itself, inspiring and beautiful with obvious Judaeo-Christian symbolism throughout with such ideas as overcoming adversity, even evil - as well as obeying God's commands, relying upon inspiration, and turning weaknesses into strengths. Religious symbolism includes effective archetypes of the godhead and the devil, Adam & Eve, the forbidden fruit of the tree of The Knowledge of Good and Evil, the Garden of Eden and the fallen earth (I could go on) are all throughout and well used within the story. These concepts are simplified and woven into the story in a way that a full grasp of them is not necessary to appreciate the over-arching theme of good versus evil and one can enjoy the movie even if the symbolism is missed. This movie isn't polished enough to warrant a sequel. Most of the story retelling and acting is just okay - leaving the beauty solely in the hands of the over-arching story itself: which beauty, thankfuly, remains intact. A good movie to watch at home, especially with the family due to it's positive moral themes.

Considering that this is a Disney Movie I was very disappointed.  It did not have Disney Quality or Depth.  It was made more like a made for TV Movie.   It didn't explain much, it was like they were trying to fast forward to the moral of the story.  Kids would never get it, in fact I would think any child under 13 would be bored.  Oprah's performance was stale, stiff, unemotional, and unmemorable.  If she was supposed to be Glinda type guide she failed terribly.  Reese Witherspoon on the other hand, overacted, too loud, too much all around.  Mindy Kaling was dull also, seems I seen her on the cooking network.  None of them had emotional ties to their characters they were just reading a script, not performing as a character.  The little girl was OK, but she needs to be on Disney Channel for a while get some experience before taking on a movie roll.  The bright star is the little boy Deric McCabe he took on a complex role with many twists and a lot of dialog and he handled it well for such a young boy.  But he needs more experience also.   Disney needs to lock this up way in the back of the Disney Vaults.

However, Ava DuVernay's take on an allegedly unfilmable book comes off as misguided thanks to overreliance on being "original", having a face-heel turn that comes out of nowhere, performances of other characters feeling like they belong in different movies and the boy from Pan having no effect on the plot. Nada. He literally just walks into the movie and accompanies our heroine and her adopted little brother because he was in the book, I guess. A Wrinkle In Time had good intentions but as far as live-action Disney movies go, this overambitious misfire is a low point for the studio.

First of all, im a 32 year old male who watched this film with his 6 year old daughter. We are both mixed race but our skin color is considered white( which matters because this movie plays like a minority empowerment film at times I don't want people to think my love for the movie has anything to do with race). I don't understand why this movie is rated badly. Yeah Oprah is in it and she's terrible, but honestly I couldn't stop crying the entire film. It's extremely metaphoric and aligns with my spiritual identity exactly.  I felt connected to the idea that love is our most important emotion and the idea of finding your true self through personal strife. I think people have taken this movie literally and missed the deep underlying point. It had my daughter and me in tears because the things they handle in the film are very real for us (abandonment, obsession with work to the point of losing family, selfishness, mistrust of others, etc.) If you are Buddhist, this movie will speak to you as it did to me. Ignore oprah and try it out.

I find myself quite astounded at how lightly fellow critics are reviewing this movie. The script of this movie appears to be written one page at a time, each by a different person and thrown together with no editing. Unashamedly I would say this might be the worst acting performance we've seen out of either Oprah Winfrey or Reese Witherspoon and it is nothing short of cringeworthy. On top of all of this, an overly ambitious attempt to create the magical dimensions described in the original book lead to some of the worst CGI production seen in a major blockbuster in quite some time. As a matter of fact, the only reason I'm not giving this film any fewer stars is due to the fact that it doesn't look like it was filmed on a handy-cam.

This book was written to be imagined, not to be shown. But for anyone who read this book as a child and connected with it deeply, it's a deeply satisfying film. The emotions Meglyn expresses with her facial expressions and eyes - some adult actors don't approach her level. And the racial inclusiveness of the casting is a breath of fresh air. The special effects are beautiful but don't replace the heart of the story. The film doesn't go as deep into the darkness and terror of the It as I would have liked, but this is a children's movie so I get it. The message comes across regardless. If you loved the book as a child or are willing to watch it with childlike wonder - go for it. Especially now that it's available on Netflix.

"That was fine" was the consensus in my viewing party though it is fairly easy to see why this film did not work for most audiences. Unfortunately, I am going to have to wonder if the consistent flat characters and forced whimsical acting, is the fault of director Ava Duvernay. I have not seen Selma but it got lots of praise for its acting so I have my fingers crossed that the flat script etc was more at fault than the director. Duvernay is attached to DC/Warner Bros adaptation of The New Gods, a project that has the potential to break my heart, so I want her to succeed.
Chris Pine and Gugu Mbatha-Raw, as the only adult human characters in the film, are both very good and convincing. The rest of the talented cast are not given much to do besides be cute/menacing and explain the plot. 
There is a lot of story and science removed from the source material yet it seems like there is not enough happening on screen to justify the run time. Unlike, say, the Harry Potter films there is not enough story in the book to justify the edits and Wrinkle in Time is a thin experience.
No Charles Wallace I didn't forget your name. In fact I'll remember it for a long time.

I'm awe as I read some of the reviews for A Wrinkle In Time, which I just watched again as a treat. I find it an evolved type of inspirational movie that speaks to the heart of issues faced by distinct subjects. This movie is about a tenacious, fiery, young, black girl who through nature and nurture is strong yet not allowed to show any signs of it. It;'s about self acceptance and love. Then, when I see the scenes where she's instructed to embrace herself to "tesser well" and the reminder that "aberrations are far more interesting", i'm not surprised by the widespread reaction. It's a reaction of privilege. Imagine judging the movie on the CGI, as if that ever mattered in a movie taking on such an audacious topic. Even the missing paternal figure storyline fits well with the key audience and it's even refreshing. I come out of watching it with so many positive mantras and insights and I just hope that the intended audiences are like me and never listen to the mainstream bent reviews take. Just see the movie!! It will clean the lense of self-loathing that comes standard in this universes starter-pack.
Best movie I have seen in a while. My favorite movie to watch with my younger siblings! Defiantly recommended!

Its meant to be seen from a preteen or childs point of view. If I had seen this as a child I wouldve loved it. Watching it made me feel nostalgic more than anything. It was still entertaining nonetheless but one must read the book beforehand to fully follow along.

Mystical and infantile gibberish preached as a philosophy to inspire children to be social- justice warriors.  No kidding.  Two parents, physicists, claim that because electrons relate to another in an atom through probabilistic wave functions having spherical harmonics, then because the galaxy and humans have electrons, we merely need to dial in the love frequency to travel across the galaxy.  They preach this as a new non-standard quantum model and mathematical topology, to a room of physicists, who just don't get it  Good grief.  We have Hollywood writers and a director with an infantile understanding of physics and an infantile understanding of pretty much everything else, using this as the basis of a philosophy to inspire social justice warriors.  Wow, we really are ruled by an idiocracy.  The kids learn to "tesser" across the universe and they learn how to indulge in nonsensical emotional thoughts that will transform the universe.  Ok -- I no longer believe in freedom of speech.  Disney is helping propel us into an idiocracy,

In 5th grade, I discovered a "Wrinkle in Time."  I went back to the library again and asked the librarian to help me request every book of Madeleine L'engle. I have read the series several times since then and have found profound messages about evil and hoped, with Meg, that I could also be a defender of light. The movie was well done! Of course, it's not exactly like the books. It's not just a kids movie or book series. Quality job by all involved. Thank you for presenting it in such a talented manner!

OK. Suspend your disbelief, become childlike again and it's not a bad flick, although the bad guys are a bit unrealistic and overdone. I wanted this movie to be good because I am a fan of the book, but I was bored by it.  Even the actors looked bored, as if they didn't want to be in this movie, except for Reese Witherspoon.

If I could add zero stars I would. I had wanted to see this movie in theaters because of all the hype..... I can only imagine how disappointed the people who actually paid money to see this movie were. It was by far not the acting that was terrible, it was just the storyline. Basically in a nutshell ( spoiler alert) the dads a POS who abandons his family not once but TWICE!! Lol Thanks Disney for once again showing us what morals and family values are all about! I also could not get passed the plot holes, what happened to Calvin at the end of the movie!!?? It's like they just forgot that he was along for the ride and at the very end just decided to throw him back in and say " it's cool, I just hitched a ride back with your dad who left you to die for the second time"..... just terrible. Sucks to be Chris Pine in this movie, not sure he realized he was signing up to play the part of an A-hole.

Other than gorgeous special effects, a beautiful score, and lovable actors...that's really all there is to admire about the movie. The rest is a jumbled mess of...geez, I still don't know what. Never picked up the books to this, but when I'm left confused and still not knowing what the purpose to MULTIPLE scenes in this movie, you've done something wrong. The story made no sense, the plot was messy, and the script was just painfully obvious that someone didn't give a damn about this movie; which is truly a shame because the director is remarkable.

Once the movie passes the scene where they talk to the flowers (my favorite scene) it goes downhill from there. Why did Miss Whatsit turn into a giant flying leaf and fly with everyone if they truly weren't intending on seeking out the dad? Oh, because it was just meant as a visual gift for those who get distracted easily, and this movie is filled with TONS of visually amazing scenes that don't lead anywhere or are just there.

Also, whoever wrote this movie needs to understand that "intimidating" and the intellectual dialogue sounds completely absurd and silly from the mouths of children, and it also doesn't help that the child actor comes off as outright laughable when his big evil moment of stardom comes up.

Terrible and outright confusing movie.

I read the book when I was like 9 and remember not really understanding a lot of what was going on. I always kind of thought it was because I was only half paying attention. Watching this movie made me realize that the story was just all over the place. Things just happen, most of them seem to lack any real significance. 

Let's break one of these scenes down.The kids are taken to a magic world and ask flowers to help find their father. This makes sense. They are told to ask flowers where their father is. Weird, but sure, fine. The flowers say something in flower language, so Mrs. Whatsit turns into a giant flying lettuce leaf and carries the kids away. Oh, they must be going to find the father. A kid falls off and is caught by the flowers. Then they teleport to a completely different place. Wait...what? Why were we flying on the lettuce, if not to find the father? This kind of stuff happens repeatedly. Things that don't seem to drive the story forward, or they do, but we don't understand how or why.

There are parts of this movie that seem like they have to have been pulled directly from the book, because the writing is so atrocious on screen. I don't know how any living human being could have watched these scenes play out and not thought that they were unwatchable. Like one scene where a character goes "Charles Wallace...we're the same." and then they start multiplying small numbers by 2, therefore proving how special he is? Huh? What? These child actors too, oof. Jacob Tremblay, these kids are not.
It tries to be too "cool" and the characters are not believable.
WORST MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN.. Awful acting and confusing story line. I am still confused what happened in the movie. I am nothing but disappointed.

I expected a lot from this film based on the high praise of the original work, the star power, and the promise of 21st century special effects. I was ultimately disappointed with this effort from Ava DuVernay (Selma). Admittedly, the story is one that's challenging to translate to the big screen, and even with the special effects and the contributions of Oprah Winfrey, Mindy Kaling, and Reese Witherspoon, plus Chris Pine, it just wasn't enough to make this movie more watch-able. I felt no connection to the characters; they were somehow unemotional even with all that acting. I'm not sure what the point of all this was.
I personally loved it.  If you understand energy and connecting to others, this is the perfect movie for you.

I held off seeing this in the theater because as a lover of all Madeleine L'Engle's books, the trailer for this movie left me underwhelmed. But I finally decided to give it a chance this week on Netflix. Sadly, it was even worse than I'd expected. Even with a cast of star actors, it was all just too sappy and cutesy. I'm not usually the person who complains when movies deviate from the books, as I can almost always enjoy each for their own merits. But in this case, it felt like they took the bare bones of the book and turned it into a falsely bright and goody-goody story that simply didn't do justice to the original in any fashion. Also, I'm a fan of diversity. I usually don't mind at all when directors take liberties with the source material in order to offer diverse characters. But this was...overkill. It felt like someone (the director? Disney?) was trying to make a point of checking as many cultural/ethnic boxes as possible, even changing Charles Wallace to an adopted child in order to (it felt to me) include yet another diverse character. Don't get me wrong, the little boy who played Charles Wallace was brilliant. But on top of everything else, it just felt contrived. Overall, the movie was far too floofy and sugary, like the director was afraid the source story wasn't good enough or wouldn't be appealing enough to kids and adults (never mind it's been an award-winning, bestselling classic for decades). So it had to be prettied up and made to appear visually bright and colorful and magical, like the inside of a candy store. For me...it fell flat and I came away from it thinking it was one of the worst movies I've seen in a good long time. And I think I would have felt that way even if I had never read the book.

Absolute garbage. Disney is so far out of touch with its target audience. This film panders to a liberalist audience that only supports LGBT agendas. They were more concerned in a concentrated mix of ethnicities and alternate family models to further their all inclusive ideal. The beginning of the movie seems very contrived and more concerned with an appearance of diversity than in trying to tell a story. I watch movies to escape political agendas and personal beliefs of movie executives and producers.

The book won every children's book award under the sun.  It was hailed when my children was just the age of the heroine and her guypal, though it had been pubished a decade earlier.   They did a really fine job of this I think - except that, with the topic so much about the abstract and imagination, there would always be the problem:  when we make the story a film, the imagination  of the reader is no longer included - the images are there to see, NOT imagine any longer.  A HUGE berm in the road of such a film project.           

So for 50 years there was NO movie version of this top award-winning book.    But thanks to today's neat special effects, it was not a limited experience. The visuals in the film were not disappointing.

Simply a disgusting film. If the film changes so many things from the original book you must expect something new to come out of the film, such as new ideas and concepts. However, the only new side is the dreadful CGI and story. The beginning of the movie was paced very slowly and character set-up wasn't done too well.

The imagery and actors were fantastic. A fan of the story since childhood, my expectations were high and I wasn't disappointed. The pace was slow thus took away from the anxiety meg experiences throughout the story. It is suppose to be a science fiction suspense film, but since it was geared toward younger children I think they minimized the scary parts with the pace and music.

SPOILERS BELOW. 

I didn't love the old movie as much as the book and this new remake wasn't what I wanted in a movie about this book either but I understand why they did what they did. 

First of all THERE ARE SPOILERS here so don't read from here on out if u want to watch it fresh with no spoilers and want surprises. If u I ant to want it and get angry, read the book. Wait a week. Read it again. Refer to the book often to fact check before watching it so you have it all in your head. And honestly I think he first movie was worse in comparison to the new one so if u really want to enjoy this one, watch them both so you will like Disney's new one more. Continuing on now. 

The book was amazing. I've read it perhaps six times in thirty years and don't remember but I may have done a report on it once and probably discussed the book often with other readers and peers so keep it in mind during my review. Also I have read all the books and have about decent memory if not total understandIng of the series as well so some things missing irritate me. That's a big problem I have with the new movie as well that colors my perspective. I also have a strong belief in keeping true to the original book and series when making a movie and can see reasoning as to why things were cut for production and time reasons but I don't like them and this also colors my perspective. But I will try to be fair. Here goes. 

So a lot was cut out or barely mentioned from the book in the new movie. The Jenkins arc was barely referenced and and not touched upon at all. That sucks. Time was probably the main reason, and that goes for a lot of my gripes. 

The movie had hardly no impact or reference for this being a battle for Charles Wallace's "soul" or being forced to conform to society or remain an individual. Time again probably and maybe it was too deep for a Disney movie. Disney probably didn't want the artraction of meg and Calvin as a focal point due to their ages I'd guess. I dont think Charles Wallace was adopted in the book, but it made some sense for the tension of the IT controlled kid to play into his attitude to the Dad. I'll attribute that to creative license I guess. But I think it also lessens the love of meg to Charles Wallace and that isn't my feelings of an adopted kid being loved less or anything, certainly not according to my believes or anything in my life, I'm just assuming it wasn't done to help explain the dialogue used in the movie. Opinion only as I said. 

I don't remember the dog being in any scenes but my kid said it was there somewhere so it probably wasn't but had no impact on me watching it and so time probably was the reason as we'll as the big boy being integral so there u go. Think it wasn't called fortinbras in the book and I vaguely remember hearing someone say FORT early on so okay whatever. Calvin's one or two lines about his home life in response to meg talking about why who used Calvin know about not being accepted everywhere and maybe he was only looked at as a jock to me felt overlooked and mentioned briefly as a nod to what was actually pretty important to his character background and thus making him more important to being in the film at all. Without that backstory or such I just saw him as being hungry a couple times and pretty useless in the movie except to play as a foil to meg in showing they shouldn't stay and conform on the planet with the mustached guy. Sigh. May as well have taken him completely ouT of the film without all that. Like they basically did with Jenkins. Jenkins is super important in my opinion to the story as his arc with meg and Charles giving them backstory and how they don't really fit in at school but it was all basically cut.  Time probably was the reason and they chose to focus on the rescue. 

I thought Charles was basically a recluse and mute at school in the book. Don't remember him going off like the movie had him do. I'll give it to them because it made him more attractive on screen as a good little brother and defensive of his family which made his turn against his dad when the it controlled him more impactful on the screen so I get it even though i like the book setup much more. And the teachers knowing Charles was gifted I thought was important to tell the audience in the movie since they cut out all the family interaction really so o understand it if not agree with the choice. 

I don't remember seeing the twins at all. Which in addition to all the stuff that was cut from the movie that was in the book makes me strongly believe that they have absolutely no plans on doing the other books as movies. They are sort of inportant in other books, and what interactions and dialogue that wasn't in the movie about a lot of these things make doing the sequels harder without laying the groundwork now. I really think that they should have committed more and done this as a multipart miniseries of maybe five or six hours and done it to scale and really fleshed out the entire book. If Disney got the rights just to make money on a single movie and ignore the rest, then all the cuts make sense. So in my jaded opinion they did this as a money grab and edited it down to what was integral in their timeframe and ignored the rest or made just passing reference to parts that the book used to help tell the entire story. I truly believe they just wanted to make money on a single movie and cut way too much. As a whole the book should really be told in its entirety. 

The special effects were good. Disney I think threw too much music into the score and at times it needed to be lower in volume so the dialogue was more distinct. In some cases the inpactfulness of a scene and the essential dialogue and acting was reduced by loud music and scoring. 

The story was really dumbed down for the audience, and maybe that is because it was aimed at kids and not people who know the book. He wanted to entertain and not have kids ask parents questions during the film. I'm guessing that in that vein they accomplished their goal and that wasn't meant to insult any kids or their intelligence. I feel that the book was aimed at perhaps a sixteen year old kid up to an adult in their twenties. This movie I feel was aimed at kids from ten to sixteen and if they are on the younger side obviously to be watched with their parents. Purely an opinion. I haven't any idea on how bright kids are now or what their level of understanding is. I'm going by ages of kids from my era. I am about forty years old to give you a reference point. Again, no insult intended to anyone's intelligence level is intended. I am guessing. And obviously this is a Disney movie I assume is aimed at a younger demographic. I feel they only just barely touched on meg and her faults and acceptance or embracing of such and honestly the focus of her love for (or of if u prefer) Charles Wallace was obviously there but not as impactful as in the book. Either by design or not I am not sure. It didn't seem like the major focal point or epiphany as the book intended in my opinion, because I'd think that Disney would beat you over the head with it in a movie. I appreciated it not being in a way that obviously pandered to me, but it did seem underwhelming in comparison to the book. And I don't know if I like their choice or not. 

If I'm remembering correctly, meg was at l set at one point in the book "lost" or being taken over by the IT and she needed to be brought back into "herself" for lack of a better term.  All I can find in the movie that is sort of like this is when her dad is trying to bring her back or wake her up whatever the hell was going on there. As I recall in the book, she needed to recite chemistry or math problems or something GROUNDED IN SCIENCE and her brain and memory and knowledge to recover her being. That didn't happen here. Her dad basically just called her name and shook her or something and she was back. Then he was going to leave her again (after saying minutes earlier I'd never leave you and then said he never meant to be gone so long but that has nothing to do with his original choice to actually leave her and now he's doing it again which i chuckled at after pausing the movie to point this out to my family as we were all watching it together and after thinking about it since then has made me angrier at the illogic and poor wording.). Well, the only thing close to the recovery of megs core being from the book is ironically how the IT got control of Charles Wallace in the movie. Reciting the two times table. Which is mathematics. Which in the book is a major part of what makes meg a standout if not as a student but an intelligent girl. It sort of fits the narrative the movie shows as an obvious logical pattern. The bouncing balls the kids do in the driveways and the houses and identical mothers speaking in unison. I get it. Anyone watching the movie has figured out this obvious connection. So maybe I'm not remembering the book perfectly because I was sure meg was amazing at math and reciting facts about such was how she was recovered in the book. Maybe it was chemistry which is basically just math in the number of electrons to join elements together or maybe it was her calculating pi or an equation which is not repeating or something that would stand out as a pattern but I'm pretty sure math was involved as a few of the questions either Calvin or her dad or Charles Wallace used to bring her back. And I think it happened twice actually. But the movie didn't use anything to bring her back. That pissed me off. 

Now I am almost CERTAIN there was not even a mention of a farandolae (excuse the spelling if it's off) with a name that had to bury or root itself and grow or something and it was actually inside Charles Wallace and it was the one deciding factor that would determine if he was going to go good or bad, conform or stay individual, etc. He had a name too. Now it HAS BEEN several years since I read any of the books at all so I'm going off a memory of at least a dozen years here. Maybe I'm wrong and this is from a later book. But I am pretty sure it's from WRINKLE and it was a major part of the story.  Why was this cut?  Time?  Didn't want to scare or confuse kids?  Keep focus of movie on rescuing Dad?  Too deep into science or sci-fi?  Any or all. Whatever the reason, I feel this was a tremendous loss. Didn't Megan's love of the farandolae youngster rescue him and help him root and win the battle and he helped them later?  This whole adventure near the end seemed to take place on a planet. I thought the "planet" was a short stay like a weigh station to rest up and return to the battle later when they met up with the witches again and then the entire time after was inside Charles Wallace. Was the dad inside Charles Wallace?  Not sure I remember if they rescued their dad from inside him or what in the book, but they did seem to simplify all this to not confuse the audience (I still believe it's mainly aimed at kids anyway) and removed even more science from this story. 

There's more I didn't like. I truly hated a great deal of things in the film that were either changed, dumbed down, barely referenced, or missing completely that were in the book. And this stuff happens. I get that doing this movie in full like the book would probably take twice as long. I get it. Maybe even five hours. People won't sit for that in a theater. And probably not kids. Got u. Disney HAS A NETWORK.  Maybe multiple ones I don't know. Channels. They could easily have shot this into five or so hours and cut it up into a miniseries. Show it an hour a day for five days. Or three episodes of two apiece I dunno. They could have done this I mean they have the distribution and can release a two disc set for sale as well as showing it over a couple days and advertise  it I mean they have the money airtime network distribution...they have the means. Why sacrifice so much to throw out another two hour movie and cut so much and adapt it for such a different audience???

It is an injustice to those of us that wanted to see the book fleshed out and done fully. I think they cut way too much story, arcs, and dumbed it down for a different target demographic than what the book was originally intended. For a two hour fantasy movie, I guess it was okay. They made money. I think lots of it. But this wasn't what I could or should have been and they left a lot more money on the table for future use. The other books. A longer movie replacing this also fills more airtime and builds the watching audience up begging for more. Sequels on the other books. And they could ALWAYS cut down the original long version I'd have preferred and adapted it into this film or even reshot it. Hell they could have animated this into a cartoon later or done it with the ducks like they did with the old Christmas special or even the (non-Disney) chipmunks go to the movies series they used to adapt famous movies. 

There were several options to utilize with their VAST RESOURCES that would have been superior to this movie version and they could have banked on what I listed above as spinoffs or the like AFTER doing this film. Which I'm sure they won't do. I assume they own the rights now to the book and likely the series. Why not start off with a long true to story version that's longer and uses everything in the first book and leaving the seeds for the others later down the line?  Like I said they could edit and shorten it to make a second version close to what they made, and even gone animated even for it. As is, they made a movie that is based on a good book and honestly in my opinion this was a one and done with absolutely no thought to the rest of the books. It's not as deep as the book, it's in my opinion dumbed down and devoid of the science and math and several plot points and story arcs that are needed for later, and all I see is a very base version of what could have been excellent. 

I described this movie to my family before we watched it to  never ending story, narnia (which I never read or saw,) with some science and sci-fi aspects like sliders and star trek. I was just throwing things out that they were familiar with to give an idea mind you. That's not what we watched. This was devoid of science, plot points and story arcs, the characters were much less deep with less background and detail, and it was to me honestly aimed at young children.  There was nothing really that parents and kids could sit down with and explain afterwards or even during, certainly nothing to prompt multiple viewings to take specific note of dialogue to look deeper into the characters, and t was almost totally based on the power of love as well as accepting ones faults and loving yourself despite them. Not because of them. Not because your faults make u unique and working towards betting yourself because now you know what they are, which honestly is where I figured they would end up like an old afternoon special tv show on the weekends on abc which I think Disney owns that channel anyway, but it's a block of a couple hours that doesn't make one think nearly as much as the book and is missing way too much. 

This is an opinion. I don't proclaim to be a master of knowing everything about all the books or even the one book this was based on. I admit I haven't read them in years. I haven't watched the original movie in years. My memory is not perfect. And again, I don't mean to criticize anyone that enjoyed this version, the prior one, nor the books. I don't mean to come across as condescending or insulting younger viewers when I say this was aimed at a younger demographic of kids or that it was dumbed down. It was fine. It was entertaining. The special effects were good and the dialogue from what I remember had important lines I think were unchanged or slightly perhaps, and maybe some was completely new or out of order or context, whatever. This is solely my opinion. And it was a good movie. I just think it wasn't aimed at the same group of people the book was, the movie was missing a lot of stuff that I as a child and also now as an adult kept me guessing, forced me to think more, and want to read the other books. This movie was less than the book, and I don't want to rewatch it to find more clues I may have missed and I certainly don't want to learn about science after watching it because it was much more about fantasy and not science or sci-fi. It was fine. I think it could have been awesome. Whatever was added to the production by visually watching it was hampered by what I could not find in the movie that was in the book. And I truly feel they wasted future opportunities by removing so much. And I understand that they had to fit it into a movie and cut things. But...did they have to really?  It probably did well and made money. Maybe a true to book version while much longer may not have done as welll. Probably not. But adults like me who read even only that book were not satisfied and wanted more. They could shorten it later and edit another version like this one. Animate it. Put the long one on tv as a miniseries or something and if not shorten it for theatrical release then reshoot it and use the long version to promote it in theaters or on dvd. 

Never ending story was superior as a film for theaters in my opinion. Forget the story aspect...that's subjective...but the  defects even for the time in my opinion were great and both films sort of were told the same way and ended the same way generally speaking. Feel good at the end. Both were fantasy and not about science. The book had more science, and many more things as I said before that were not in the movie. Was there a neverendinn story book before the film?  Maybe. I don't know. Really I don't. If there was maybe the same sort of cuts were made there. But if know there were two sequels of movies to it and if there were three books or more written before the film maybe some people said the same things then. If so then maybe the two sequel movies have nothing to do with the original books of ther was a series written prior. But I do know that this new movie left no reason for me to wait for another film. There were no hints or seeds left to entice me.

We got them all and watched them as a marathon. Y s we saw the original and then the next two straight through despite seeIf the first the day before.

I whispered to the oldest that there are three (I think) after this one. Wind in the door and swiftly tilting planet, I forget the other. I do have a copy of each. She's demanding to see them now. But she is going to finish number two and then be on three when the young ones start 2. 

Now I have to point out here I didn't think they'd all stay interested. And they're are bathroom breaks and snacks and dinner and such going on here. But far as I can tell they watched last night. Well keeping this many kids caring about this on their own for so long is ridiculous. Just saying. Hey maybe a longer movie with ALL THE STUFF from the original book would HAVE MADE MORE SENSE.
